projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Turkey Buzzard, Jo≈ø≈øelyn.‚ÄîLaw≈øon, 138.‚ÄîCate≈øby, i. 6.‚ÄîBancroft, 152.‚ÄîDu Pratz, ii. 77.
Vultur Aura, Lin. Sy≈øt. 122.‚ÄîDe Buffon, i. 175.‚ÄîPl. Enl. No 187.

div.p: WEIGHT four pounds and an half. Head ≈ømall,DESCRIPTION. covered with a naked wrinkled red ≈økin, be≈øet with black bri≈øtles. This gives it ≈øome re≈øemblance to a Turkey; from which it derives one of the names. The no≈øtrils are very large, and pervious: the whole plumage is du≈øky, da≈øhed with purple and green: legs of a dirty fle≈øh-color: claws black.

The≈øe birds are common from Nova Scotia to Terra del Fuego; PLACE. but ≈øwarm in the hotter parts of America; and are found in the i≈ølands, where they are ≈øaid to be far inferior in ≈øize to tho≈øe of North America.

In the warm climates they keep in va≈øt flocks.MANNERS. Perch at night on rocks or trees; ≈øitting with di≈øhevelled wings to purify their bodies,
which are mo≈øt offen≈øively fetid. Towards morning they take flight, ≈øoaring at a va≈øt height, with the gentle motion of a kite; expecting notice of their banquet by the tainted effluvia of carrion, excrements, or any filth. They have mo≈øt ≈øagacious no≈øtrils, and ≈ømell their prey at a va≈øt di≈øtance; to which they re≈øort from all quarters, wheeling about, and making a gradual de≈øcent till they reach the ground. They do not confine them≈øelves to dead animals, but feed on Snakes, and ≈øometimes on Lambs. They are very tame, and, while they are at their meals, will ≈øuffer a very near approach.

In the torrid zone, particularly about Carthagena, they haunt inhabited places, and are ≈øeen in numbers ≈øitting on the roofs of the hou≈øes, or walking along the ≈øtreets with a ≈øluggi≈øh pace. In tho≈øe parts they are u≈øeful, as the IBIS in Egypt, devouring the noi≈øome ≈øubjects, which would otherwi≈øe, by the intolerable ≈øtench, render the climate ≈øtill more unwhole≈øome than it is.

When the≈øe birds find no food in the cities, they are driven by hunger among the cattle of the neighboring pa≈øtures. If they ≈øee a bea≈øt with a ≈øore on the back, they in≈øtantly alight on it, and attack the part affected. The poor animal attempts in vain to free it≈øelf from the devourers, rolling on the ground with hideous cries: but in vain; for the Vultures never quit hold, till they have effected its de≈øtruction. Sometimes an Eagle pre≈øides at the banquet, and keeps the≈øe cowardly birds at a di≈øtance, until it has fini≈øhed its repa≈øt.

USES.Mi≈øchievous as they are in a few in≈øtances, yet, by the wi≈øe and beneficent di≈øpen≈øations of Providence, they make in the hot climates full recompence, by le≈ø≈øening the number of tho≈øe de≈øtructive animals the Alligators, which would otherwi≈øe become intolerable by their multitudes. During the ≈øea≈øon in which the≈øe reptiles lay their eggs in the ≈øand, the Vultures will ≈øit hid in the leaves of the trees, watching the coming of the female Alligator to depo≈øit its eggs, who then covers them with ≈øand, to ≈øecure them, as ≈øhe imagines, from all danger: but no ≈øooner does ≈øhe retire into the water,
than the birds dart on the ≈øpot, and with claws, wings, and beak, tear away the ≈øand, and devour the whole contents of the depo≈øitory.

No birds of this genus are found in northern regions of Europe or A≈øia, at le≈øt in tho≈øe latitudes which might give them a pretence of appearing here. I cannot find them in our quarter of the globe higher than the Gri≈øon Alps Wil. Orn. 67. , or Sile≈øia Schwenckfeldt av. Sile≈øia, 375. ; or at farthe≈øt Kali≈øh, in Great Poland Rzaczyn≈øki, Hi≈øt. Nat. Polon. 298. . Certainly the Count De Buffon was mi≈øinformed as to the habitation of the ≈øpecies, which he a≈øcribes to Norway Hi≈øt D'Oi≈ø. i. 164. Pl. Enl. 449. . In the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions, the Bearded Vulture of Mr. Edwards, iii. tab. 106. breeds on the high rocks of the great Altaic chain, and beyond lake Baikal Dr. PALLAS'S Catalogue of the Birds of the Ru≈ø≈øian empire, which he favored me with in MS. my ≈øure≈øt clue to the Arctic birds.; which may give it in Europe a latitude of 52. 20. in A≈øia of 55.

div.head: 86. A. SEA EAGLE.

list.item: Br. Zool. i. No 44.
Falco O≈ø≈øifragus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 124.‚ÄîLatham, i. 30.‚ÄîPl Enl. 12. 415.
Grey Eagle, Law≈øon, 137.
Land Oern, Leems, 230.
L'Orfraie, De Buffon, i. 112. pl. 3.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: VARIES a little from the Briti≈øh ≈øpecies, and is much ≈øuperior in ≈øize. The length three feet three inches; of wing, twenty-five inches.

Feathers on head, neck, and back, brown, edged with dirty white: chin white: brea≈øt and belly brown, ≈øpotted with white: coverts of wings brown, clouded; primaries black: tail du≈øky; the middle mottled with white: legs feathered half down.

PLACE.Very common in the northern parts of America, and endures its ≈øevere≈øt winters, even as high as Newfoundland. The≈øe birds prey on ≈øea fowls, as well as land, and on young Seals, which they ≈øeize floating, and carry out of the water.

Eagles, and all ≈øorts of birds of prey, abound in America, where ≈øuch quantity of game is found. Multitudes are always ≈øeen below the falls of Niagara, invited by the carca≈øes of Deer, Bears, and other animals, which are ≈øo frequently hurried down in attempting to cro≈øs the river above this ≈øtupendous cataract.

This ≈øpecies is very frequent in Kamt≈øchatka; and is found during ≈øummer even on the Arctic coa≈øt: is very common in Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria; nor is it more rare about the Ca≈øpian ≈øea, where they breed on the loftie≈øt trees.

div.head: 87. BLACK EAGLE.

list.item: Br. Zool. i. No 43.
Falco Fulvus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 125.‚ÄîLatham, i. 32, No 6.
White-tailed Eagle, Edw. i. 1.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.
L'Aigle commun, De Buffon, i. 86,‚ÄîPl. Enl. 409.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: THE whole plumage is of a du≈øky-brown: the brea≈øt marked with triangular ≈øpots of white; in which it varies from the Briti≈øh kind: the tail white, tipt with black; but in young birds du≈øky, blotched with white: legs covered to the toes with ≈øoft ru≈øt-colored feathers: vent feathers of the ≈øame color.

Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay, and northern Europe as far as Drontheim E≈øpecially in the winter, Leems, 233..PLACE. Is found on the highe≈øt rocks of the Uralian chain, where it is not covered with woodDr. Pallas.; but is mo≈øt frequent on the Sibirian, where it makes its ne≈øt on the loftie≈øt rocks. It is rather inferior in ≈øize to the former; but is a generous, ≈øpirited, and docile bird. The independent Tartars train it for the chace of Hares, Foxes, Antelopes, and even Wolves. The u≈øe is of con≈øiderable antiquity; for Marco Polo, the great traveller of 1269, ob≈øerved and admired the diver≈øion of the great Cham of Tartary; who had ≈øeveral Eagles, which were applied to the ≈øame purpo≈øes as they are at pre≈øentM. Polo, in Purchas, iii. 85. in Bergeron. 74. . I mu≈øt add, that the Tartars e≈øteem the feathers of the tail as the be≈øt they have for pluming their arrows.

The Kalmucs u≈øe, be≈øides this ≈øpecies of Eagle, that which the French call Jean le Blanc De Buffon., and al≈øo the Lanner; all which breed among them: but people of rank, who are curious in their Falcons, procure from the Ba≈øchkirians the Gyrfalcon and the Peregrine, which inhabit the lofty mountains of the country Extracts, iii. 303. A name by which I quote an abridgement of the travels of PALLAS, GMELIN, LEPECHIN, and others, publi≈øhed by the SOCIETE TYPOGRAPHIQUE, at Berne, under the title of HISTOIRE DES DECOUVERTES, faites par divers ≈øavans voyageurs dans plu≈øieurs contre√®s de la Ru≈ø≈øie et de la Per≈øe, 4 vols. 8vo..

div.head: 88. BLACK-CHEEKED EAGLE.
div.p: F. With a du≈øky and blue bill; yellow cere: head, neck, and brea≈øt, of a deep a≈øh-color: each cheek marked with a broad black bar pa≈ø≈øing from the corner of the mouth beyond the eyes: back, belly, wings, and tail, black: legs yellow, feathered below the knees.

SIZE, AND PLACE.Is about the ≈øize of the la≈øt. Communicated to me by the late Taylor White, E≈øq who informed me that it came from North America. Is de≈øcribed by Mr. Latham, i. 35, No 10; and ≈øeems to be the ≈øpecies engraven by M. Robert, among the birds in the menagery of Louis XIV.

div.head: 89. WHITE-HEADED EAGLE.

list.item: Falco Leucocephalus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 124.
Bald Eagle, Law≈øon, 137.‚ÄîCate≈øby, i. 1Le Pygargue a t√™te blanche, De Buffon, i. 99. Pl. Enl. 411.. Brickell, 173.‚ÄîLatham, i. 29.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.
Le Pygargue a t√™te blanche, De Buffon, i. 99.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 411.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: BILL, cere, and feet, pale yellow: head, neck, and tail, of a pure white: body and wings of a chocolate-color. It does not acquire its white head till the ≈øecond year.

This Eagle is le≈ø≈øer than the foregoing ≈øpecies, but of great ≈øpirit: preys on Fawns,MANNERS. Pigs, Lambs, and fi≈øh: is the terror of the O≈øprey, who≈øe motions it watches. The moment the latter has ≈øeized a fi≈øh, the former pur≈øues till the O≈øprey drops its prey; which, with amazing dexterity, it catches before it falls to the ground, be the di≈øtance ever ≈øo great. This is matter of great amu≈øement to the inhabitants of North America, who often watch their aerial conte≈øts. This ≈øpecies frequently attends the ≈øport≈øman, and ≈ønatches up the game he has ≈øhot, before he can reach it.

The≈øe birds build in va≈øt decayed cypre≈ø≈øesCate≈øby., or pines, impending over the ≈øea, or ≈øome great river, in company with O≈øpreys, Herons, and other birds: and their ne≈øts are ≈øo numerous, as to re≈øemble a rookery. The ne≈øts are very large, and very fetid by rea≈øon of
the reliques of their prey. Law≈øon ≈øays, they breed very often, laying again under their callow young; who≈øe warmth hatches the eggs. In Bering's i≈øle they make their ne≈øts on the cliffs, near ≈øix feet wide, and one thick; and lay two eggs in the beginning of July.

div.head: 90. WHITE EAGLE.
div.p: THIS mo≈øt beautiful and ≈øcarce ≈øpecies is entirely white, except the tips of the wings, which are black. We know nothing of this bird, but what is collected from Du Pratz Du Pratz, ii. 75. Latham, i. 36. . The natives of Loui≈øiana ≈øet a high value on the feathers, and give a large price for tho≈øe of the wings; with them they adorn the Calumet, or pipe of peace. Different nations make u≈øe of the wings, or feathers of different birds; but, according to Hennepin, always decorate it with the mo≈øt beautiful.

The Calumet is an in≈øtrument of the fir≈øt importance among the Americans. It is nothing more than a pipe,CALUMET. who≈øe bowl is generally made of a ≈øoft red marbleDu Pratz, i. 298. Kalm, iii. 230. : the tube of a very long reed, ornamented with the wings and feathers of birds. No affair of con≈øequence is tran≈øacted without the Calumet. It ever appears in meetings of commerce, or exchanges; in congre≈ø≈øes for determining of peace or war; and even in the very fury of a battle. The acceptance of the Calumet is a mark of concurrence with the terms propo≈øed; as the refu≈øal is a certain mark of rejection. Even in the rage of a conflict this pipe is ≈øometimes offered; and if accepted, the weapons of de≈øtruction in≈øtantly drop from their hands, and a truce en≈øues. It ≈øeems the ≈øacrament of the Savages; for no compact is ever violated, which is confirmed by a whiff from this holy reed. The Dance of the Calumet is a ≈øolemn rite which always confirms a peace, or precedes a war. It is divided into three parts: the fir≈øt, appears an act of devotion, danced in mea≈øured time: the ≈øecond, is a true repre≈øentation of the Pyrrhic dance Strabo, lib. x. p. 736. edit. Am≈øtel. 1707.: the third, is attended with ≈øongs expre≈ø≈øive of the victories they had obtained, the nations they had conquered, and the captives they had made.

From the winged ornaments of the Calumet, and its conciliating u≈øes, writers compare it to the Caduceus of Mercury, which was carried by the Caduceatores, or me≈ø≈øengers of peace, with terms to the ho≈øtile ≈øtates. It is ≈øingular, that the mo≈øt remote nations, and the mo≈øt oppo≈øite in their other cu≈øtoms and manners, ≈øhould in ≈øome things have, as it were, a certain con≈øent of thought. The Greeks and the Americans had the ≈øame idea, in the invention of the Caduceus of the one, and the Calumet of the other. Some authors imagine, that among the Greeks the wings were meant as a ≈øymbol of eloquence. I rather think that the twi≈øted Serpents expre≈ø≈øed that in≈øinuating faculty; and that the emblem was originally taken from the fatal effect the rhetoric of Satan had on our great mother, when he a≈ø≈øumed the form of that reptile, which the highe≈øt authority repre≈øents as more ≈øubtile than any bea≈øt of the field. On this the heathen mythology formed their tale of Jupiter taking the figure of a Serpent, to in≈øinuate him≈øelf into the good graces of Olympias; who, like Eve, fell a victim to his per≈øua≈øive tongue. As to the wings, it is mo≈øt probable that they were to ≈øhew the flight of di≈øcord; which the reconciled parties gave, with all the horrors of war, to the air, and ≈øport of the winds.

The Oole, or Eagle, is a ≈øacred bird among the Americans. In ca≈øe of ≈øickne≈øs, they invoke this bird to de≈øcend from heaven (which in its exalted flight it approaches nearer than any other) and bring down refre≈øhing things; as it can dart down on its rapid wing quick as a fla≈øh of lightningAdair's Hi≈øt. Am. Indians, 179. .

div.head: 91. OSPREY.

list.item: Fi≈øhing Hawk, Cate≈øby, i. 2.‚ÄîLaw≈øon, 137.‚ÄîBrickell, 173.
O≈øprey. Jo≈ø≈øelyn's Rarities, ii.‚ÄîBr. Zool. i. No 46.‚ÄîLatham, i. 45.

Falco Haliaetus. Blafot. Fi≈øk-orn, Faun. Suec. No 63.

div.p: F. With blue cere, and feet: head, and lower part of the body, white: upper part brown: two middle feathers of the tail plain brown; the re≈øt barred with white and brown.

This, in all re≈øpects, re≈øembles the European kind.MANNERS. Notwith≈øtanding it is ≈øo per≈øecuted by the Bald Eagle, yet it always keeps near its haunts. It is a ≈øpecies of va≈øt quickne≈øs of ≈øight; and will ≈øee a fi≈øh near the ≈øurface from a great di≈øtanceThat agreeable traveller, the reverend Dr. Burnaby, adds, that it is often ≈øeen re≈øting on the wing for ≈øome minutes, without any vi≈øible change of place, before it de≈øcends. Travels in America, 2d ed. p. 48.: de≈øcend with prodigious rapidity, and carry the prey with an exulting ≈øcream high into the air. The Eagle hears the note, and in≈øtantly attacks the O≈øprey; who drops the fi≈øh, which the former catches before it can reach the ground, or water. It ≈øometimes happens that the O≈øprey peri≈øhes in taking its prey; for if it chances to fix its talons in an over-grown fi≈øh, it is drawn under water before it can di≈øengage it≈øelf, and is drowned.

It is very frequent in Kamt≈øchatka; and in ≈øummer,PLACE. even under the Arctic zone of Europe and A≈øia. Is very common in Sibiria, and ≈øpreads far north; probably common to the north of America, and A≈øia. Is rare in Ru≈ø≈øia. It is likewi≈øe very frequent as low on the Wolga as the tract between Sy≈øran and Saratoff, where they are ≈øaid to be the ≈øupport of the Ern Eagle, as they are of the White-tailed Eagle in America, each living by the labors of the O≈øprey. The Tartars have a ≈øuper≈øtition, that a wound from its claws is mortal, either to man or fi≈øh, and con≈øequently dread its attackExtracts, i. 479. .

div.p: F. With a yellow cere, and feet: head, neck, and brea≈øt, of a yellowi≈øh white, marked with a few oblong brown ≈øpots: belly of a deep brown: thighs white, ≈øtriped with brown: ≈øcapulars blotched with yellowi≈øh white and brown: coverts of the wings edged with ru≈øt-color; primaries black: tail, little longer than the wings; the part next to the rump white; the end marked with a black bar; the tips white: legs feathered to the toes: feet yellow. Length two feet two inches.SIZE.
PLACE.Inhabits England, Norway, Lapmark, and North America. Was ≈øhot in Connecticut.

div.head: 93. ST. JOHN'S.

list.item: Latham, i. 77, No 58.

div.p: F. F. With a ≈øhort ≈øtrong bill, toothed on the upper mandible, of a blui≈øh color: cere yellow: irides hazel: forehead whiti≈øh: crown, and hind part of the head, du≈øky: the back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of wings, elegantly barred with deep blue and black: the

The American ≈øpecies is larger than the European. They are ≈øubject to vary. The black Falcon, and the ≈øpotted Falcon of Mr. Edwards, are of this kind; each pre≈øerve a ≈øpecific mark, in the black ≈øtroke which drops from beneath the eyes, down towards the neck. The differences in the marks in the tail may po≈ø≈øibly proceed from the different ages of the birds; for few kinds differ ≈øo much in the ≈øeveral periods of life as the Rapacious.

Inhabits different parts of North America, PLACE. from Hud≈øon's Bay as low as Carolina. In A≈øia, is found on the highe≈øt parts of the Uralian and Sibirian chain. Wanders in ≈øummer to the very Arctic circle. Is common in Kamt≈øchatka.

div.head: 99. GOSHAWK.

div.p: F. With a blui≈øh bill, black at the tip: yellowi≈øh green cere: yellow legs: head brown; hind part mottled with white: over each eye extends a long whiti≈øh line: hind part of the neck, back, and wings, of a deep brown color: brea≈øt and belly white, cro≈ø≈øed with numerous undulated lines of brown: tail of a cinereous brown, cro≈ø≈øed by four or five bars of black: wings ≈øhorter than the tail.

That which I ≈øaw in the Leverian Mu≈øeum, was ≈øuperior in ≈øize to the European. PLACE. Mr. Law≈øon ≈øays, they abound in Carolina: are ≈øpirited birds, but le≈ø≈øer than tho≈øe of Mu≈øcovy. Is common in that country,A WHITE VARIETY. and Sibiria. Dr. Pallas adds, that there is a large white variety on the Uralian mountains, mottled with brown and yellow. The≈øe are yet more frequent in the ea≈øt part of Sibiria; and in Kamt≈øchatka they are entirely white. The≈øe are the be≈øt of all Hawks for falconry.EXCELLENT FOR FALCONRY. They extend to the river Amur; and are u≈øed by the emperor of China in his ≈øporting progre≈ø≈øes Bell. ii. 87., attended by his grand falconer, and a thou≈øand of the ≈øubordinate. Every bird has a ≈øilver plate fa≈øtened to its foot, with the name of the falconer who had the charge of it; that in ca≈øe it ≈øhould be lo≈øt, it might be brought to the proper per≈øon: but if he could not be found, the bird is delivered to another officer, called the Guardian of lo≈øt birds; who keeps it till it is demanded by the falconer to whom it belonged. That this great officer may the more readily be found, among the army of hunters, who attend the emperor, he erects a ≈øtandard in the mo≈øt con≈øpicuous placeBergeron, 75, 76. .

The emperor often carries a Hawk on his hand, to let fly at any game which pre≈øents it≈øelf; which are u≈øually Phea≈øants, Partridges, Quails, or Cranes. Marco Polo ≈øaw this diver≈øion about the year
1269Bergeron, 75. 76. ; a proof of its antiquity in the≈øe parts, when it formed ≈øo regular and princely an e≈øtabli≈øhment in the ≈øtate of this great ea≈øtern monarch; the origin of which might have been in ≈øome long preceding age. The cu≈øtom of carrying a Falcon extended to many countries, and was e≈øteemed a di≈øtinction of a man of rank. The Wel≈øh had a ≈øaying, that you may know a gentleman by his Hawk, Hor≈øe, and Grehound. In fact, a per≈øon of rank ≈øeldom went without one on his hand. Harold, afterwards king of England, is painted going on a mo≈øt important emba≈ø≈øy, with a Hawk on his hand, and a Dog under his armMonumens de la Monarchie Fran√ßoi≈øe, i. 372. . Henry VI. is repre≈øented at his nuptials, attended by a nobleman and his FalconMr. Walpole's Anecdotes of Painting, i. 33. . Even the ladies were not without them, in earlier times; for in an antient ≈øculpture in the church of Milton Abbas, in Dor≈øet≈øhire, appears the con≈øort of King Athel≈øtan with a Falcon on her royal fi≈øt Hutchins's Dor≈øet≈øhire, ii. 443. tearing a bird: and, perhaps to indulge his queen in her pa≈ø≈øion for the diver≈øion, he demanded of my countrymen (be≈øides an immen≈øe tribute) ≈øome of their mo≈øt excellent Hounds, and of their be≈øt Hawks: which proves the high e≈øteem in which our Dogs and Falcons were held in tho≈øe early daysMalm≈øbury, lib. ii. c. 6. .

div.head: 112. DUBIOUS.
div.p: F. With a du≈øky bill: yellow cere and irides: head du≈øky, ≈øtreaked with ru≈øt-color: back and coverts of wings brown, edged with ru≈øt; the primaries du≈øky a≈øh-color, barred with black, and the inner webs marked tran≈øver≈øely with oval ferruginous ≈øpots: tail long, of a deep cinereous, with four broad bars of black: brea≈øt and belly dirty white, marked with oblong ≈øtreaks of brown: legs yellow.
Length about ten inches. Weight ≈øix ounces.SIZE. In the marks and colors of the tail it much re≈øembles the Sparrow Hawk: in the ≈øpots on the brea≈øt it agrees with the Engli≈øh Merlin.
Inhabits New York and Carolina. PLACE. I have my doubts whether this is any more than a variety of the preceding, e≈øpecially as the Engli≈øh SPARROW HAWK varies with the ≈øame colors.

div.head: 113. DUSKY.
div.p: F. With a blui≈øh bill; upper mandible armed with a ≈øharp proce≈øs; yellow cere: head, back, and coverts of the wings, and tail, a du≈øky brown, ≈ølightly edged with ferruginous: hind part of the neck ≈øpotted with white: primaries du≈øky; inner webs marked with oval ≈øpots of a pale ru≈øt-color: tail ≈øhort, tipped with white, and barred with four broad du≈øky ≈øtrokes, and the ≈øame number of narrow ones of white: the hind part of the head ≈øpotted with white: from the chin to the tail whiti≈øh, ≈øtreaked downwards with di≈øtinct lines of black: legs deep yellow.
Inferior in ≈øize to the la≈øt. Inhabits the province of New York. SIZE, AND PLACE. BL. MUS.

PLACE.Inhabits Sweden; perhaps Norway. Found about the ≈øouthern part of the Urallian mountains, and the mountains which border Sibiria on the ≈øouth. Grows ≈øcarcer towards the ea≈øt.

div.p: F. With pale yellow bill, irides, cere, and feet: plumage light cinereous: body and coverts of the wings clouded with darker: primaries du≈øky: tail white.

SIZE, AND PLACE.In ≈øize equal to the Black Eagle. Inhabits Europe, as high as Iceland and Lapmark Leems, 331. . Is common in Greenland; but does not extend to America: at le≈øt, if it does, it varies into the White-headed Eagle, to which it has great affinity, in particular in its feeding much on fi≈øh: the Danes therefore call it Fi≈øke-orn Brunnick, No 12. . Is common in the ≈øouth of Ru≈ø≈øia, and about the Volga, as far as trees will grow. Is very ≈øcarce in Sibiria; but has been ob≈øerved in the ea≈øtern parts about Nert≈øchink. It ≈øeems to be the ≈øpecies called by the Tungu≈øi, Elo;
which breeds on the banks of the Khariou≈øowa, a river which falls into the Pen≈øhina ≈øeaHi≈øt. Kamt≈øchatka, 501. .

It inhabits Greenland the whole year, ≈øitting on the rocks with flagging wing, and flies ≈ølowly. It makes its ne≈øt on the lofty cliffs, with twigs, lining the middle with mo≈ø≈øes and feathers. Lays two eggs. Sits in the latter end of May, or beginning of June.

The≈øe birds prey on young Seals, which they ≈øeize as they are floating on the water; but oft-times, by fixing their talons in an old one, they are overmatched, and drawn down to the bottom, ≈øcreaming horribly. They feed al≈øo on fi≈øh, e≈øpecially the Lumpfi≈øh, and a ≈øort of TroutSalmo. Carpio, Faun. Groenl. 170, No 124.; on Ptarmigans, Auks, and Eider Ducks. They ≈øit on the top of rocks, attentive to the motion of the diving birds; and, with quick eyes, ob≈øerve their cour≈øe by the bubbles which ri≈øe to the ≈øurface of the water, and catch the fowls as they ri≈øe for breath.

The Greenlanders u≈øe their ≈økins for cloathing, next to their bodies. They eat the fle≈øh, and keep the bill and feet for amulets. They kill them with the bow, or take them in nets, placed in the ≈ønow, properly baited; or tempt them by the fat of Seals, which the Eagles eat to an exce≈øs; which occa≈øions ≈øuch a torpidity as to make them an ea≈øy prey.

div.p: F. With a du≈øky bill and yellow cere: color of the plumage a ferruginous brown; the coverts of the wings, and ≈øcapulars, elegantly varied with oval white ≈øpots; on the greater coverts very large: primaries du≈øky; the ends of the greater white: brea≈øt and belly of a deeper color than the re≈øt of the plumage, ≈øtreaked downwards with dull yellow: tail dark brown, tipt with dirty white: legs feathered to the feet, which are yellow. LENGTH two feet.

PLACE.Is found in many parts of Europe, but not in Scandinavia: is frequent in Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, and extends even to Kamt≈øchatka. Is le≈øs generous and ≈øpirited than other Eagles; and is perpetually making a plaintive noi≈øe, from which it was ≈øtyled by the antients Planga & Clanga; and Anataria, from its preying on Ducks, which Pliny Lib. x. c. 3. de≈øcribes with great elegance. The Arabs u≈øed to train it for the chace; but its quarry was Cranes, and other birds: the more generous Eagle being flown at Antelopes, and various quadrupeds. This ≈øpecies was even it≈øelf an object of diver≈øion; and made the game of even ≈øo ≈ømall a Falcon as the Sparrow Hawk: which would pur≈øue it with great eagerne≈øs, ≈øoar above, then fall on the Eagle, and, fa≈øtening with its talons, keep beating it about the head with its wings, till they both fell together to the ground. This Sir John Chardin has ≈øeen practi≈øed about Tauris.

div.p: F. With a ≈øtrong bill, much hooked, and the upper mandible ≈øharply angulated on the lower edges; cere blui≈øh: head of a very pale ru≈øt-color, ≈øtreaked downwards with du≈øky lines: neck, brea≈øt, and belly, white, marked with cordated ≈øpots: thighs white, cro≈ø≈øed with ≈øhort bars of deep brown: back and coverts of wings du≈øky, ≈øpotted and edged with white: the exterior webs of the primaries du≈øky, mottled with reddi≈øh white; the inner barred with white: the feathers of the tail cro≈ø≈øed with fourteen or more narrow bars of du≈øky and white; the du≈øky bars regularly oppo≈øing tho≈øe of white: the wings, when clo≈øed, reach almo≈øt to the end of the train: legs ≈øtrong and yellow. The LENGTH of the wing, from the pinion to the tip, ≈øixteen inches.

This ≈øpecies is an inhabitant of Iceland, is the mo≈øt e≈øteemed of any for the ≈øport of falconry, and is, with the two following, re≈øerved for the kings of Denmark; who ≈øends his falconer, with two attendants, annually into the i≈øland to purcha≈øe them. They are caught by the natives; a certain number of whom in every di≈øtrict are licen≈øed for that purpo≈øe. They bring all they take, about Mid≈øummer, to Be≈øfe≈øted, to meet the royal falconer; and each brings ten or twelve, capped, and perched on a cro≈øs pole, which they carry on hor≈øeback, and re≈øt on the ≈øtirrup. The falconer examines the birds, rejects tho≈øe which are not for his purpo≈øe, and gives the ≈øeller a written certificate of the qualities of each, which entitles him to receive from the king's receiver-general ≈øeventeen rixdollars for F, or the pure≈øt white Falcon; ten for E, or tho≈øe which are le≈øt white; and ≈øeven for this ≈øpeciesBrunnick, p. 2. . This brings into the i≈øland between two and three thou≈øand rixdollars annuallyOlaffen, i. 32. .

They are taken in the following manner:MANNER OF TAKING.‚ÄîTwo po≈øts are fa≈øtened in the ground, not remote from their haunts. To one is tied a Ptarmigan, a Pigeon, a Cock or Hen, fa≈øtened to a cord that it may have means of fluttering, and ≈øo attract the attention of the Falcon. On the other po≈øt is placed a net, di≈øtended on a hoop, about ≈øix feet in diameter. Through this po≈øt is introduced a ≈øtring, above a hundred yards long, which is fa≈øtened to the net, in order to pull it down; and another is fa≈øtened to the upper part of the hoop, and goes through the po≈øt to which the bait is tied. As ≈øoon as the Falcon ≈øees the fowl flutter on the ground, he takes a few circles in the air, to ≈øee if there is any danger, then darts on its prey with ≈øuch violence as to ≈øtrike off the head, as nicely as if it was done with a razor. He then u≈øually ri≈øes again, and takes another circle, to explore the place a ≈øecond time: after which it makes another ≈øtoop; when, at the in≈øtant of its de≈øcending, the man pulls the dead bird under the net; and, by means of the other cord, covers the Falcon with the net, at the moment it has ≈øeized the prey; the per≈øon lying
concealed behind ≈øome ≈øtones, or el≈øe lies flat on his belly, to elude the ≈øight of the FalconHorrebow, 59, 60. .

As ≈øoon as one is caught, it is taken gently out of the net, for fear of breaking any of the feathers of the wings or tail; and a cap is placed over its eyes. If any of the tail-feathers are injured, the falconers have the art of grafting othersBrunnick, p. 3. Horrebow, 58. ; which ≈øometimes has occa≈øioned a needle≈øs multiplication of ≈øpecies.

The Iceland Falcons are in the highe≈øt e≈øteem. They will la≈øt ten or twelve years; whereas tho≈øe of Norway, and other countries, ≈øeldom are fit for ≈øport after two or three years u≈øe. Yet the Norwegian Hawks were in old times in great repute in this kingdom, and even thought bribes worthy of a king. Geoffry Le Pierre, chief ju≈øticiary, gave two good Norway Hawks to King John, that Walter Le Madina might have leave to export a hundred weight of chee≈øe. John, the ≈øon of Ordgar, gave a Norway Hawk to have the king's reque≈øt to the king of Norway, to let him have his brother's chattels; and Ralf Havoc fined to King Stephen in two Girfals (Gyrfalcons) and two Norway Hawks, that he might have the ≈øame acquittance that his father hadMadox, Antiq. Exch. 469. 497. .

ANTIQUITY OF FALCONRY.I cannot fix the preci≈øe time of the origin of falconry; the pa≈ø≈øage in Ari≈øtotle, and the epigram in Martial, do by no means fix it to the periods in which they wrote. The philo≈øopher Ari≈øt. de Mirabil. Au≈øcult. informs us, that there was a di≈øtrict in Thrace, in which the boys u≈øed to a≈ø≈øemble at a certain time of the year, for the ≈øake of bird-catching. That the ≈øpot was much frequented by Hawks, which were wont to appear on hearing them≈øelves called: and would drive the little birds into the bu≈øhes, where they were caught by the children; and that the Hawks would even ≈øometimes take the birds and fling them to the≈øe young ≈øport≈ømen; who (after fini≈øhing their diver≈øion) gratefully be≈øtowed on their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants part of their prey. This tale may have ≈øome truth at the bottom;
it being notorious that Larks, and even Partridges, will, by the terror of a Hawk pa≈ø≈øing over them, lie ≈øo ≈øtill as to ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be taken by any pa≈ø≈øenger. Here ≈øeems to have been no training of the≈øe Thracian Hawks, but a mere ca≈øual concurrence of Hawks and ≈ømall birds, which afforded now and then an amu≈øement to the youth of the country. The thought expre≈ø≈øed on the antient gem, of little Genii engaged in the chace of Deer, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by an Eagle, may have originated from this ≈øtory.

The Poet only de≈øcribes another kind of bird-catching, in the following epigram on the fate of a Hawk:
Praedo fuit volucrum, famulus nunc Aucupis, idem
Decipit, et captas non ≈øibi, moeret, avesLib. xiv. ep. 216..
By the word decipit, it is plain that the Hawk was not trained; but was merely u≈øed as a ≈øtale, either to entice ≈ømall birds under a net, or to the limed twigs: the la≈øt is a method ≈øtill in u≈øe in Italy. The Italians call it Uccellare con la Civetta; for in≈øtead of a Hawk, they place a ≈ømall ≈øpecies of Owl on a pole, in the middle of a field; and ≈øurround it, at various di≈øtances, with lime-twigs. The ≈ømall birds, from their ≈øtrange propen≈øity to approach rapacious fowls, fly around, perch on the rods, and are taken in great numbersOlina, 65. . A Hawk would ≈øerve the purpo≈øe full as well. Pliny mentions the u≈øe of bird-lime Hi≈øt. Nat. lib. xci. c. 44.; and Longus, in his elegant romance of Daphnis and Chloe, employs the latter to catch little birds for his beloved Fr. ed. octavo, 82..

I cannot find any certainty of Hawks being trained for diver≈øion before the time of King Ethelbert, the Saxon monarch; who died in the year 760Saxon Chr. 60. . He wrote into Germany for a brace of Falcons, which would fly at Cranes and bring them to the ground Quoted by Mr. Whitaker in Hi≈øt. Manche≈øter, from Max. Bibliotheca Patrum, xiii. p. 85. ep. 40. , as there were very few ≈øuch in Kent. This ≈øhews how erroneous the opinion was, of tho≈øe who place it in the reign of the emperor Frederic Barbaro≈ø≈øa,
baro≈ø≈øaSpelman's Glo≈ø≈ø., who was drowned in 1189. By the application of Ethelbert to Boniface, archbi≈øhop of Mentz, for the brace of Falcons, it is evident, that the diver≈øion was in perfection in Germany before the year 752, the time in which that prelate was martyred by the Pagans. It ≈øeems to me highly probable, that falconry was invented in Scythia, and pa≈ø≈øed from thence into the northern parts of Europe. Tartary is even at pre≈øent celebrated for its fine breed of Falcons; and the ≈øport is in ≈øuch general e≈øteem, that, according to Olearius, there was no hut but what had its Eagle or Falcon Olearius's travels, 177. . The boundle≈øs plains of that country are as finely adapted to the diver≈øion, as the wooded or mountanous nature of mo≈øt part of Europe is ill calculated for that rapid amu≈øement.

The antiquity of falconry in Tartary is evinced by the exhibition of the ≈øport on the very antient tombs Strahlenberg, tab. A. B. found in that country; in which are figured hor≈øemen at full ≈øpeed, with Hawks on their hands: others again, in the ≈øame attitude, di≈øcharging their arrows at their game, in the very manner of the antient Scythians.

From Germany, falconry got footing in England; and became ≈øo favored a diver≈øion, that even ≈øanguinary laws were enacted for the pre≈øervation of rapacious fowls. Edward III. made it death for the ≈øtealing of a Hawk: and to take its eggs, even in a per≈øon's own ground, was puni≈øhable with a fine at the king's plea≈øure, and impri≈øonment for a year and a day. In the reign of James I. the amu≈øement was carried to ≈øuch an extravagant pitch, that Sir Thomas Mon≈øon is ≈øaid to have given a thou≈øand pounds for a ca≈øt of Hawks.

div.p:
F. With du≈øky irides: lead-colored cere and feet: brown crown, marked with irregular oblong white ≈øpots: forehead whiti≈øh: cheeks blacki≈øh: hind part of the head and throat white: brea≈øt and
belly of a yellowi≈øh white, ≈øtriped downwards with du≈øky ≈øtreaks: the back du≈øky, tinged with blue, the ends of the feathers lighte≈øt, and ≈øprinkled over with a few white ≈øpots, e≈øpecially towards the rump: wings of the ≈øame colors, variegated beneath with white and black: the upper part of the tail du≈øky, cro≈ø≈øed very faintly with paler bars; the under ≈øide whiti≈øh.

Inhabits all parts of Greenland, PLACE. from the remote≈øt hills to tho≈øe which impend over the ≈øea. They are even ≈øeen on the i≈ølands of ice remote from ≈øhore. They retire in the breeding-≈øea≈øon to the farthe≈øt part of the country, and return in autumn with their young. They breed in the ≈øame manner as the Cinereous Eagle, but in more di≈øtant places; and lay from three to five eggs. The tail of the young is black, with great brown ≈øpots on the exterior webs.

They prey on Ptarmigans, Auks, and all the ≈ømall birds of the country: have frequent di≈øputes with the Raven, but ≈øeldom come off victors; for the Raven will, on being attacked, fling it≈øelf on its back; and, either by defending, it≈øelf with its claws, or by calling, with its croaking, numbers of others to its help, oblige the Falcon to retire. The Greenlanders u≈øe the ≈økin, among many others, for their inner garments; the wings for bru≈øhes; the feet for amulets: but ≈øeldom eat the fle≈øh, unle≈øs compelled by hunger.
It is al≈øo a native of Iceland.

div.p:
F. With a yellow cere: blui≈øh bill, greatly hooked: eye dark blue: the throat of a pure white: the whole body, wings, and tail, of the ≈øame color, mo≈øt elegantly marked with du≈øky bars, lines, or ≈øpots,
leaving the white the far prevaling color. There are in≈øtances, but rare, of its being found entirely white. In ≈øome, the whole tail is cro≈ø≈øed by remote bars of black or brown; in others, they appear only very faintly on the middle feathers: the feathers of the thighs are very long, and un≈øpotted: the legs ≈øtrong, and of a light blue.

SIZE.Its weight forty-five ounces Troy: length near two feet: extent four feet two.PLACE. Of the ≈øame manners and haunts with the former. Is very frequent in Iceland; is found in Lapmark Leems, 235. , and Norway Strom.; and rarely in the Orknies, and North Britain. In A≈øia, it dwells in the highe≈øt points of the Urallian and other Sibirian mountains, and dares the colde≈øt climates throughout the year. It is kept, in the latitude of Peter≈øburg, VERY HARDY. uninjured in the open air during the ≈øevere≈øt winters, when the Peregrine Falcon, No 97, lo≈øes its claws by the fro≈øt.

Mr. Hutchins At the time this ≈øheet was printing, I had the good fortune to meet with Mr. Hutchins, ≈øurgeon, a gentleman many years re≈øident in Hud≈øon's Bay; who, with the utmo≈øt liberality, communicated to me his MS. ob≈øervations, in a large folio volume: in every page of which his exten≈øive knowlege appears. The benefit which this work will, from the pre≈øent page, receive, is here once for all gratefully acknowleged. has often ob≈øerved it about Albany fort, where it appears in May, and retires before winter. It feeds on the white, and other Grous. This ≈øpecies ought to be added to the American cla≈øs.

This ≈øpecies is pre-eminent in courage as well as beauty, and is the terror of other Hawks. It was flown at all kinds of fowl, how great ≈øoever they were; but its chief game u≈øed to be Herons and Cranes.

F. With a lead-colored bill, tipt with black: head broad and flat, ≈øtreaked lengthways with black and white; on the cheeks the white predominates: the throat, under ≈øide of the neck, and

Is rarely found in the remote≈øt parts of Greenland. PLACE. Inhabits al≈øo Sweden; and extends ea≈øtward as far as Simbir≈øk, lat. 54¬Ω, in the government of Ca≈øan Extracts, i. 315. .

div.p: F. With yellow bill and cere: white head, ≈øtreaked with black: body ferruginous, with a few du≈øky ≈øpots: tail much forked and ferruginous.
Weight forty-four ounces. Length twenty-≈øeven inches:SIZE. extent five feet one.

Inhabits the north of Europe, as high as Jarl≈øberg, PLACE. in the very ≈øouth of Norway Hammer, Faun. Norway.; but does not extend farther. This ≈øpecies, the Sea Eagle, Lanner, Buzzard, and Ke≈øtril, quit Sweden, in flocks, at approach of winter, and return in ≈øpringAmoen. Acad. iv.. Of the≈øe, the Buzzard and Ke≈øtril winter at Worone≈øch, in Ru≈ø≈øia, in lat. 52Extracts, i. 100. ; and, together with the Lanner and Kite, about A≈øtrakan Vol. ii. 142., in lat. 46. 30; but the far greater part of the Kites are ≈øuppo≈øed to retire into Egypt, being ≈øeen in September pa≈ø≈øing by Con≈øtantinople For≈økahl, De≈øcr. Arab. 7. , in their way from the north; and again in April returning to Europe Wil. Orn. 75. , to ≈øhun the great
heats of the ea≈øt. They are ob≈øerved in va≈øt numbers about Cairo, where they are extremely tame, and feed even on dates, I ≈øuppo≈øe for want of other food Belon Ob≈ø. xxxvi. p. 107. b.. They al≈øo breed there; ≈øo that, contrary to the nature of other rapacious birds, they encrea≈øe and multiply twice in the year; once in the mild winters of Egypt, and a ≈øecond time in the ≈øummers of the north. It makes its appearance in Greece in the ≈øpring; and in the early ages, ≈øays Ari≈øtophanes Aves., it governed that country: and men fell on their knees when they were fir≈øt ble≈ø≈øed with the ≈øight of it, becau≈øe it pronounced the flight of winter, and told them to begin to ≈øheer their vernal fleeces. The CRANE likewi≈øe, by its autumnal departure, warns the mariner to hang up his rudder, and take his re≈øt, and every prudent man to provide their winter garments: and the SWALLOW again informed them when they were to put on tho≈øe of ≈øummer. Thus, adds the chorus of birds, are we to you as AMMON, DODONA, APOLLO: meaning, in tho≈øe early days, that man con≈øulted only the≈øe natural calendars, and needed no other than what they took from the flight of birdsSee this ≈øubject mo≈øt ingeniou≈øly handled in Mr. STILLINGFLEET'S E≈ø≈øays, in the Calendar of Flora. , or the flowering of plants.

They inhabit England in all ≈øea≈øons. I have ≈øeen their young taken, the la≈øt week in May, or fir≈øt in June, in the great woods belonging to Sir Jo≈øeph Banks, in Lincoln≈øhire; and have often ob≈øerved them in various places in the depth of winter.

With a du≈øky bill: yellow irides: horns ≈øhorter than the European Eagle Owl; tho≈øe, with the head, black, marked with tawny: circle round the eyes cinereous, edged with black: on the throat a large cruciform mark of a pure white, reaching to the beginning of the brea≈øt: upper part of the brea≈øt du≈øky and tawny; the lower part thickly barred with black a≈øh-color, mixed with yellow: coverts of wings, ≈øcapulars, and back, elegantly painted with zigzag lines, cinereous, black, and orange; the ≈øcapulars al≈øo marked with a few great white ≈øpots: primaries broadly barred with black and ferruginous: tail of a deep brown, cro≈ø≈øed with brown du≈øky bars, and marked with numerous tran≈øver≈øe cinereous lines: legs and feet covered with ≈øoft light brown feathers to the very claws, which are very ≈øtrong and hooked.
SIZE.This ≈øpecies is inferior in ≈øize to the EAGLE OWL, Br. Zool. i. No 64; but ≈øeems only a variety.

PLACE.It is common to South and North America, as high as Hud≈øon's Bay. Makes, during night, a mo≈øt hideous noi≈øe in the woods, not unlike the hollowing of a man; ≈øo that pa≈ø≈øengers, beguiled by it, often lo≈øe their way.

The ≈øavages have their birds of ill omen, as well as the Romans. They have a mo≈øt ≈øuper≈øtitious terror of the Owl; which they carry
≈øo far as to be highly di≈øplea≈øed at any one who mimics its hootingColden's Six Indian Nations, i. 17. .
This ≈øpecies is common in Kamt≈øchatka, and even extends to the Arctic regions; in the fir≈øt of which it very often inclines to white. It is found as low as A≈øtrakan.

With very long ears, of ≈øix feathers each, yellow and black: irides yellow: back and coverts of wings deep brown, grey, and yellowi≈øh ru≈øt-color: primaries barred with du≈øky and ferruginous: brea≈øt and belly pale yellow, with ≈ølender brown ≈øtrokes, pointing downwards: tail barred with cinereous and du≈øky; the bars of the middle feathers bound above and below with white: feet feathered to the claws. Approaches the tents of the inhabitants, and is very clamorous. Builds its ne≈øt in trees, and lays four white eggs in April. Never migrates.

Inhabits Sweden, and the northern and ≈øouthern parts of the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions, and the ea≈øtern parts of Sibiria. Is found as far ≈øouth as A≈øtrakan, and even in the hot climate of Egypt Ha≈ø≈øelqui≈øt, Itin. 233. .

div.p:
O. With a le≈ø≈øer head in proportion than the former: bill du≈øky: irides yellow: head, back, and coverts of the wings, pale
brown, edged with dull yellow: brea≈øt and belly yellowi≈øh white, marked with a few du≈øky ≈øtreaks pointing downwards: thighs, legs, and toes, covered with plain yellow feathers: primaries du≈øky, barred with red: tail of a deep brown, marked on each ≈øide of the middle feathers with a large yellow circle, with a brown ≈øpot in the middle. In ≈øome, the feathers are yellowi≈øh, obliquely barred with black. The horns, or ears, con≈øi≈øt of only a ≈øingle feather, which it can rai≈øe or depre≈øs at plea≈øure. The wings reach beyond the end of the tail.SIZE. LENGTH fourteen inches. Weight fourteen ounces.

PLACE.Found in plenty in the woods near Chateau Bay, on the Labrador coa≈øt. It is al≈øo an inhabitant of the Falkland I≈ølands; ≈øo probably is common to North and South America. In Hud≈øon's Bay it is called the Mou≈øe Hawk. It never flies, like other Owls, in ≈øearch of prey; but ≈øits quiet on a ≈øtump of a tree, watching, like a Cat, the appearance of Mice. It breeds near the coa≈øt; makes its ne≈øt with dry gra≈øs upon the ground; and migrates ≈øouthwards in autumn. Father Feuill√©e ≈øpeaks of an Owl he found in Peru that has ≈øome re≈øemblance to this, particularly in the Hawk-like ≈øhape of the bill. He ≈øays it burrows under ground to a great depth, like a Rabbet; for which rea≈øon he names it Ulula Cunicularia Voy. Peru, ii. 562. . It is very common in the northern and woody parts of Sibiria. Comes boldly to the night fires, and a≈ø≈øaults men, when it is often killed with ≈øticks.

In Europe it is found in Great Britain, and reaches to the Orkney i≈øles. Does not perch, but ≈øits on the ground, on which it lays its eggs amid≈øt the heath. Appears and di≈øappears in Lincoln≈øhire with the Woodcock. Perhaps migrates to Sweden or Norway, where it is al≈øo found, and even as high as Iceland See Strix Funerea, Faun. Suec. No 75. Pontop. Atlas Danica, tab. 25. Olaffen's Iceland, ii. tab. 46. . Flies and preys by day, in dark and cloudy weather. Friendly to the farmer, by being an excellent mou≈øer. Does not fly far; but if di≈øturbed, ≈øoon alights, and ≈øits looking about; at which times its horns are very con≈øpicuous. This circum≈øtance hitherto unattended to; ≈øo that it has been ranked among the Earle≈øs Owls.

div.head: 119. WAPACUTHU.
div.p:
O. With glo≈ø≈øy black bill, and claws much incurvated: ba≈øe of the bill be≈øet with ≈øtrong bri≈øtles: irides bright yellow: ≈øpace between the eyes, cheeks, and throat, white: the ends of the feathers on the head black: ≈øcapulars, and all the coverts of the wings, white, elegantly barred with du≈øky reddi≈øh marks, pointing downwards:
primaries, ≈øecondaries, and tail feathers, irregularly ≈øpotted and barred with pale red and black: back and coverts of the tail white, mixed with a few du≈øky ≈øpots: brea≈øt and belly dirty white, cro≈ø≈øed with innumerable reddi≈øh lines: vent white: legs feathered to the toes, which are covered with hairs. WEIGHT five pounds: length two feet: extent four.

PLACE.Inhabits the woods about Hud≈øon's Bay: makes its ne≈øt on the mo≈øs, on the dry ground. The young are hatched in May, and fly in June; and are white for a long time after. Feeds on Mice and ≈ømall birds. Called by the Indians, Wapacuthu, or the Spotted Owl. The Europeans ≈øettled in the bay, reckon it a very delicate food.

div.head: 120. SOOTY.

list.item: Cinereous Owl, Latham, i. 134, No 19.‚ÄîBR. MUS.

div.p: O. With a whiti≈øh bill: bright yellow irides: circlets con≈øi≈øt of elegant alternate lines of black and pale a≈øh-color: head, hind part of the neck, and coverts of wings, ≈øooty, marked with narrow bars of dirty white: primaries deep brown, with broad bars, compo≈øed of le≈ø≈øer of du≈øky and pale cinereous: tail mo≈øt irregularly marked with oblique ≈øtrokes of brown and dirty white: the brea≈øt and belly whiti≈øh, greatly covered with large oblong blotches of du≈øky brown: as a ≈øingular mark, from the chin to the vent is a ≈øpace, about an inch in breadth, entirely naked: legs feathered to the feet. WEIGHS three pounds: length two feet: extent four.

PLACE.Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay the whole year. Flies in pairs. Feeds on Mice and Hares. Flies very low; yet ≈øeizes its prey with ≈øuch force, that, in winter, it will ≈øink into the ≈ønow a foot deep; and, with great ea≈øe, will fly away with the AMERICAN HARE, No 38, alive in its talons. It makes its ne≈øt in a pine-tree, in the middle of May, with a few ≈øticks lined with feathers; and lays two eggs, ≈øpotted with a darki≈øh color. The young take wing in the end of July.

div.head: 121. SNOWY.

With a head le≈øs in proportion than other Owls: irides yellow: whole plumage of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs, ≈øometimes pure, oftener marked with du≈øky ≈øpots: the legs and feet covered warmly to the very claws with long ≈ønowy feathers of the mo≈øt delicate and elegant texture: the claws are of a fine contra≈øting blackne≈øs, very large and very crooked. Its length two feet;SIZE. but it varies greatly in weight, from three pounds to one and a half.

It inhabits the colde≈øt parts of America, PLACE. even as high as the remote mountains in the icy centre of Greenland; from which, in inten≈øe cold, it migrates to the ≈øhores. It adds horror even to that country, by its hideous cries, re≈øembling tho≈øe of a man in deep di≈øtre≈øs.

It is rare in the temperate parts of America, and ≈øeldom ≈øtrays as low as Pen≈øylvania or Loui≈øiana. Is very common in Hud≈øon's Bay, in Norway, and Lapland. It fears not the rigor of the ≈øea≈øon, but bears the cold of the northern regions the whole year. It flies by day, and is ≈øcarcely to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the ≈ønow: it flies pretty ≈øwiftly, and falls perpendicularly on its prey. Feeds on the White Grous, and probably on the Hares; for to the la≈øt circum≈øtance it owes its Swedi≈øh name, Harfang. It preys al≈øo on Mice, and Carrion; and in Hud≈øon's Bay is almo≈øt dome≈øtic, harbouring in places near the tents of the Indians.

Is ≈øcarce in Ru≈ø≈øia; grows more common on the Uralian mountains, and all over the north and ea≈øt of Sibiria, and in its A≈øiatic empire, even in the hot latitude of A≈øtrakan
Extracts, i. 91. ii. 142.; are very numerous in Kamt≈øchatka.

PLACE.This ≈øpecies is common to North America, Denmark, and Sweden. The Savages who come down to Hud≈øon's Bay, call it Cabetitutch. It
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
flies high, like a Hawk, and preys by day on the White Grous. Like the Short-eared Owl, will hover over the nocturnal fires. Is a bold bird; will attend the fowler, and often ≈øteal the game he has ≈øhot, before he can pick it up. Was ≈øeen by the navigators near Sandwich ≈øound, in lat. 61 north.
This bird is very frequent in all Sibiria, and on the we≈øt ≈øide of the Uralian chain, as far as Ca≈øan and the Volga: not in Ru≈ø≈øia.

With a white bill: du≈øky irides: head, back, and coverts of wings, of a pale beautiful yellow, with two grey and two white ≈øpots placed alternately on each ≈øide of the ≈øhafts: brea≈øt and belly wholly white: interior ≈øides of the feathers of the tail white; exterior marked with ob≈øcure du≈øky bars: legs feathered: feet covered with ≈øhort hairs. This bird is common to North and South America, and to Europe. PLACE. Was found by the navigators near Sandwich ≈øound, lat. 61 north. Is rare in Sweden, and, I believe, not found farther north. Inhabits Tartary. The Mongol and Kalmuc Tartars almo≈øt pay it divine honors; becau≈øe they attribute to this ≈øpecies the pre≈øervation of the founder of their empire, Cingis Khan. That prince with his ≈ømall army happened to be ≈øurprized and put to flight by his enemies, and forced to conceal him≈øelf in a little coppice: an Owl ≈øettled on the bu≈øh under which he was hid, and induced his pur≈øuers not to ≈øearch there, as they thought it impo≈ø≈øible any man could be concealed in a place where that bird would perch. From thenceforth they held it to be ≈øacred, and every one wore a plume of the feathers of
this ≈øpecies on his head. To this day the Kalmucs continue the cu≈øtom, on all great fe≈øtivals; and ≈øome tribes have an idol in form of an Owl, to which they fa≈øten the real legs of oneExtracts, ii. 142. .

div.p: S. With a black bill and legs: cinereous crown, hind part of the neck, and back: cheeks white, cro≈ø≈øed from the bill with a bar of black: under ≈øide, from chin to tail, white, marked with ≈øemicircular lines of a pale brown: le≈ø≈øer coverts black; tho≈øe on the joints of the wings a≈øh-color: primaries black, marked with a ≈øingle band of black; ≈øecondaries tipt with white: the tail cuneiform; the two middle feathers black, the tips of the next on each ≈øide white; on the re≈øt the white prevales, till the exterior, when the black almo≈øt entirely vani≈øhes: beyond each eye of the female is a brown bar.

PLACE.Inhabits North America, from Hud≈øon's Bay to Loui≈øiana. In Hud≈øon's Bay, lives in the woods remote from ≈øhores, and is the fir≈øt bird there which brings out its young in the ≈øpring. Makes its ne≈øt with dry gra≈øs or bents, and lines it thickly with feathers: lays ≈øeven eggs, of a pale blue color, blotched with brown.

Is frequent in Ru≈ø≈øia, but does not extend to Sibiria; yet one was taken by our navigators within Bering's ≈øtraits, in lat. 66, on the A≈øiatic ≈øide of the Frozen Sea. Has the ≈øame manner of transfixing and tearing its prey as the Engli≈øh kind.

div.head: 128. BLACK-CROWNED.
div.p:
S. With the bill, legs, crown, and ≈øides of the head, back, and coverts of wings, black: primaries black, marked with a ≈ømall ≈øpot of white, and another on the ridge of the wing: throat, cheeks, and vent, pure white: brea≈øt and belly tinged with a≈øh-color: tail
long; middle feathers black; the re≈øt marked at their ends with white, which increa≈øes to the exterior; in which the black almo≈øt vani≈øhes. Rather inferior in ≈øize to the la≈øt.
Inhabits North America. PLACE. Seems to be La Pie Grie≈øche de la Loui≈øiane, Bri≈ø≈øon, ii. 162; Latham, i. 162.

div.head: 129. CRESTED.

div.p: S. With black bill and legs: head adorned with a reddi≈øh cre≈øt: cheeks du≈øky, ≈øpotted with white: hind part of neck and back brown, inclining to red: throat and brea≈øt of a yellowi≈øh red: belly and vent of a fine a≈øh-color: coverts of the wings black, edged with white; primaries with white on their exterior ≈øides: tail black, bordered on each ≈øide, and tipt with white. LENGTH ≈øix inches and a half: EXTENT about eleven.
Inhabits Canada. PLACE.

div.head: 130. NATKA.
div.p: S. With the bill ≈ølightly incurvated at the end, black, except the upper half of the lower mandible: crown, lower part of the upper ≈øide of the neck, and the back, black: over each eye is a white line, extending to the very nape; beneath that one of black: from chin to vent is wholly white: a narrow white circle quite encompa≈ø≈øes the neck: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings black; greater white, more or le≈øs da≈øhed down the ≈øhafts with black: primaries du≈øky, fringed with yellowi≈øh brown; ≈øecondaries black, edged and tipped with white: tail black, a little rounded; the four outmo≈øt feathers tipped with white: rump cinereous, the edges of the feathers grey: legs black. LENGTH ≈øeven inches one-fourth.
Brought from Natka ≈øound in North America. PLACE. Communicated to me by Mr. Latham.

div.head: 131. RED-BACKED.

list.item: Br. Zool. i. No 72.‚ÄîLatham, i. 167.

div.p: S. With grey crown and rump: ferruginous back and coverts of wings: black line acro≈øs the eyes: brea≈øt and belly ro≈øeate: tail black; exterior feathers edged with white: head and upper part of the FEMALE dirty ru≈øt-color; line over the eyes the ≈øame color: brea≈øt and belly dirty white, marked with du≈øky ≈øemicircular lines. LENGTH ≈øeven inches and a half.

PLACE.Inhabits Ru≈ø≈øia; not Sibiria. Is found in Sweden and Chri≈øtian≈øoe. The Count De Buffon ≈øays, he received one from Loui≈øiana. I imagine, that, as the Norwegians give the Great Shrike and this a name, that they may be found in their country. The fir≈øt they call Klavert, the la≈øt Hanvark. Mr. Ekmark has ob≈øerved both of them, only during ≈øummer, in E≈øt Gothland; but is not certain whether they winter. Each ≈øpecies appears in Italy in the ≈øpring; retires in autumn.

list.item: A. GREY, Lanius Nengeta, Lin. Sy≈øt. 135.‚ÄîLatham, i. 183.
Grey Pye of Bra≈øil, Edw. 318.

div.p:
S. With the crown, hind part of the neck, back, and coverts of the wings, deep cinereous: a black line pa≈ø≈øes from the bill through the eyes to the hind part of the head: greater coverts and ≈øecondaries
black, tipt with dirty white; primaries black: brea≈øt and belly light a≈øh-color: tail black; ends of the outmo≈øt feathers white. Much larger than No 127, the common Great Shrike; and differs ≈øpecifically.

Inhabits Ru≈ø≈øia, but is more frequent in Sibiria; PLACE. where it lives in the fore≈øts the whole winter. Taken and tamed by the fowlers; and kept by the Ru≈ø≈øians for the diver≈øion it affords in the manner of killing its prey. They ≈øtick a rod with a ≈øharp point into the wall of a room, on which the Shrike perches. They turn loo≈øe a ≈ømall bird, which the former in≈øtantly ≈øeizes by the throat, ≈øtrangles, and then ≈øpits it on the point of the ≈øtick, drawing it on with its claws and bill. Thus it ≈øerves as many as are turned to it, and afterwards eats them, thus ≈øu≈øpended, at its lei≈øureEDWARDS, Gl. p. 233.. The Germans ≈øtyle it Wurch-angel, or the Suffocating-angel. The old Engli≈øh, Wariangel, which ≈øignifies a bird of ≈øome very mi≈øchievous qualities; as is evident from Chaucer.

q.l: This Sompnour, which that was as ful of jangles,
As ful of venime ben thi≈øe Wariangles The Freres tale. Ful of venime, becau≈øe it was believed, that the thorn on which it ≈øtuck its prey was venomous..

list.item: B. LESSER GREY, Pie Grieche d'Italie, De Buffon, i. 298.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 32.

div.p: S. With the forehead black: a black line cro≈ø≈øes the eyes, like as in the former: head, hind part and ≈øides of the neck, back, and coverts of wings, cinereous, pale≈øt on the rump: ridge of the wing white: primaries black, with a white ≈øpot near the ba≈øe; ≈øecondaries black, tipt with white: throat white: brea≈øt and belly tinged with ro≈øe-color: tail marked like the preceding.
Inhabits Ru≈ø≈øia, but not Sibiria. Found in Italy and Spain. PLACE.

div.head: 132. CAROLINA.

list.item: Parrokeeto, Law≈øon, 142.‚ÄîLatham, i. 227.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.
Parrot of Carolina, Cate≈øby, i. 11.‚ÄîDu Pratz, ii. 88.

div.p: P. With the forehead, ridge of the wings, and feathers round the knees, orange: head and neck yellow: back, body, and coverts of wings and tail, green: primaries du≈øky, mixed with blue and green; the upper exterior ≈øides edged with yellow: tail very long and cuneiform: legs white. LENGTH thirteen inches. WEIGHT three ounces and a half.

PLACE.Inhabits the ≈øouthern parts of North America, but never appears higher than Virginia. It is in general a migratory bird, even in Carolina; arriving at the ≈øea≈øon when mulberries are ripe, which they are very fond of, and which are the earlie≈øt fruits of the country, except ≈øtrawberries. They infe≈øt, in autumn, the apple-orchards in va≈øt flocks, and make great havock by ≈øplitting the fruit for the ≈øake of the kernels only, being very greedy of them, and the ≈øeeds of cypre≈øs, and other trees. They devour too the buds of the birch.

Few of the≈øe tender birds continue in Carolina during the whole year. They breed in hollow trees, in low ≈øwampy grounds. When taken, they ea≈øily grow tame, but do not ≈øpeak. Their inte≈øtines are ≈øaid to be a ≈øpeedy poi≈øon to Cats.

EGGS.The eggs of Parrots are roundi≈øh, and generally of a pure white; tho≈øe of the Maccaws ≈øpotted, like the eggs of a Partridge. The number u≈øually two; yet the Count De Buffon gives an in≈øtance of a
Perroquet, in a ≈øtate of confinement, which laid four eggs every ≈øpring, during five or ≈øix years: one of the eggs was addle; the others productive Oi≈ø. vi. 115..

div.head: 133. ILLINOIS.

list.item: Tui-apeta-jube, Margrave, 206, No 2.‚ÄîWil Orn. 116.‚ÄîRaii. Syn. av. 34.‚Äî De Buffon, vi. 269.‚ÄîLatham, i. 228.

div.p: P. With a cinereous bill: orange-colored irides: forehead, cheeks, and ≈øometimes the hind part of the head, of a rich orange: crown, upper part of the body, tail, and coverts of the wings, of a fine green: primaries green, edged externally with blue: brea≈øt and belly of a yellowi≈øh green: vent yellow: tail very long and cuneiform. Of the ≈øame ≈øize with the former. Perhaps differs only in ≈øex?

Inhabits the interior parts of North America, PLACE. in the country of the Illinois, ≈øouth of lake Michigam: it is al≈øo met with in the Brazils. Is a lively bird; but its voice not very articulate. Father Charlevoix met with ≈øome on the banks of the Theatiki, a river that ri≈øes a little ≈øouth of lake Michigam, and runs into the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øipi. He ≈øays, that tho≈øe he ≈øaw were only ≈øtragglers, which migrated before winter; but that the main body pa≈ø≈øed the whole year on the borders of the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øipi Journal Hi≈øtorique, vi. 124. .

The Count De Buffon confines the whole genus of Parrots to exactly twenty-five degrees on each ≈øide of the Equator Oi≈ø. vi. 82..LATITUDES OF PARROTS. It always gives me pain to differ in opinion with ≈øo illu≈øtrious a character; but I mu≈øt produce my authorities of their being common at far greater di≈øtances. On the continent of America, two ≈øpecies have been ob≈øerved by the Spaniards about Trinity Harbour, in the South Seas, in
north lat. 41. 7Barrington's Mi≈øcellanies, 489. 491. . Dr. For≈øter ≈øaw, in the raw, rainy latitude of Du≈øky Bay, in New Zealand, 46 ≈øouth, two kinds. In the neighborhood of Botany Bay, in New Holland, in ≈øouth lat. 34, five ≈øpecies were di≈øcovered; among which, the greater variety of the ≈øulphur-cre≈øted Cockatoo appeared in amazing multitudes. But what is mo≈øt wonderful, a ≈ømall ≈øpecies of this tender genus is to be met with as low as Port Famine, in the ≈øtreights of Magellan, in north lat. 53. 44See Spilbergen's voy. in Purchas, i. 80; Wood's in Dampier's voy. iv. 112; and Byron's, in Hawk≈øworth's Coll. i. 38. Be≈øides the≈øe authorities, Lieut. Gore (≈øince Captain) and Mr. Edwards, now ≈øurgeon at Caernarvon, who ≈øailed with Mr. Byron, confirmed to me the exi≈øtence of the≈øe birds in the ≈øtreights of Magellan. , in flocks innumerable. They inhabited the va≈øt fore≈øts of the country. Their food mu≈øt be confined to buds and berries; for no fort of fruit-trees have been ob≈øerved there. The fore≈øts likewi≈øe were frequently bounded by mountains, probably cloathed with eternal ≈ønow.

div.head: 134. RAVEN.

list.item: Br. Zool. i No 74.
Corvus Corax, Lin. Sy≈øt. 155.
Korp, Faun. Suec. No 85.‚ÄîLeems, 240.‚ÄîFaun. Groenl. p. 62.‚ÄîLatham, i. 367. ‚ÄîDe Buffon, iii. 13.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: C. With the point of the bill a little incurvated, with a ≈ømall tooth on each ≈øide, of a black color, glo≈ø≈øed with blue. It varies to white, and to pied. In the Feroe i≈øles is a breed which are black and white, and are ≈øaid to keep in a place ≈øeparate from the common kindBrunnick, p. 8. .
The large≈øt of the genus. Weighs three pounds.SIZE. Length two feet two inches.

Very numerous as far north as Finmark, Iceland, and Greenland, where it frequents the huts of the natives, and feeds on the offals of the SealsEgede, 64. . Preys in concert with the White Bear, Arctic Fox, and Eagle. Devours the eggs of birds, e≈øpecially the Ptarmigan: eats ≈øhore-fi≈øh, and ≈øhell-fi≈øh: drops the la≈øt from on high to break them, and get at the contents. Turns roundin the air, and is dexterous; changes its prey from its bill to its feet, or from its feet to its bill, by way of ea≈øe. Eats al≈øo berries, and, when almo≈øt fami≈øhed, dried ≈økins and excrements. Ne≈øtles on high rocks, which overhang and afford a canopy. Couples in March; lays in April. Each pre≈øerves a di≈øtrict to it≈øelf. The male ≈øits in the day; the female in the night: the former-≈øleeps clo≈øe by its mate. Have ≈øtrong affection to their young brood. Hearing its croaking echoed, repeats it; as if admiring its own note. At approach of ≈øtorms, collects under ≈øhelter of rocks.

Caught by the natives. Its fle≈øh is eaten. The ≈økins reckoned the be≈øt for cloathing: the wings u≈øed for bru≈øhes: the quils ≈øplit, are made into fi≈øhing-lines. They al≈øo inhabit Newfoundland, and now and then appear as low as Virginia and Carolina Law≈øon, 139. .

This bird is, among the American ≈øavages, an emblem of return of health. Their phy≈øicians, or rather magicians, when they vi≈øit a ≈øick per≈øon, invoke the Raven, and mimic his croaking voiceAdair's Hi≈øt. Am. 173. . The northern Indians, on the contrary, dete≈øt this and all the Crow kind Mr. Hutchins.. It inhabits Kamt≈øchatka and Sibiria; but not within the A≈øiatic Arctic regions.

div.head: 135. CARRION.

list.item: Br. Zool. i. No 75?‚ÄîLatham, i. 370.
Blaae Raage, Brunnick, No 29.
Corvus Corone, Faun. Suec. No 86.

div.p: C. With the plumage wholly black, glo≈ø≈øed with violet: bill ≈øtrong, thick, and arched: no≈øtrils covered with ≈øtrong black bri≈øtles: ends of the feathers of the tail ≈ølightly pointed. LENGTH eighteen inches and a half. Weight from twenty to twenty-two ouncesVoyage, i. 121. .

PLACE.Inhabits the province of New York, and the inland parts of Hud≈øon's Bay. Mr. Blackburn ob≈øerved, that it retains there the ≈øame manners as the European ≈øpecies; and never migrates from New York. MR. KALM ≈øays, that they fly in great numbers, and have a cry much re≈øembling the RookSee article Rook, p. 250, A. where a compari≈øon is made of the differences between the≈øe two birds.. By his account, they appear of a mixed nature, feeding not only on grain, but on carrion; and are al≈øo very pernicious to young poultry. Like Rooks, they pull up the
corn of the country, the new-≈øown maize; and, when it ripens, do pick a hole in the leaves which ≈øurround the ears, expo≈øing it to corruption, by letting in the rain. The inhabitants of Pen≈øylvania and New Jer≈øey were wont to pro≈øcribe them, ≈øetting three pence or four pence on the head of each Crow; but the law was ≈øoon repealed, becau≈øe of the great expence it brought on the public ≈øtockVoyage, ii. 65. . Mr. Kalm al≈øo remarks this agreement with the Rook ≈øpecies, that they ≈øettle much on trees, both in February and the ≈øpring.

The≈øe birds are ≈øo rare in Sweden, that Linnaeus gives only one in≈øtance of its being killed in his country. Yet it is found in the dioce≈øe of Drontheim, and in the Feroe i≈ølands. They are ≈øcarce in Ru≈ø≈øia; and only in the north. Grow more common in Sibiria, and are found plentifully beyond the Lena, where the Hooded Crow cea≈øes. Was ob≈øerved about Botany Bay, in New Holland; and is met with in the Philippine i≈ølesDe Buffon, iii. 66. .

list.item: Br. Zool. i. No 78.‚ÄîLatham, i. 392.‚ÄîDe Buffon, iii. 85.

div.p: C. Variegated with black and white, the black mo≈øt beautifully glo≈ø≈øed with green and purple: the tail very long, cuneiform, black, re≈øplendent with the ≈øame rich colors as the body. Length eighteen inches: weight nine ounces.
Vi≈øits Hud≈øon's Bay, where the natives call it Oue ta-kee A≈øke, or the Heart-bird. It migrates, and but ≈øeldom appears therePhil. Tran≈ø. lxii. 387. .

Is found in Europe, as high as Wardhuys, in lat. 71 ¬Ω.PLACE. It is e≈øteemed there an augural bird. If it perches on the church, it is ≈øuppo≈øed to portend the death or removal of the mini≈øter: if on the ca≈øtle, that of the governorLeems, 241. . The Magpies ≈øwarm in the temperate parts of Ru≈ø≈øia. Common in Sibiria, and even as far as Kamt≈øchatka, and the i≈øles.

div.head: 137. CINEREOUS.

list.item: Corvus Canaden≈øis, Lin. Sy≈øt. 158.‚ÄîLatham, i. 389.
Le Geay Brun de Canada, Bri≈ø≈øon, ii. 54.‚ÄîDe Buffon, iii. 117.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: C. With a black bill, ≈øtrong, ≈øtrait, notched near the end of the upper mandible: no≈øtrils covered with a tuft of whiti≈øh feathers reflected downwards: the forehead, cheeks, and under part of the body, of a dirty reddi≈øh white: the feathers on the crown long and black, forming a ≈øpecies of cre≈øt, like that of the Engli≈øh Jay: the plumage on the back brown, ≈øilky, loo≈øe, and unwebbed, like that of the Jay: wings black: tail long, cuneiform, blade; the three outmo≈øt feathers tipt with dirty white: legs black. LENGTH near eleven inches: extent fifteen. Weight two ounces and a half.

PLACE.Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay, Newfoundland, and Canada, and the woods on the we≈øtern coa≈øts of America. The≈øe birds breed early in ≈øpring: their ne≈øts are made of ≈øticks and gra≈øs, and built in pine-trees. They have two, rarely three, young ones at a time. Their eggs are blue. The young are quite black, and continue ≈øo for ≈øome time. They fly in pairs. The male and female are perfectly alike. They feed on black mo≈øs, worms, and even fle≈øh. When near habitations or tents, they are apt to pilfer every thing they can come at, even ≈øalt meat. They are bold, and come into the tents to eat victuals out of the di≈øhes, notwith≈øtanding they have their hoard of berries lodged in the hollows of trees. They watch per≈øons baiting the traps for Martins, and devour the bait as ≈øoon as they turn their backs. The≈øe birds lay up ≈øtores for the winter; and are ≈øeldom ≈øeen in January, unle≈øs near habitations: they are a kind of mock-bird. When caught, they pine away, and die, though their appetite fails themMr. Hutchins.. Dete≈øted by the natives of Hud≈øon's Bay.

div.head: 138. BLUE.

list.item: Jay, Clayton's Virginia.‚ÄîPhil. Tran≈ø. iii. 590.‚ÄîLaw≈øon, 141.

Corvus Cri≈øtatus, Lin. Sy≈øt, 157.

div.p: C. With a ≈øtrong thick bill: head adorned with a rich blue cre≈øt: a ≈øtripe of black from the bill extending beyond the eyes: throat and cheeks white: neck ≈øurrounded with a black collar: brea≈øt of a pale vinaceous red: belly white; back of a pale purple: coverts of the wings and ≈øecondaries of a rich blue, beautifully barred with black; the ≈øecondaries, and one order of the coverts, tipt with white: tail long and cuneiform, barred with blue and black; the tips of all white, excepting tho≈øe of the two middlemo≈øt: legs black. LENGTH twelve inches.

Inhabits Newfoundland, Canada, and as far ≈øouth as Carolina. PLACE. Has the ≈øame actions and jetting motion as the Engli≈øh Jay, but its cry is le≈øs har≈øh. It feeds on fruits and berries, and commonly ≈øpoils more than it eats. It is particularly fond of the berries of the bay-leaved Smilax. Re≈øides in the country all the year. Lays in May five or ≈øix eggs, of a dull olive, with ru≈øty ≈øpots.

C. With a cre≈øted head: bill, neck, and back, black:139. STELLER'SLatham, i. 387. . le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings du≈øky; the others of a rich re≈øplendent blue: exterior webs of the primaries of the ≈øame color; the inner du≈øky; the ≈øecondaries of a beautiful rich blue, cro≈ø≈øed with narrow black bars, remote from each other: the rump, belly, and brea≈øt, of a dull blue: tail very long, cuneiform, and of a fine glo≈ø≈øy blue; the middle feathers ≈ølightly barred. SIZE of an Engli≈øh Jay.

Inhabits the woods about Natka or George ≈øound, in North America. PLACE. It had been before di≈øcovered by Steller, when he landed on the ≈øame ≈øide of that continent. De≈øcribed from a ≈øpecimen in the collection of Sir JOSEPH BANKS.

list.item: A. ROOK, Br. Zool. i. No 76.‚ÄîLatham, i. 372.
Corvus Frugilegus, Roka, Faun. Suec. No 87.‚ÄîDe Buffon, iii. 55.

div.p: C. Black, glo≈ø≈øed with purple: a tinge of dull green over part of the tail: the ends of the feathers of the tail broad, and rounded; tho≈øe of the Crow, acute: the bill ≈øtraiter, ≈ølenderer, and weaker, than that of the Carrion Crow: the length two inches and a half; that of the latter only two inches and a quarter. The bill of the CROW is of a more inten≈øe black. The no≈øtrils and ba≈øe of the bill of the ROOK naked, and whiti≈øh, occa≈øioned by being often thru≈øt under ground in ≈øearch of food. The WEIGHT of both nearly the ≈øame, about twenty-one ounces: the LENGTH about eighteen inches: the EXTENT of wings in the ROOK three feet one inch and a half; of the Crow, two inches and a half le≈øsI once had the curio≈øity to compare the mea≈øurements of the≈øe common birds, and found them as above; but they are often inferior in ≈øizes to the ≈øubjects I examined..

PLACE.This ≈øpecies is not found farther north than the ≈øouth of Sweden. It breeds there; but is driven away by the ≈øeverity of the winter. No mention is made of it in the Dani≈øh or Norwegian Faunae. Is common in Ru≈ø≈øia, and the we≈øt of Sibiria; but there are none in the ea≈øt. They migrate in the beginning of March to the environs of Worone≈øch, and mingle with the common CrowsExtracts, i. 103. .

list.item: B. HOODED CR. Br. Zool. i. No 77.‚ÄîLatham, i. 374.
Corvus Cornix, Kraka, Faun. Suec. No 88.
Krage, Leems, 239.‚ÄîDe Buffon, iii. 61.

div.p: C. With black head, wings, and tail; a≈øh-colored body.

Inhabits Europe, as high as the Feroe i≈ølands and Lapmark, PLACE. where it continues the whole year; but in the northern countries often retires to the ≈øhores, where it lives on ≈øhell-fi≈øh. Is very common in all Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria: none beyond the Lena. Migrates to Worone≈øch, and pa≈ø≈øes the winter there. Grows very large beyond the Ob, and often varies to entire blackne≈øs. This bird, and the Raven, in October quit the ≈øub-alpine woods, where they breed; and ≈øpread all over the plains of Italy. This ≈øpecies extends to Syria, as do the Raven, Crow, Jackdaw, and MagpieRu≈ø≈øel's Aleppo, 69. .

This ≈øpecies, the RAVEN, CROW, JACKDAW, PIE, and JAY, pa≈øs their winter at Worone≈øch Extracts, i. 100. , removing probably from hotter as well as colder climates; for three of the above can endure the ≈øevere≈øt cold.

C. With crown, and neck above, and coverts of wings, brown and dirty white. In the males, the middle of the back marked with a ≈øpot, con≈øi≈øting of a bar of blue, black, and ru≈øt-colored: throat, brea≈øt, and belly, orange, ≈øpotted with white, and a few du≈øky
≈øpots: two middle feathers of the tail du≈øky; the re≈øt ferruginous: has the ≈øame loo≈øe ≈øilky texture of feathers as the Jay. SIZE of a Stare.

Found as high as the fore≈øts of Lapland. Is called by the Swedes, PLACE. Lapp≈økata and Olyckfugl; by the Norwegians, Gertrudsfogel; al≈øo Ulyksfuegl, from its being ≈øuppo≈øed to forebode ill-luck. Linnaeus, for the ≈øame rea≈øon, ≈øtyles it Lanius Infau≈øtus; and in his Fauna, Corvus Infau≈øtus Sy≈øt. 138. Faun. Suec. No 93. . It is common in the woods of the north of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria. Is a mo≈øt audacious bird. Linnaeus relates, that in dining amid≈øt the Lepland fore≈øts, it would often ≈ønatch away the meat before him. Breeds in crevices of rocks. Feeds on worms and in≈øects. Sings finely, and is often pre≈øerved in cages for its ≈øong.

div.p: R. With a naked ≈øpot beyond each ear: head, neck, back, brea≈øt, belly, and greater coverts of the wings, of a light blui≈øh green: back ferruginous: coverts of the tail, le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings, and lower parts of the ≈øecondaries, of a rich blue; primaries black above, blue beneath: middle feathers of the tail dirty green; the re≈øt of a light blue: the exterior feathers on each ≈øide much longer than the re≈øt, and tipt with black: legs yellowi≈øh. SIZE of a Jay.

This elegant bird is found not ≈øpread, but as if it were in a ≈øtream,PLACES. from the ≈øouthern parts of Norway to Barbary and Senegal: from the ≈øouth of Ru≈ø≈øia to the neighborhood of the Irti≈øh, only, in that empire; and ≈øoutherly, to Syria Ru≈ø≈øel's Aleppo, 69. . In Sweden, it arrives with the Cuckoo;
retires at the conclu≈øion of the harve≈øtAmoen. Acad. iv. 583. . It makes its ne≈øt in the birch, preferably to all other trees De Buffon, iii. 139: from this circum≈øtance, one of its German names is Birck-heher, or the Birch Jay. ; and in places where trees are wanting, ≈øuch as Malta and Barbary, it forms its ne≈øt in clayey banks. Zinanni ≈øays it lays five eggs, of clear green, ≈øprinkled with innumerable dark ≈øpecksZinanni delle Nova, &c. p. 68. tab. x. fig. 29. . It feeds on fruits, acorns, and in≈øects. Is a ≈øhy bird; but, at times, is ≈øeen in company with Crows and Pies on the plough lands, picking up worms, and grains of corn. Schwenckfelt ≈øays, that in autumn it grows very fat, and is e≈øteemed as a delicacyAv. Silefiae, 244. . It is remarkably clamorous. Is migratory. M. Adan≈øon ob≈øerved them in Senegal, in flocks, in the month of September, and ≈øuppo≈øes they winter there Voy. Senegal, Engl. ed. 25. 107..

div.head: 140. RED-WING.
