div.p: O. With black bill and legs: plumage of a fine jetty blackne≈øs, except the le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings, which are of a bright ≈øcarlet, with the lowe≈øt row white. LENGTH ten inches. The FEMALES are of a du≈øky color.

Inhabit from the province of New York to the kingdom of Mexico. In North America they are called Red-winged Starlings,PLACE. and Swamp Black-birds; in Mexico, Commendadores, from their red ≈øhoulders, re≈øembling a badge worn by the commanders of a certain Spani≈øh order. That kingdom ≈øeems to be their mo≈øt ≈øouthern re≈øidence. They appear in New York in April, and leave the country in October. MANNERS. They probably continue the whole year in the ≈øouthern parts, at le≈øt Cate≈øby and Law≈øon make no mention of their departure. They are ≈øeen in flocks innumerable, ob≈øcuring at times the very ≈øky with their multitudes. They were e≈øteemed the pe≈øt of the colonies, making mo≈øt dreadful havock among the maize and other grain, both when new ≈øown, and when ripe. They are very bold, and not to be terrified with a gun; for, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øport≈øman makes ≈ølaughter in a flock, the remainder will take a ≈øhort flight, and ≈øettle again in the ≈øame field. The farmers ≈øometimes attempt their de≈øtruction, by ≈øteeping the maize in a decoction
of white hellebore before they plant it. The birds which eat this prepared corn are ≈øeized with a vertigo, and fall down; which ≈øometimes drives the re≈øt away. This potion is particularly aimed again≈øt the PURPLE GRAKLES, or PURPLE JACKDAW, which con≈øorts in myriads with this ≈øpecies, as if in con≈øpiracy again≈øt the labors of the hu≈øbandman. The fowler ≈øeldom ≈øhoots among the flocks, but ≈øome of each kind fall. They appear in greate≈øt numbers in autumn, when they receive additions from the retired parts of the country, in order to prey on the ripened maize.

Some of the colonies have e≈øtabli≈øhed a reward of three pence a dozen for the extirpation of the Jackdaws: and in New England, the intent was almo≈øt effected,USES. to the co≈øt of the inhabitants; who at length di≈øcovered that Providence had not formed even the≈øe ≈øeemingly de≈øtructive birds in vain. Notwith≈øtanding they cau≈øed ≈øuch havock among the grain, they made ample recompence, by clearing the ground of the noxious worms The Caterpillar of the Bruchus Pi≈øi, or Pea≈øe Beetle, in particular. See Kalm, i. 173. 176. with which it abounds. As ≈øoon as the birds were de≈øtroyed, the reptiles had full leave to multiply: the con≈øequence was the total lo≈øs of the gra≈øs, in 1749; when the New Englanders, late repentants, were obliged to get their hay from Pen≈øylvania, and even from Great Britain.

NEST.The Red-winged Orioles build their ne≈øts in bu≈øhes, and among the reeds, in retired ≈øwamps, in the form of a hang-ne≈øt; leaving it ≈øu≈øpended at ≈øo judicious a height, and by ≈øo wondrous an in≈øtinct, that the highe≈øt floods never reach to de≈øtroy it. The ne≈øt is ≈øtrong, made externally with broad gra≈øs, a little pla≈øtered; thickly lined with bent or withered gra≈øs. The eggs are white, thinly and irregularly ≈øtreaked with black.

Fernandez ≈øays, that in Mexico they build in trees near towns; and both he and Cate≈øby agree, that they ≈øing as well in a ≈øtate of confinement as of nature; and that they may be taught to ≈øpeak. I agree with M. de Buffon, that, in ca≈øe the manner of their nidification
is as Fernandez a≈ø≈øerts, the di≈øagreement in the different countries is very wonderful.

In Loui≈øiana they appear only in winter, and are taken in a clapnet, placed on each ≈øide of a beaten path made on purpo≈øe, and ≈øtrewed over with rice. As ≈øoon as the birds alight, the fowler draws the net, and ≈øometimes takes three hundred at a haul. They are al≈øo eaten in the Engli≈øh colonies. Fernandez does not commend their fle≈øh, which, he ≈øays, is unpalatable and unwhole≈øome.

Du Pratz ≈øpeaks of two kinds: this, and another which is grey and black, with a red ≈øhoulder; like the ≈øpecies in que≈øtion.YOUNG, OR FEMALES? I ≈øu≈øpect he forms out of the young birds, not yet arrived at full color, a new kind; or perhaps a female bird: for I have received from Dr. Garden one under that title, which agrees with the de≈øcription given by M. Du Pratz. The≈øe are ≈øtreaked with pale ru≈øty brown: cheeks black: over each eye a white line: brea≈øt and belly black, ≈øpotted with pale brown: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings rich orange.

div.p: G. With a black bill: ≈øilvery irides: head and neck black, glo≈ø≈øed over with a mo≈øt re≈øplendent blue, variable as oppo≈øed to the light: back and belly, with green and copper-color, growing more du≈øky towards the vent: tail long, and cuneiform: legs black: wings and tail rich purple. Female entirely du≈øky; darke≈øt on the back, wings, and tail.
LENGTH of the male thirteen inches and a half:SIZE. the WEIGHT about ≈øix ounces. LENGTH of the female eleven inches and a half.

The≈øe birds inhabit the ≈øame countries as the Red-wing Orioles, and generally mingle with them. They ≈øometimes keep ≈øeparate; but u≈øually combine in their ravages among the plantations of maize. After that grain is carried in, they feed on the ≈øeeds of the Water Tare Gra≈øs, or Zizania aquatica. Their good qualities, in clearing the country from noxious in≈øects, have been recited before, in page mixed with the hi≈øtory of their congenial companions.

They appear in New York and Philadelphia in February, PLACE. or the beginning of March; and ≈øit perched on trees near the farms, and give a tolerably agreeable note. They al≈øo build in trees, u≈øually in retired places, making their ne≈øts externally with coar≈øe ≈øtalks,NEST. internally
with bents and fibres, with plai≈øter at the bottom. They lay five or ≈øix eggs, of a pale plue color, thinly ≈øpotted and ≈øtriped with black. After the breeding-≈øea≈øon, they return with their young from their mo≈øt di≈øtant quarters, in flights continuing for miles in length, blackening the very ≈øky, in order to make their depredations on the ripening maize. It is unfortunate that they increa≈øe in proportion as the country is more cultivated; following the maize, in places they were before unknown, where≈øoever that grain is introduced.

They migrate from the northern colonies at approach of winter; but continue in Carolina the whole year, feeding about the barndoor. Their fle≈øh is rank, and unpalatable; and is only the food of birds of prey. The ≈ømall Hawks da≈øh among the flocks, and catch them in the air.
They are al≈øo found in Mexico, and in the i≈øland of Jamaica. They are ≈øometimes eaten; but their fle≈øh is hard, rank, and of bad nouri≈øhment.

div.head: 154. BOAT-TAIL.

div.p: G. With the bill an inch and a half long, ≈øharp, and black: plumage black, glo≈ø≈øed with purple: tail cuneiform, expanded when walking; in flight, or on the perch, folded, ≈øo as to form an oblong cavity in its upper part. LENGTH about thirteen inches.

PLACE.Inhabits not only the greater Antilles, but the warmer parts of North America; con≈øorting with the Purple Grakles, and Red-winged Orioles. Feeds on maize and in≈øects; in the i≈ølands on Bananas.

div.p: C. With the upper mandible of the bill black, the lower yellow: head, and whole upper part of the body, and coverts of the wings, cinereous; under ≈øide entirely white: primaries brown on their exterior, orange on their interior ≈øides: tail long; two middle feathers entirely cinereous, the others tipt with white: legs du≈øky. LENGTH twelve inches.

Inhabits North America. Arrives in New York in May. PLACE. Makes its ne≈øt in June, u≈øually in apple-trees; and lays four eggs, of a blui≈øh white color. The ne≈øt is made of ≈ømall ≈øticks and roots, and re≈øembles greatly that of the Engli≈øh Jay; but is ≈ømaller. It retires from North America in autumn.
This bird, as well as all the foreign Cuckoos, have only the generical character of the well-known European ≈øpecies. They differ in their oeconomy, nor have the opprobrious notes of that bird.

list.item: A. EUROPEAN CUCKOO, Br. Zool. i. No 82. tab. xxxvi. fem.‚ÄîLatham, i. 509.
Cuculus Canorus, Gjok, Faun. Suec. No 96.
Le Coucou, De Buffon, vi. 305.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: C. With dove-colored head, hind part of the neck, back, rump, and coverts: throat, and under ≈øide of the neck, of a pale grey: brea≈øt and belly white, barred with black: primaries du≈øky; inner webs marked with white oval ≈øpots: tail cuneiform; middle feathers black, tipped with white; the re≈øt marked with white ≈øpots on each web. FEMALE. Neck of a browni≈øh red: tail barred with ru≈øt-color and black, and ≈øpotted with white.

PLACE.Inhabits all parts of Europe, as high as Saltens Fogderie, in Norway Pontop. ii. 75. , within the Arctic circle; and even at Loppen, in Finmark Leems, 291. . It is found equally high in A≈øia; and extends as far ea≈øt as Kamt≈øchatka. In all places it retains its ≈øingular note, and its more ≈øingular nature of laying its eggs in the ne≈øts of ≈ømall birds, and totally de≈øerting themDr. PALLAS.. Of the above circum≈øtance I beg leave to add a proof, which fell under my own notice in June 1778; when I ≈øaw a young Cuckoo, almo≈øt full grown (when I fir≈øt di≈øcovered it) in the ne≈øt of a white Wagtail, beneath ≈øome logs in a field adjacent to my hou≈øe. The Wagtail was as ≈øolicitous to feed it, as if it had been its own offspring; for, many days after the Cuckoo fled, it was ≈øeen often perched on the adjacent walls, ≈øtill attended and fed by the Wagtail.
It arrives in the northern and ea≈øtern parts of A≈øia, about the tenth of June.

list.item: B. WRYNECK, Br. Zool. i. No 83.‚ÄîLatham, i. 548.

div.p: W. With a black and colored li≈øt dividing lengthways the crown and back: upper part of the body elegantly pencilled with grey, black, white, and ferruginous: tail con≈øi≈øts of ten feathers, grey, ≈øpeckled with black, and marked equidi≈øtant with four broad black bars.

Extends over all Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, and even to Kamt≈øchatka. PLACE. Found in Sweden, and as high as Drontheim, in Norway; and probably migrates as far as the Cuckoo. The Swedes call this bird Gjoktyta, or the bird which explains the Cuckoo: probably for the ≈øame rea≈øon as the Wel≈øh and Engli≈øh ≈øtyle it the Cuckoo's Man, as it ≈øeems its attendant, and to point out its arrival.

div.p: W. With a bill of ivory whitene≈øs; great ≈øtrength; three inches long: irides yellow: a conic cre≈øt, of a rich ≈øcarlet color, on the hind part of the head: head, throat, neck, brea≈øt, and belly, black: beneath each eye is a narrow ≈øtripe of white, crooked at its beginning, running afterwards ≈øtrait down the ≈øides of the neck: upper part of the back, primary feathers, and coverts of the wings, black; lower part of the back, and the ≈øecondaries, white: tail black.
This is a gigantic ≈øpecies, weighing twenty ounces; and in bulk equal to a Crow.

PLACE.Inhabits the country from New Jer≈øey to the Bra≈øils. Is in North America a ≈øcarce bird; in South America more common. It breeds in the kingdom of Mexico in the rainy ≈øea≈øon; for which rea≈øon Nieremberg ≈øtyles it Picus Imbrifoetus Eu≈øeb. Nieremberg.. The Spaniards call them Carpenteros, Carpenters, on account of the multitude of chips which they hew out of the trees, either in forming their ne≈øts, or in ≈øearch of food, in≈øects, and worms, which lurk beneath the bark. They are very de≈øtructive to trees; for they have been known to cut out a mea≈øure of chips in an hour's timeCate≈øby.. In≈øtinct directs them to form their holes in a winding form, in order the better to protect their ne≈øts from the injury of the weatherBarrere..

Canada is de≈øtitute of the≈øe birds. The Indians of that ≈øevere climate purcha≈øe the bills from the ≈øavages of the more ≈øouthern parts, at the rate of two or three Buck ≈økins apiece, in order to form the coronets Cate≈øby. of their ≈øachems and warriors. The≈øe coronets were made with ≈øeveral materials. Gay plumes formed the rays; the beaks of birds, claws of rare animals, and the little horns of their Roes, were the other ornaments. They were never worn but on high ≈øolemnities; either when a warrior ≈øung the ≈øong of war, or was ≈øetting forward on his march to meet the enemy. He went forth like a Spartan hero, dancing, and crownedLafitau Moeurs de Sauvage, ii. 60. .

LENGTH eighteen inches. WEIGHT nine ounces.

Inhabits the fore≈øts of Pen≈øylvania and New York. PLACE. When the maize begins to ripen, this and the other kinds make great havock, by
≈øettling on the heads, and picking out the grain; or making holes in the leaves, and letting in the wet, to the de≈øtruction of the plantKalm.. It breeds and re≈øides the whole year in the country. It extends as high as lat. 50. 31. north; being found near the banks of Albany river, near four hundred miles from its di≈øcharge into Hud≈øon's Bay. Lays ≈øix eggs, and brings forth its young in June. The Indians deck their Calumets with the cre≈øt of this ≈øpecies.

PLACE.Inhabits from Hud≈øon's Bay to Carolina, and again on the we≈øtern ≈øide of North America. In the fir≈øt is migratory, appearing in April, and leaving the country in September. All the American Woodpeckers agree with tho≈øe of Europe in building in hollow trees, and in laying ≈øix white eggs. The natives of Hud≈øon's Bay call this ≈øpecies, Ou-thee-quan-nor-ow,
Ferruginous Woodpecker. No. 159. Nuthatch No. 170.
from the golden color of the ≈øhafts and under ≈øide of the wing feathers Phil. Tr. lxii. 387..

The Swedi≈øh Americans call it Hittock, and Piut
Kalm, ii. 36.; words formed from its notes. It is almo≈øt continually on the ground; and never picks its food out of the ≈øides of trees, like others of the genus: neither does it climb, but ≈øits perched, like the Cuckoo; to which it has ≈øome re≈øemblance in manners, as well as form. It feeds on in≈øects. Grows very fat, and is reckoned very palatable. It inhabits the Jer≈øies, and other provinces to the ≈øouth, the whole year.

They feed al≈øo on acorns. They were formerly pro≈øcribed; a reward of two pence was put on their heads: but the law was repealed. They migrate ≈øouthward at approach of winter. When they are ob≈øerved to linger in numbers in the woods, in the beginning of winter, the inhabitants reckon it a ≈øign of a mild ≈øea≈øon Kalm, ii. 87..
This ≈øpecies extends acro≈øs the continent to the we≈øtern coa≈øt of America.

Tran≈ø. lxii. 388.
white: two middle feathers of the tail black; the two outmo≈øt entirely white; the re≈øt black, marked cro≈ø≈øways with white. The female wants the red ≈øpot on the head. LENGTH nine inches. WEIGHT two ounces.

The Woodpecker tribe is the mo≈øt pernicious of all the birds of America, except the PURPLE GRAKLE; but this little ≈øpecies is the mo≈øt de≈øtructive of its whole genus, becau≈øe it is the mo≈øt daring. It is the pe≈øt of the orchards, alighting on the apple-trees, running round the boughs or bodies, and picking round them a circle of equidi≈øtant holes. It is very common to ≈øee trees encircled with numbers of the≈øe rings, at ≈øcarcely an inch's di≈øtance from each other; ≈øo that the tree dries and peri≈øhes.

div.head: 167. YELLOW-LEGGED.
div.p:
THIS is in≈øerted on the ≈øu≈øpicious authority of Albin
Vol. iii. 9.‚ÄîBri≈ø≈øon, iv. 24, who follows Albin, calls it, Le Pic noir de la Nouvelle Angleterre.. PLACE.Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay, and Norton Sound, lat. 64. Is frequent in Sibiria, and common as far as Mo≈øcow, in the alps of Dalecarlia in Sweden, and in tho≈øe of Switzerland
M. Sprunglin's collection at Stettlin, near Bern, who told me it was common among the Alps. .

list.item: A. BLACK W. Picus Martius, Lin. Sy≈øt. 173.

PLACE.Inhabits the fore≈øts of Germany, Switzerland, and the north, from Peter≈øbourg to Ochot≈øk, on the ea≈øtern ocean, ea≈øtward, and to Lapmark we≈øtward. It migrates to Worone≈øch, about the third of March, and continues coming in greate≈øt numbers in April. Is called there The
Fu≈øilier; and is the mo≈øt cunning, and difficult to be ≈øhot, of all the tribe.

It does va≈øt damage to trees,MANNERS. by making holes of a great depth in the bodies to ne≈øtle in. A bu≈øhel of du≈øt and chips, a proof of its labors, are often found at the foot of the tree. Makes as much noi≈øe in the operation, as a woodman does with an axe. Rattles with its bill again≈øt the ≈øides of the orifice, till the woods re≈øound. Its note very loud. Lays two or three white ≈øemi-tran≈øparent eggs. Feeds on caterpillars and in≈øects, e≈øpecially Ants.

list.item: C. GREY-HEADED, Edw. 65.‚ÄîLatham, i. 583.

With a grey head, and neck of a blui≈øh grey: no≈øtrils covered with har≈øh black feathers, extending in a line to the eyes: a black line, beginning at the ba≈øe of the lower mandible, points beneath the cheeks towards the hind part of the neck: under ≈øide of the body of the color of the head, da≈øhed with green: all other parts ≈øo exactly like the la≈øt, that I ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe it to have been a variety, had not my very ≈øcientific friend, PALLAS, a≈ø≈øured me that it was a di≈øtinct ≈øpecies, and inferior in ≈øize to the common GREEN.

PLACE.It is found in Norway, and among the alps of Switzerland Catalogue of Swi≈øs birds in M. Sprunglin's cabinet, which that gentleman favored me with. This ≈øpecies was not unnoticed by the great GESNER. See his Hi≈øt. av. ed. p. 710, line 20.; and common in the north of Ru≈ø≈øia, and ≈øtill more in Sibiria. div.p: H. With a black bill, three quarters of an inch long: crown, upper part of the neck, back, and coverts of the wings, of a mo≈øt re≈øplendent variable green and gold: chin and throat of a ≈øhining rich ≈øcarlet, changing, as oppo≈øed to the light, from gold to a full black; the≈øe feathers lie nearly as compactly as ≈øcales: brea≈øt and belly white; the ≈øides green: middle feathers of the tail green; the exterior purple.
The chin, throat, and whole under ≈øide, of the female, is white: the exterior feathers of the tail tipt with white.

MANNERS.This bird, ≈øo admirable for its minutene≈øs, va≈øt ≈øwiftne≈øs of flight, food, and elegance of form and colors, gave ri≈øe to numbers of romantic tales. They were not the Europeans alone, who were ≈øtruck with its great beauty; the natives of America, to whom it was ≈øo familiar, were affected with its gemmeous appearance, and be≈øtowed on it titles expre≈ø≈øive of its re≈øplendent colors. Some nations called it Ouri≈ø≈øia, and Guaracyaba, or the Sun-beam; others, Guanaeygaba, or Hairs of the Sun; others again named it Huitzitzil, or Vicililin,
or the Regenerated; becau≈øe they believed it died annually, and was re-animated at the return of the flowers it fed on: that it ≈øtuck its bill into the trunk of a tree, and remained lifele≈øs for ≈øix months; when the vital powers re-migrated, and re≈øtored to nature one of its mo≈øt brilliant wonders.

It flies with a ≈øwiftne≈øs which the eye is incapable of following.SWIFTNESS. The motion of the wings is ≈øo rapid as to be imperceptible to the nice≈øt ob≈øerver. Lightning is ≈øcarcely more tran≈øient than its flight, nor the glare more bright than its colors.FOOD. It never feeds but upon wing, ≈øu≈øpended over the flower it extracts nouri≈øhment from; for its only food is the honied juice lodged in the nectarium, which it ≈øucks through the tubes of its curious tongue. Like the Bee, having exhau≈øted the honey of one flower, it wanders to the next, in ≈øearch of new ≈øweets. It admires mo≈øt tho≈øe flowers which have the deepe≈øt tubes. Thus the female Bal≈øamine, and the Scarlet Monarda, are particular favorites. Who≈øoever ≈øets tho≈øe plants before the window is ≈øure to be vi≈øited by multitudes of the≈øe diminutive birds. It is a mo≈øt entertaining ≈øight to ≈øee them ≈øwarming around the flowers, and trying every tube of verticillated plants, by putting their bills into every one which encircles the ≈øtalk. If they find that their brethren have been beforehand, and robbed the flower of the honey, they will, in rage, pluck off, and throw it on the ground.

The mo≈øt violent pa≈ø≈øions animate at times their little bodies.RAGE. They have often dreadful conte≈øts, when numbers happen to di≈øpute po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame flower. They will tilt again≈øt one another with ≈øuch fury, as if they meant to transfix their antagoni≈øts with their long bills. During the fight; they frequently pur≈øue the conquered into the apartments of tho≈øe hou≈øes who≈øe windows are left open, take a turn round the room, as Flies do in England, and then ≈øuddenly regain the open air. They are fearle≈øs of mankind; and in feeding will ≈øuffer people to come within two yards of them; but on a nearer approach, dart away with admirable ≈øwiftne≈øs.

Fernandez Oviedo, an author of great repute, ≈øpeaks from his own knowlege of the ≈øpirited in≈øtinct, even of this diminutive bird, in
defence of its young: So that when they ≈øee a man clime ye tree where they have their ne≈øts, they flee at his face, and ≈øtryke hym in the eyes, commyng, goying, and returnyng, with ≈øuch ≈øwyftne≈øs, that no man woulde lyghtly beleeve it, that hath not ≈øeene itHi≈øt. of We≈øt Indies, tran≈ølated by Richard Eden, p. 199. .

Father Charlevoix gives a more apocryphal in≈øtance of the courage of this bird, in its attack on its di≈øproportioned enemy the Raven. As ≈øoon as the la≈øt appears, the Honey≈øucker flies up like lightning, beds it≈øelf beneath the Raven's wing, and, piercing him with his needle-like bill, till the bird is heard to croak with agony, at length tumbles to the ground dead, either from the fall or the wound. This relation ≈øeems of a piece with the combat of the Wren with the Eagle, mentioned by Ari≈øtotle
Hi≈øt. An. lib. ix. c. 11. vol. i. 931.‚ÄîCharlevoix, v. 232.: but, to do ju≈øtice both to the French voyager and Grecian philo≈øopher, I mu≈øt add, that each of them delivered their reports from oral evidence.

Many fables have been related of the melody of the ≈øong of the≈øe birds.NOTE. In fact, their only note is ≈øcreep, ≈øcreep, ≈øcreep; but the noi≈øe which they make with their wings, e≈øpecially in the morning, when numbers are in motion, is a ≈øort of buzz or ≈øound re≈øembling that of a ≈øpinning-wheel. Their note is chiefly emitted when they happen to ≈øtrike again≈øt each other in their flight.

NESTS.Their ne≈øts are found with great difficulty, being built in the branch of a tree, amid≈øt the thick foliage. It is of elegance ≈øuitable to the architects; formed on the out≈øide with mo≈øs; in the in≈øide lined with the down or go≈ø≈øamer collected from the Great Mullein, or Verba≈øcum Thap≈øus; but it is al≈øo ≈øometimes made of flax, hemp, hair, and other ≈øoft materials. It is of an hemi≈øpherical ≈øhape. Its inner diameter an inch: its depth half an inch. The female is ≈øaid to be the builder; the male ≈øupplying her with materials. Each a≈ø≈øi≈øts in the labor of incubation, which continues during twelve days. They lay only two eggs, white, and as ≈ømall as pea≈øe. The fir≈øt is very ≈øingular,
and contrary to the general rule of nature; which makes, in all other in≈øtances, the ≈ømalle≈øt and mo≈øt defencele≈øs birds the mo≈øt prolific. The rea≈øons of the exception in this ca≈øe are double. The ≈ømallne≈øs of their bodies cau≈øes them commonly to e≈øcape the eyes of birds of prey; or if ≈øeen, their rapid flight eludes pur≈øuit: ≈øo that the ≈øpecies is pre≈øerved as fully as if they had been the mo≈øt numerous breeders.

The Indians of Mexico, Peru, and Maynas, make mo≈øt exqui≈øite pictures of the feathers of birds; but tho≈øe of the Honey≈øuckers form the mo≈øt brilliant part. Some u≈øe them as ornaments, and hang them as pendants in their ears, which give a blaze emulous of the Ruby and Emerald. In order to compo≈øe pictures, the Indians draw off the feathers with ≈ømall pincers, and with fine pa≈øte mo≈øt artfully join them together. They di≈øpo≈øe them with ≈øuch ≈økill, as to give the true lights and ≈øhade to the performance, and imitate nature with the greate≈øt fidelity. The≈øe were meant to decorate the idols and temples; for, before the depre≈ø≈øion of the Indian ≈øpirit by the tyranny of the Spaniards, religion was highly cultivated among the Mexicans and Peruvians; and, notwith≈øtanding it was cruel, was attended with great ≈øplendor.

div.p: T. With the characters de≈øcribed in the definition of the genus.DESCRIPTION. Color of the plumage dark, glo≈ø≈øed with variable copper color and green: coverts of the wings, and the quil-feathers, barred with black and white. Tail con≈øi≈øts of two orders; the upper,TAIL. or ≈øhorter, very elegant; the ground color a bright bay; the middle feathers marked with numerous bars of ≈øhining black and green; the greate≈øt part of the exterior feathers of the ≈øame ground with the others, marked with only three broad bands of mallard green, placed remote from each other; the two next are colored like tho≈øe of the middle; but the end is plain, and cro≈ø≈øed with a ≈øingle bar, like the exterior.
The longer, or lower order, were of a ru≈øty white color, mottled with black, and cro≈ø≈øed with numerous narrow waved lines of the ≈øame color, and near the end with a broad band.

Wild Turkies pre≈øerve a ≈øamene≈øs of coloring. The tame, as u≈øual with dome≈øtic animals, vary. It is needle≈øs to point out the differences, in ≈øo well-known a bird. The black approach neare≈øt to the original ≈øtock. This variety I have ≈øeen nearly in a ≈øtate of nature, in Richmond and other parks. A mo≈øt beautiful kind has of late been introduced into England, WHITE VARIETY. of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs, finely contra≈øting with its red head, and black pectoral tuft. The≈øe, I think, came out of Holland, probably bred from an accidental white pair; and from them pre≈øerved pure from any dark or variegated birds.

SIZE.The ≈øizes of the wild Turkies have been differently repre≈øented. Some writers a≈ø≈øert, that there have been in≈øtances of their weighing ≈øixty pounds; but I find none who, ≈øpeaking from their own knowlege, can prove their weight to be above forty. Jo≈ø≈øelyn ≈øays, that he has eaten part of a Cock, which, after it was plucked, and the entrails taken out, weighed thirtyNew England Rarities, 8. . Law≈øon, who≈øe authority is unque≈øtionable, ≈øaw half a Turkey ≈øerve eight hungry men for two mealsHi≈øt. Carolina, 149 and 27. ; and ≈øays, that he had ≈øeen others, which, he believed, weighed forty pounds. Cate≈øby tells us, that out of the many hundreds which he had handledApp. xliv. The greate≈øt certain weight is given by Mr. Clayton, who ≈øaw one that reached 38 lb.‚ÄîPh. Tran≈ø. , very few exceeded thirty pounds. Each of the≈øe ≈øpeak of their being double that ≈øize, merely from the reports of others.

MANNERS.The manners of the≈øe birds are as ≈øingular as their figure. Their attitudes in the ≈øea≈øon of court≈øhip are very ≈øtriking. The males fling their heads and neck backwards, bri≈øtle up their feathers, drop their wings to the ground, ≈øtrut and pace mo≈øt ridiculou≈øly; wheel round the females, with their wings ru≈øtling along the earth, at the ≈øame time emitting a ≈øtrange found through their no≈øtrils, not unlike the grurr of a great ≈øpinning-wheel.NOTES. On being interrupted, fly into great rages, and change their note into a loud and guttural gobble; and then return to dalliance.
The ≈øound of the females is plaintive and melancholy.

The pa≈ø≈øions of the males are very ≈øtrongly expre≈ø≈øed by the change of colors in the fle≈øhy ≈øub≈øtance of the head and neck,IRASCIBLE. which alters to red, white, blue, and yellowi≈øh, as they happen to be affected. The ≈øight of any thing red excites their choler greatly.

They are polygamous, one cock ≈øerving or hens.POLYGAMOUS. They lay in the ≈øpring; and will lay a great number of eggs. They will per≈øi≈øt in laying for a great while. They retire to ≈øome ob≈øcure place to ≈øit, the cock, through rage at lo≈øs of its mate, being very apt to break the eggs. The females are very affectionate to the young, and make great moan on the lo≈øs of them. They ≈øit on their eggs with ≈øuch per≈øeverance, that, if they are not taken away when addle, the hens will almo≈øt peri≈øh with hunger before they will quit the ne≈øt.
Turkies greatly delight in the ≈øeeds of nettles; but tho≈øe of the purple Fox-glove prove fatal to themDe Buffon..
They are very ≈øtupid birds; quarrel≈øome, and cowardly. It is diverting to ≈øee a whole flock attack the common Cock; who will for a long time keep a great number at bay.

They are very ≈øwift runners, in the tame as well as the wild ≈øtate.SWIFT. They are but indifferent flyers. They love to perch on trees;PERCH HIGH. and gain the height they wi≈øh, by ri≈øing from bough to bough. In a wild ≈øtate, they get to the very ≈øummit of the loftie≈øt trees, even ≈øo high as to be beyond the reach of the mu≈øquetLaw≈øon, 45. .

In the ≈øtate of nature they go in flocks even of five hundredLaw≈øon, 149. .GREGARIOUS. Feed much on the ≈ømall red acorns; and grow ≈øo fat in March, that they cannot fly more than three or four hundred yards, and are then ≈øoon run down by a hor≈øeman. In the unfrequented parts bordering on the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øipi, they are ≈øo tame as to be ≈øhot with even a pi≈øtolAdair's Amer. 360. .

They frequent the great ≈øwamps It is in the ≈øwamps that the loftie≈øt and mo≈øt bulky trees grow: the wet, with which they are environed, makes them a mo≈øt ≈øecure retreat. of their native country;HAUNTS. and leave them at ≈øun-ri≈øing to repair to the dry woods, in ≈øearch of
acorns, and various berries; and before ≈øun-≈øet retire to the ≈øwamps to roo≈øt.

The fle≈øh of the wild Turkey is ≈øaid to be ≈øuperior in goodne≈øs to the tame, but redder. Eggs of the former have been taken from the ne≈øt, and hatched under tame Turkies; the young will ≈øtill prove wild, perch ≈øeparate, yet mix and breed together in the ≈øea≈øon. The Indians ≈øometimes u≈øe the breed produced from the wild, as decoy-birds, to ≈øeduce tho≈øe in a ≈øtate of nature within their reachLaw≈øon, 149. .
Wild Turkies are now grown mo≈øt exce≈ø≈øively rare in the inhabited parts of America, and are only found in numbers in the di≈øtant and mo≈øt unfrequented ≈øpots.

The Indians make a mo≈øt elegant cloathing of the feathers. They twi≈øt the inner webs into a ≈øtrong double thread of hemp, or inner bark of the mulberry-tree, and work it like matting. It appears very rich and glo≈ø≈øy, and as fine as a ≈øilk ≈øhagLaw≈øon, 18. Adair, 423. . They al≈øo make fans of the tail; and the French of Loui≈øiana were wont to make umbrellas by the junction of four of the tailsDu Pratz, ii. 85. .

When di≈øturbed, they do not take to wing, but run out of ≈øight. It is u≈øual to cha≈øe them with dogs; when they will fly, and perch on the next tree. They are ≈øo ≈øtupid, or ≈øo in≈øen≈øible of danger, as not to fly on being ≈øhot at; but the ≈øurvivors remain unmoved at the death of their companionsDu Pratz, 224. .

PLACE.TURKIES are natives only of America, or the New World; and of cour≈øe unknown to the antients. Since both the≈øe po≈øitions have been denied by ≈øome of the mo≈øt eminent naturali≈øts of the ≈øixteenth century, I beg leave to lay open, in as few words as po≈ø≈øible, the cau≈øe of their error.

MISTAKEN BY BELON. Belon
248. Hi≈øt. des Oi≈ø., the earlie≈øt of tho≈øe writers who are of opinion that the≈øe birds were natives of the old world, founds his notion on the de≈øcription of the Guinea Fowl, the Meleagrides of Strabo, Athenaeus, Pliny, and others of the antients. I re≈øt the refutation on the excellent
account given by Athenaeus, taken from Clytus Mile≈øius, a di≈øciple of Ari≈øtotle, which can ≈øuit no other than that fowl. "They want, ≈øays he, natural affection towards their young. Their head is naked, and on the top is a hard round body, like a peg or nail: from their cheeks hangs a red piece of fle≈øh, like a beard: it has no wattles, like the common poultry: the feathers are black, ≈øpotted with white: they have no ≈øpurs: and both ≈øexes are ≈øo like, as not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed by the ≈øight. Varro Lib. iii. c. 9. and Pliny Lib. x. c. 26. take notice of the ≈øpotted plumage, and the gibbous ≈øub≈øtance on the head. Athenaeus is more minute, and contradicts every character of the Turkey: who≈øe females are remarkable for their natural affection; which differ materially in form from the males; who≈øe heads are de≈øtitute of the callous ≈øub≈øtance; and who≈øe heels (in the male) are armed with ≈øpurs.

Aldrovandus, who died in 1605,ALDROVANDUS, draws his arguments from the ≈øame ≈øource as Belon; I therefore pa≈øs him by, and take notice of the greate≈øt of our naturali≈øts, GESNER Av. 481.;AND GESNER. who falls into a mi≈øtake of another kind, and wi≈øhes the Turkey to be thought a native of India. He quotes Aelian for that purpo≈øe; who tells us, that in India are very large poultry, not with combs, but with various-colored cre≈øts, interwoven like flowers: with broad tails, neither bending, nor di≈øplayed in a circular form; which they draw along the ground, as Peacocks do when they do not erect them: and that the feathers are partly of a gold color, partly blue, and of an emerald color De Anim. lib. xvi. c. 2..

This, in all probability, was the ≈øame bird with the Peacock Phea≈øant of Mr. Edwards, Le Paon de Tibet of M. Bri≈ø≈øon, and the Pavo Bicalcaratus of Linnaeus. I have ≈øeen this bird living. It has a cre≈øt, but not ≈øo con≈øpicuous as that de≈øcribed by Aelian; but it has tho≈øe ≈øtriking colors in form of eyes: neither does it erect its tail like the
PeacockEdw. ii. 67. Bri≈ø≈øon, i. 291. Lin. Sy≈øt. 268. . The Catreus of Strabo Lib. xv. p. 1046. ≈øeems to be the ≈øame bird. He de≈øcribes it as uncommonly beautiful, and ≈øpotted; and very like a Peacock. The former author De Anim. lib. xvii. c. 23. gives a more minute account of this ≈øpecies, and under the ≈øame name. He borrows it from Clitarchus, an attendant of Alexander the Great in all his conque≈øts. It is evident from his de≈øcription, that it was of this kind; and it is likewi≈øe probable, that it was the ≈øame with his large Indian poultry before cited. He celebrates it al≈øo for its fine note; but allowance mu≈øt be made for the credulity of Aelian. The Catreus, or Peacock Phea≈øant, is a native of Tibet, and in all probability of the north of India, where Clitarchus might have ob≈øerved it; for the march of Alexander was through that part of India which borders on Tibet, and now known by the name of Penj-ab, or Five Rivers.

NOT NATIVES OF EUROPE;I ≈øhall now collect from authors the ≈øeveral parts of the world where Turkies are unknown in the ≈øtate of nature. Europe has no ≈øhare in the que≈øtion, it being generally agreed, that they are exotic in re≈øpect to our continent.

NOR OF ASIA.Neither are they found in any part of A≈øia Minor, or the A≈øiatic TURKEY, notwith≈øtanding ignorance of their true origin fir≈øt cau≈øed them to be named from that empire. About Aleppo, capital of Syria, they are only met with dome≈øticated, like other poultryRu≈ø≈øell, 63. . In Armenia they are unknown, as well as in Per≈øia, having been brought from Venice by ≈øome Armenian merchants into that empireTavernier, 146. ; where they are ≈øtill ≈øo ≈øcarce, as to be pre≈øerved among other rare fowls in the Royal menageryBell's Travels, i. 128. .
In India they are kept for u≈øe in our ≈øettlements, and imported from Europe, as I have been more than once informed by gentlemen long re≈øident in that country.
Du Halde acquaints us, that they are not natives of China; but were introduced there from other countries. He errs, from mi≈øinformation, in ≈øaying that they are common in India.

I will not quote Gemelli Careri, to prove that they are not found in the Philippine i≈ølands, becau≈øe that gentleman, with his pen, travelled round the world in his ea≈øy chair, during a very long indi≈øpo≈øition and confinement Sir James Porter's Ob≈ø. Turkey, i. 1. .
But Dampier bears witne≈øs that none are found in Mindanao I. 321..

The hot climate of Africa barely ≈øuffers the≈øe birds to exi≈øt in that va≈øt continent, except under the care of mankind.NOR AFRICA: Very few are found in Guinea, except in the hands of the Europeans: the negroes declining to breed any, on account of their great tenderne≈øsBarbot, in Churchill's Coll. v. 29. Bo≈øman, 229. .

Pro≈øper Alpinus ≈øatisfies us that they are not found either in Nubia or in Egypt. He de≈øcribes the Meleagrides of the antients; and only proves that the Guinea-hens were brought out of Nubia, and ≈øold at a great price at Cairo Hi≈øt. Nat. Aegypti, i. 201. , but is totally ≈øilent about the Turkey of the moderns.

Let me in this place ob≈øerve, that the Guinea-hens have long been imported into Britain. They were cultivated in our farm-yards: for I di≈øcover, in 1277, in the grainge of Clifton, in the pari≈øh of Ambro≈øden, in Buckingham≈øhire, among other articles, VI. mutilones, and ≈øex AFRICANAE faeminae Kennet's Parochial Antiq. 287. ; for this fowl was familiarly known by the names of Afra Avis, and Gallina Africana & Numida. It was introduced into Italy from Africa, and from Rome into our country. They were neglected here by rea≈øon of their tenderne≈øs and difficulty of rearing. We do not find them in the bills of fare of our antient fea≈øtsNeither in that of George Nevil, archbi≈øhop of York, in 1466, nor among the delicacies mentioned in the Northumberland Hou≈øhold Book, in the beginning of the reign of Henry VIII.: neither do we find the Turkey: which la≈øt argument amounts to almo≈øt a certainty, that ≈øuch a hardy and princely bird had not found its way to us. The other likewi≈øe was then known here by its cla≈ø≈øical name; for that judicious writer,
Dr. Caius Caii Opu≈øc. 93. , de≈øcribes, in the beginning of the reign of Elizabeth, the Guinea fowl, for the benefit of his friend Ge≈øner, under the name of Meleagris, be≈øtowed on it by Ari≈øtotle
Hi≈øt. An. lib. vi. c. 2..

Having denied, on the very be≈øt authorities, that the Turkey ever exi≈øted as a native of the old world, I mu≈øt now bring my proofs of its being only a native of the new; and of the period in which it fir≈øt made its appearance in Europe.

BUT OF AMERICA.The fir≈øt preci≈øe de≈øcription of the≈øe birds is given by Oviedo; who in 1525 drew up a ≈øummary of his greater work, the Hi≈øtory of the Indies, for the u≈øe of his monarch Charles V. This learned man had vi≈øited the We≈øt Indies and its i≈ølands in per≈øon, and payed particular regard to the natural hi≈øtory. It appears from him, that the Turkey was in his days an inhabitant of the greater i≈ølands, and of the main land. He ≈øpeaks of them as Peacocks; for, being a new bird to him, he adopts that name, from the re≈øemblance he thought they bore to the former: But (≈øays he) the neck is bare of feathers, but covered with a ≈økin which they change after their phanta≈øie into divers colours. They have a horn as it were on their front, and HAIRES on the brea≈øtIn Purchas, iii. 995.. He de≈øcribes other birds, which he al≈øo calls Peacocks. They are of the gallinaceous genus, and known by the name of Cura≈ø≈øao birds; the male of which is black, the female ferruginous.

The next who ≈øpeaks of them as natives of the main land of the warmer parts of America, is Franci≈øco Fernandez, ≈øent there by Philip II. to whom he was phy≈øician. This naturali≈øt ob≈øerved them in Mexico. MEXICO. We find by him, that the Indian name of the male was Huexolofl, of the female Cihuatotolin: he gives them the title of Gallus Indicus, and Gallo-Pavo. As the Indians as well as Spaniards dome≈øticated the≈øe u≈øeful birds, he ≈øpeaks of the ≈øize by compari≈øon, ≈øaying that the wild were twice the magnitude of the tame; and that they were ≈øhot with arrows or gunsHi≈øt. Av. Nov. Hi≈øp. 27. . I cannot learn the time
when Fernandez wrote. It mu≈øt be between the years 1555 and 1598, the period of Philip's reign.

Pedro de Cie≈øa mentions Turkies on the I≈øthmus of Darien Seventeen Years Travels, 20. .DARIEN. Lery, a Portugue≈øe author, a≈ø≈øerts that they are found in Bra≈øil, and gives them an Indian name In De Laet's De≈øcr. des Indes, 491. ; but ≈øince I can di≈øcover no traces of them in that diligent and excellent naturali≈øt Marcgrave, who re≈øided long in that country, I mu≈øt deny my a≈ø≈øent. But the former is confirmed by that able and hone≈øt navigator Dampier, who ≈øaw them frequently, as well wild as tame, in the province of Yucatan
Voyages, vol. ii. part 2d. p. 65, 85, 114.,YUCATAN. now reckoned part of the kingdom of Mexico.

In North America they were ob≈øerved by the very fir≈øt di≈øcoverers.N. AMERICA. When Ren√® de Laudonniere, patronized by Admiral Coligni, attempted to form a ≈øettlement near the place where Charle≈øtown now ≈øtands, he met with them on his fir≈øt landing, in 1564, and by his hi≈øtorian, has repre≈øented them with great fidelity in the Vth plate of the recital of his voyageDe Bry.. From his time, the witne≈ø≈øes to their being natives of this continent are innumerable. They have been ≈øeen in flocks of hundreds in all parts, from Loui≈øiana even to Canada: but at this time are extremely rare in a wild ≈øtate, except in the more di≈øtant parts, where they are ≈øtill found in va≈øt abundance.

It was from Mexico or Yucatan that they were fir≈øt introduced into Europe; WHEN FIRST INTRODUCED INTO EUROPE. for it is certain that they were imported into England as early as the year 1524, the 15th of Henry VIII Baker's Chr. Ander≈øon's Dict. Com. i. 354. Hackluyt, ii. 165. makes their introduction about the year 1532. Barnaby Googe, one of our early writers on hu≈øbandry, ≈øays they were not ≈øeen here before 1530. He highly commends a Lady Hales, of Kent, for her excellent management of tho≈øe fowl. p. 166.. We probably received them from Spain, with which we had great intercour≈øe till about that time. They were mo≈øt ≈øucce≈øsfully cultivated in our kingdom from that period; in≈øomuch that they grew common in every farm-yard, and became even a di≈øh in our rural fea≈øts by
the year 1585; for we may certainly depend on the word of old Tu≈ø≈øer, in his account of the Chri≈øtmas hu≈øbandlie fareFive hundred pointes of good hu≈øbandrie, p. 57. .

q.l: Beefe, mutton, and porke, ≈øhred pies of the be≈øt,
Pig, veale, goo≈øe and capon, and Turkie well dre≈øt:
Chee≈øe, apples, and nuts, jolie carols to heare,
As then in the countrie, is counted good cheare.

div.p: But at this very time they were ≈øo rare in France, that we are told that the very fir≈øt which was eaten in that kingdom appeared at the nuptial fea≈øt of Charles IX. in 1570Ander≈øon's Dict. Comm. i. 410. .
They are now very common in all parts of Ru≈ø≈øia, but will not thrive in Sibiria. Are cultivated in Sweden, and even in Norway, where they degenerate in ≈øizePontopp. 78. .

div.p: GR. With a great ruff on the hind part of the neck, to be rai≈øed or depre≈ø≈øed at plea≈øure: the head cre≈øted: that, hind part of the neck, the ruff, back, and coverts of the wings, prettily varied with brown, ferruginous, and black: the black on the ruff di≈øpo≈øed in broad black bars: the coverts of the tail marked with heart-≈øhaped ≈øpots of white: chin white: fore part of the neck yellowi≈øh: brea≈øt and belly dirty white, barred with cinereous brown: primaries barred on their outmo≈øt ≈øides with black and ru≈øt-colour.

Tail large, expan≈øible like a fan; in ≈øome of a cinereous colour, in others orange, mo≈øt elegantly barred with narrow undulated lines of black; near the end with a broad band of a≈øh-color, another of black, and tipped with white.
Legs feathered to the feet: toes naked and pectinated.

Female wants both cre≈øt and ruff. Crown du≈øky: back mixed with black and ru≈øt-colour like a Woodcock: brea≈øt, belly, and coverts of the wings, barred with dirty white and cinereous brown: tail ≈øhort, brown, tipt with white; two middle feathers mottled with red.
SIZE.In ≈øize the≈øe birds ob≈øerve a medium between a Phea≈øant and a Partridge. Length 1 foot 5 inches.

PLACE.They inhabit North America, from Hud≈øon's Bay Phil. Tran≈ø. lxii. 393. to the Carolinas, and probably to Loui≈øiana The accounts given by Bo≈ø≈øu, Engl. ed. i. 95. and by Du Pratz, ii. are too flight for us to determine the ≈øpecies they mean. Charlevoix, in his account of Canada, vol. v. de≈øcribes it very well..

MANNERS.The hi≈øtory of this ≈øpecies is very curious: all which I beg leave to tran≈øcribe from Mr. Edwards, according to the accounts given him by Mr. Bartram and Mr Brooke, who had frequent opportunity of ob≈øerving its manners; to which I ≈øhall add another, borrowed from the Travels of the Baron La Hontan.

p.q:
He is (≈øays Mr. Bartram) a fine bird when his gaiety is di≈øplayed; that is, when he ≈øpreads his tail like that of a Turkey-cock, and erects a circle of feathers round his neck like a ruff, walking very ≈øtately with an even pace, and making a noi≈øe ≈øomething like a Turkey; at which time the hunter mu≈øt fire immediately at him, or he flies away directly two or three hundred yards, before he ≈øettles on the ground. There is ≈øomething very remarkable in what we call their thumping; which they do with their wings, by clapping them again≈øt their ≈øides, as the hunters ≈øay. They ≈øtand upon an old fallen tree, that has lain many years on the ground, where they begin their ≈øtrokes gradually, at about two ≈øeconds of time di≈øtant from one another, and repeat them quicker and quicker, until they make a noi≈øe like thunder at a di≈øtance; which continues, from the beginning, about a minute; then cea≈øeth for about ≈øix or eight minutes before it begins again. The ≈øound is heard near half a mile, by which means they are di≈øcovered by the hunters, and many of them killed. I have ≈øhot many of them in this po≈øition; but never ≈øaw them thump, they mo≈øtly ≈øeeing me fir≈øt, and ≈øo left off. They commonly exerci≈øe in thumping ≈øpring and fall, at about nine or ten in the morning,
and four or five in the afternoon. Their food is chiefly berries and ≈øeeds of the country: their fle≈øh is white, and choice food. I believe they breed but once a year, in the ≈øpring, and hatch twelve or fourteen at a brood; which keep in a company till the following ≈øpring. Many have attempted to rai≈øe the young ones, and to tame them; but to no purpo≈øe. When hatched under a hen, they e≈øcape into the woods ≈øoon after they are hatched, where they either find means to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, or peri≈øh.

div.p: LA HONTAN.In order to perfect, as far as I am able, the hi≈øtory of this bird, I ≈øhall give a quotation from Baron La Hontan's Voyages to North America, publi≈øhed in Engli≈øh, (vol. i. p. 67.) where he ≈øpeaks of a bird found near the lakes of Canada, which, I think, can be no other than the above-de≈øcribed, though the names given them di≈øagree.

La Hontan ≈øays, I went in company with ≈øome Canade≈øe on purpo≈øe to ≈øee that fowl flap with its wings: believe me, this ≈øight is one of the greate≈øt curio≈øities in the world; for their flapping makes a noi≈øe much like a drum, for about the ≈øpace of a minute; then the noi≈øe cea≈øes for half a quarter of an hour; after which it begins again. By this noi≈øe we were directed to the place where the unfortunate More-hen ≈øat, and found them upon rotten mo≈ø≈øy trees. By flapping one wing again≈øt the other they mean to call their mates; and the humming noi≈øe that en≈øues thereupon may be heard half a quarter of a league. This they do in the months of April, May, September, and October; and, which is very remarkable, the More-hen never flaps in this manner but upon one tree. It begins at break of day, and gives over at nine o'clock in the morning, till about an hour before ≈øun-≈øet, then it flutters again, and continues ≈øo to do till night.

Mr. GRAHAM.To the≈øe accounts I beg leave to add the following, out of the Philo≈øophical Tran≈øactions; which informs us, that this ≈øpecies of Grous bears the Indian name of Pu≈økee, or Pu≈øpu≈økee, at Hud≈øon's Bay, on account of the leanne≈øs and dryne≈øs of their fle≈øh, which is extremely white, and of a very clo≈øe texture; but when well prepared, is excellent eating. They are pretty common at Moo≈øe Fort and Henly Hou≈øe; but are ≈øeldom ≈øeen at Albany Fort, or to the northward of the above places. In winter they feed upon juniper-tops, in ≈øummer on goo≈øeberries, ra≈øpberries, currants, cranberries, &c. They are not
migratory; ≈øtaying all the year at Moo≈øe Fort: they build their ne≈øt on dry ground, hatch nine young at a time, to which the mother clucks as our common hens do; and, on the le≈øt appearance of danger, or in order to enjoy an agreeable degree of warmth, the young ones retire under the wings of their parent.

div.p: GR. With head, cheeks, and neck of a reddi≈øh brown, marked with du≈øky lines: chin and throat of a pale ru≈øty brown: on the head is a ≈ømall cre≈øt: on each ≈øide of the neck a mo≈øt ≈øingular tuft (five feathers in each) gradually lengthening to the fifth, which is about three inches long: the upper feathers ferruginous and white; the lower black: back and ≈øcapulars black and pale ru≈øt-colour; the former ≈øpotted with white: brea≈øt and belly barred with white and pale brown: tail barred with pale brown and black.
Legs covered with ≈øoft brown feathers: toes naked and pectinated.

SIZE of a Phea≈øant. A peculiar ≈øpecies,SIZE. not to be confounded with the precedingThe Comte De Buffon, ii. 282. falls into this mi≈øtake.. De≈øcribed from the real bird by Mr. Cate≈øby; and by my≈øelf from the ≈øpecimens in Mrs. Blackburn's cabinet; which were ≈øent from the province of Connecticut. PLACE. Is frequent about a hundred miles up Albany river, in Hud≈øon's Bay.

The tufts, which di≈øtingui≈øh this ≈øpecies from all others, are rooted high on the neck, not far from the hind part of the head. The bird has the power of erecting or dropping them at plea≈øure. When di≈øturbed, it would ≈øpread them horizontally, like little wings; at other times let them fall on the ≈øides of the neckCate≈øby.. It is probable, that they a≈ø≈øi≈øt in running or flying, or perhaps both, as the real wings are very ≈øhort, in proportion to the weight of the body. The≈øe appendages are peculiar to the cock, and almo≈øt the only difference between it and the hen.

div.head: 181. SHARP-TAILED.

list.item: Long-tailed Grous, Edw. 118.‚ÄîPh. Tr. lxii.

div.p: GR. With the head, cheeks, and hind part of the neck, varied with reddi≈øh brown and black: the back and coverts of the tail of the ≈øame color: the ≈øcapulars and great coverts of the wings ferruginous, ≈øpotted with black, and great ≈øpots of white: primaries black, ≈øpotted with white: brea≈øt and ≈øides white, elegantly marked with ≈øagittal ≈øpots of black: belly white: tail ≈øhort and cuneiform; the two middle feathers two inches longer than the others; the tail is of the ≈øame color with the back, only the exterior feathers are ≈øpotted with white: the legs are covered with ≈øoft and long feathers, extending over the pectinated toes, which would be otherwi≈øe naked.
SIZE.The LENGTH of this ≈øpecies is ≈øeventeen inches: the EXTENT of wings twenty-four: WEIGHT two pounds.
PLACE.Inhahits Hud≈øon's Bay; and, according to Dr. Mitchel, the unfrequented parts of Virginia; but none have been brought over to England from any other place than the Bay.

Linnaeus confounds this with the Wood Grous, or Cock of the Wood Br. Zool. i. No 92. tab. xl.. Compari≈øon will ≈øhew with how little rea≈øon the Comte De Buffon
Oi≈ø. ii. 279. makes it to be the female of the next ≈øpecies, our Spotted Grous. If the female of that was not a≈øcertained, the difference in the form of the tail would be ≈øufficient to e≈øtabli≈øh a di≈øtinction; by which it approaches neare≈øt to the European Phea≈øant of any bird in North America.

The Indians about Hud≈øon's Bay call this ≈øpecies the Au Ku≈økow. It continues there the whole year; lives among the ≈ømall larch bu≈øhes, and feeds, during winter, on the buds of that plant and the birch; in the ≈øummer, on all ≈øorts of berries. The females lay from nine to thirteen eggs. The young, like others of this genus, run as ≈øoon as hatched, and make a puling noi≈øe like a chicken. They differ chiefly from the cock, in having le≈øs of the red naked ≈økin over the eyes. The cock has a ≈øhrill crowing note, but not very loud. When di≈øturbed, or while flying, it makes a repeated noi≈øe of cuck, cuk; and makes a noi≈øe with the feathers of its tail like the cracking of a fan. The fle≈øh of the≈øe birds is of a light brown color, plump, and very juicy.

div.head: 182. SPOTTED.

list.item: Black and Spotted Heathcock (male) Edw. 118.
Brown and Spotted Heathcock (female) Edw. 71.
Tetrao Canaden≈øis (male) Lin. Sy≈øt. 274.
Tetrao Canace (female) Lin. Sy≈øt. 275.‚ÄîLatham.
La Gelinote de la Baye de Hud≈øon, Bri≈ø≈øon, i. 201. and the ≈øame, App. 10. (male.)
La Gelinote de Canada, Bri≈ø≈øon, i. 203. tab. xx. fig. 1. 2. (m. and fem.)‚ÄîDe Buffon, ii. 279.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 131, 132.

div.p: GR. With a white ≈øpot before and behind each eye: head, neck, back, and coverts of the wings and tail, du≈øky brown, cro≈ø≈øed with black: throat of a glo≈ø≈øy black, bounded by a white line, commencing at the external corner of each eye: brea≈øt of the former color: belly white, marked with great black ≈øpots: tail black, external feathers tipt with orange: legs feathered: toes naked and pectinated.

The FEMALE is of a reddi≈øh brown, barred and ≈øpotted with black:FEMALE. belly of a dirty white, ≈øpotted with black: tail of a deep brown, barred with mottled bands of black; the tips of the exterior feathers orange.
The WEIGHT is twenty-three ounces: LENGTH fifteen inches:SIZE. EXTENT near two feet.

PLACE.Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay, Newfoundland, and Canada. Is called by the Engli≈øh of Hud≈øon's Bay, the Wood Partridge, from its living in pine woods. The≈øe birds are very ≈øtupid; ≈øo that they are often knocked down with a ≈øtick; and are u≈øually caught by the natives with a noo≈øe fa≈øtened to a ≈øtake. In ≈øummer they are very palatable; for in that ≈øea≈øon they feed on berries. In winter they live on the ≈øhoots of the ≈øpruce-fir, which infects the fle≈øh with a very di≈øagreeable ta≈øte. If it is true, that this ≈øpecies lays but five eggs Ph. Tr. lxii. 390., it is a ≈øtrange exception to the prolific nature of the genus.

div.head: 183. WHITE.

list.item: White Partridge, Edw. 72.‚ÄîEllis's Voy. 37.
La Lagopede de la Baie de Hud≈øon, De Buffon, ii. 276. tab. ix.‚ÄîLatham.
La Gelinote blanche, Bri≈ø≈øon, i. 216.≈øPl. Enl.
Tetrao Lagopus, ≈øuecis Snoripa, Lappis Cheruna, Faun. Suec. No 203

div.p: GR. With a black bill: ≈øcarlet eye-brows, very large in the male; in the female far le≈øs con≈øpicuous. Head, neck and part of the back,SUMMER PLUMAGE. coverts of the tail, and ≈øcapulars, deep orange, cro≈ø≈øed with numerous du≈øky lines, and often marked with great blotches of white: belly, legs, and middle feathers of the tail, white: the re≈øt of the tail du≈øky, tipt with white: the ≈øhafts of the quill feathers black: the legs and toes warmly clad with a very thick and long coat of ≈øoft white feathers: the claws broad and flat, adapted for digging.

WINTER PLUMAGE.Such is the ≈øummer dre≈øs: in winter they change their color to white, or, more properly ≈øpeaking, moult, and change their colored plumes for white ones.DOUBLY FEATHERED. By a wonderful providence, every feather, except tho≈øe of the wings and tail, becomes double; a downy one ≈øhooting out at the ba≈øe of each, as expre≈ø≈øed in the plate, which gives an additional protection again≈øt the cold. In the latter end of February, the ≈øummer plumage begins to appear fir≈øt about the
rump, in form of brown ≈øtumpsDrage's Voy. ii. 9. , the fir≈øt rudiments of the coat they a≈ø≈øume in the warm ≈øea≈øon, when each feather is ≈øingle, ≈øuitable to the time. I ought to have ob≈øerved before, that the SPOTTED GROUS al≈øo changes its ≈øingle for double feathers at approach of winter, notwith≈øtanding it undergoes no change of color.
The WEIGHT of this ≈øpecies is twenty-four ounces:SIZE. its LENGTH ≈øixteen inches and a quarter: EXTENT twenty-three.

The≈øe birds are met with round the globe,PLACE. within and without the arctic circle, and as high as lat. 72, in the countries round Hud≈øon's Bay, and as low as Newfoundland; in Norway; perhaps in the N. of the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions in Europe The feathers of the Ru≈ø≈øian kind, which≈øoever it was, in early times, about Pechora, were an article of commerce, and were ≈øold for two pence of their money per Pood, or 38 lb. Purchas, iii. 536., and certainly in A≈øia all over Sibiria, as far as Kamt≈øchatka, and in the i≈ølands which lie between that country and America. Finally, they abound in Lapland and Iceland; and I repeat, with certainty,NORWAY. that Norway has ≈øupplied me with this ≈øpecies, which was ≈øent to me by the late Mr. Flei≈øcher, of Copenhagen, along with the le≈ø≈øer kind, which proved to be the ≈øame with the White Grous of the Alps, and the Ptarmigan of the Highlands of Scotland. Each of the varieties of the Norwegian birds were in their ≈øummer dre≈øs; and differed mo≈øt materially in ≈øize as well as color, the one being in all re≈øpects like the American kind: the le≈ø≈øer agreed in every point with that which I de≈øcribe, No 95, vol. i. of my Briti≈øh Zoology.

The natives di≈øtingui≈øh the kinds. The larger,NORWEGIANS DISTINGUISH TWO KINDS. which inhabits fore≈øts, is ≈øtyled by them Skorv Rype, or the Wood Grous; the le≈ø≈øer, which lives in the mountains, is called Fiaeld Rype, or the Mountain GrousThe Ru≈ø≈øian White Grous inhabits indifferently woods, mountains, plains, and mar≈øhes. The Briti≈øh ≈øpecies or variety is in Ru≈ø≈øia about half the ≈øize of the Sibirian kind.. They all burrow under the ≈ønow; and form exten≈øive walks beneath. There they feed, e≈øpecially in Lapland, on
the ≈øeeds of the dwarf birchFl. Lap. 268. , and in the ≈øea≈øon on variety of berries of mountain plants. During winter they are taken and brought to Bergen by thou≈øands; are half roa≈øted, and put into firkins, and tran≈øported to other countriesPontoppidan, ii. 92. .

The le≈ø≈øer variety is not unknown in America. The ≈øort here de≈øcribed is found in amazing quantities, e≈øpecially about Hud≈øon's Bay, where they breed in all parts along the coa≈øts, make their ne≈øts on dry ridges on the ground, and lay from nine to eleven eggs, powdered with black.

This is the only ≈øpecies of Grous in N. America to which Providence hath given that warm protection to its feet, evidently to ≈øecure them again≈øt the cold of their winter lodgings: and, as they are greatly ≈øought after by Eagles, Owls, and other birds of prey, a fine provi≈øion is made for their ≈øafety, by the change of color, which renders them not to be di≈øtingui≈øhed from the ≈ønow they lie on.

Every morning they take a flight into the air directly upwards, to ≈øhake the ≈ønow from their wings and bodies. They feed in the mornings and evenings, and in the middle of the day ba≈øk in the ≈øun. In the morning they call to one another with a loud note, interrupted; feeding in the intervals, and calling again.

In the beginning of October, they a≈ø≈øemble in flocks of two hundred, and live much among the willows, the tops of which they eat; whence they are called Willow Partridges. About the beginning of December they appear in le≈øs plenty, retiring from the flats about the ≈øettlements on Hud≈øon's Bay to the mountains, where in that month the ≈ønow is le≈øs deep than in the lowlands, to feed on cranberries and other berriesDrage's Voy. i. 174. . In Greenland they re≈øort in ≈øummer to the mountains for the ≈øake of the crowberriesEmpetrum Nigrum. See Crantz. Greenl. i. 64, 75., which they eat even with the leaves of the plant. In winter they de≈øcend to the ≈øhores, where the winds ≈øweep the ≈ønow off the rocks, and enable them to pick up a ≈øu≈øtenance.

They are an excellent food, and much ≈øearched after by the Europeans in Hud≈øon's Bay. They are generally as tame as chickens, e≈øpecially in a mild day: ≈øometimes they are rather wild; but by being driven about, or ≈øhot at with powder, they grow ≈øo weary, by the ≈øhort flights they take, as ≈øoon to become very tame again. Sometimes the hunters, when they ≈øee the birds likely to take a long flight, imitate the crying of a Hawk, which intimidates them ≈øo much, that they in≈øtantly ≈øettle. When the female is killed, the male can ≈øcarcely be forced from the body of its mateFaun. Groenl. p. 117. .

The u≈øual method of taking them is in nets made of twine, twenty feet ≈øquare, fa≈øtened to four poles, and ≈øupported in front in a perpendicular direction with ≈øticks. A long line is fa≈øtened to the≈øe props, the end of which is held by a per≈øon who lies concealed at a di≈øtance. Several people are then employed to drive the birds within reach of the net, which is then pulled down, and often covers at one haul fifty or ≈øeventy. At this time they are ≈øo plentiful, that ten thou≈øand are taken for the u≈øe of the ≈øettlement from November to the end of April. In former days, they mu≈øt have been infinitely more numerous; for Sir Thomas Button relates, that when he wintered there in 1612, he took eighteen hundred dozens of the≈øe and other fowlQuoted in North-we≈øt Fox, 228.: but this is a trifle to the ≈øucce≈øs of M. Jeremie, who a≈ø≈øerts, that there were eaten in one winter, between him≈øelf and ≈øeventy-nine others, ninety thou≈øand Grous, and twenty-five thou≈øand RabbetsRecucil de Voy. au Nord. iii. 344..

The Laplanders take them by forming a hedge with the boughs of birch-trees; leaving ≈ømall openings at certain intervals, and hang in each a ≈ønare. The birds are tempted to come and feed on the buds or catkins of the birch; and whenever they endeavour to pa≈øs through the openings they are in≈øtantly caught.

div.head: 184. ROCK.
div.p: ROCK Gr. With a black line from the bill to the eye. In all other parts of the plumage of the ≈øame colors with the WHITE, No 183; but inferior in ≈øize by one third.

Differs in nature. Feeds on the tops of ≈ømall birch. Frequents only the dry rocky grounds, and the larch plains. Makes a ≈øingular ≈ønoring noi≈øe, with its neck ≈øtreched out, and ≈øeemingly with difficulty. Is very numerous in the northern parts of Hud≈øon's Bay, and never vi≈øits the ≈øouthern end, except in very hard weather. Never takes ≈øhelter in the woods, but ≈øits on the rocks, or burrows in the ≈ønow. Is inferior in goodne≈øs to the preceding.

list.item: A. WOOD GROUS, Br. Zool. i. No 92.
Tetraonis alterum Genus, Plinii, lib. x. c. 22.

div.p: MALE.GR. With head, neck, and back cro≈ø≈øed with ≈ølender lines of black and grey: upper part of the brea≈øt glo≈ø≈øy green: tail black; the feathers on each ≈øide ≈øpotted with white: legs feathered: toes naked and pectinated.SIZE. LENGTH two feet eight: WEIGHT ≈øometimes fourteen pounds.
FEMALE.Length of the female only two feet two: color ferruginous and black, di≈øpo≈øed generally in bars.

Notwith≈øtanding the opinions of Linnaeus and the Count De Buffon, this ≈øpecies is unknown in North America. Its mo≈øt ≈øoutherly habitation, as far as I can di≈øcover, is the Archipelago, PLACE. it being found in the i≈ølands of Crete and of Milo. One was ≈øhot in the la≈øt, perched on a palm-tree, on who≈øe fruit it probably fed. I ≈øu≈øpect that it does not extend into A≈øia Minor; for Doctor Ru≈ø≈øell does not enumerate it among the Syrian birds. As the Tetrao, which Athenaeus
Lib. xiv. p. 654. calls a ≈øort of Phea≈øant, was found in the antient Media, it may ≈øtill be met with in the northern part of Per≈øia. If Ari≈øtotle intends this ≈øpecies by the words Tetrix and Ourax
Hi≈øt. An. lib. vi. c. 1., it was likewi≈øe found in Greece; but he applies tho≈øe names only to a bird which lays its eggs on the gra≈ø≈øy ground, and ≈øays no more.

Pliny gives a far clearer de≈øcription of the Tetraones of Italy. Decet TETRAONAS ≈øuus nitor, ab≈øolutaque nigritia, in ≈øuperciliis cocci rubor. This certainly means only the cock of the Black Grous; which is di≈øtingui≈øhed by the inten≈øe blackne≈øs and the brilliant glo≈øs of its plumage, as well as by its ≈øcarlet eyebrows, which is common to it and the Wood Grous; which la≈øt is the ≈øpecies de≈øcribed by the ancient naturali≈øt; truly in ≈øome re≈øpects, hyperbolically in others. He ≈øays it is of the ≈øize of a Vulture, and not unlike it in color Hi≈øt. Nat. lib. x. c. 22.. Both the≈øe a≈ø≈øertions approach the truth; for the upper part of the body has a du≈øky or ≈øooty look, not unlike that of the Vulture of the Alps. But when he ≈øpeaks of its being the heavie≈øt bird next to the O≈øtrich, we ≈øee plainly he goes beyond all bounds.

It is a ≈øpecies found in mo≈øt parts of the wooded and mountanous countries of Europe, and extends even to the arctic Lapmark Leems, 241. : is common in Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria; in the la≈øt are found greater and le≈ø≈øer varieties. It is found even as far as Kamt≈øchatka.

list.item: B. SPURIOUS GR. Tetrao Hybridus. Racklehane. Ro≈ølagis Ro≈øtare, Faun. Suec. No 201.

div.p: GR. With a ≈øpotted brea≈øt and forked tail. In ≈øize equal to the hen of the preceding. Is much ≈øcarcer, more timid, and its note very different. Linnaeus ≈øays it is a mixed breed between the WOOD and BLACK GROUS; but his account of it is ob≈øcure.

list.item: C. BLACK GROUS, Br. Zool. i. No 93.
Tetrao ius, Plinii.
Tetrao Tetrix, Orre, Faun. Suec. No 202.

div.p: GR. With a white ≈øpot on the ≈øhoulders, and white vent feathers: re≈øt of the plumage of a full black, glo≈ø≈øed with blue: tail much forked, exterior feathers curling outwards. Weight near four pounds. Length one foot ten inches.
Female weighs but two pounds. The tail is ≈ølightly forked and ≈øhort: the colors ru≈øt, black, and cinereous.

PLACE.Inhabits Europe, as high as Lapland: extends over Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria as far as birch-trees grow, of the catkins and buds of which it is very fond. Feeds much on the populus bal≈øamifera The Taccamahacca of North America. Cate≈øby, i. 34., which gives its fle≈øh a fine flavor. In northern Europe, this and the la≈øt ≈øpecies live during ≈øummer on whortle-berries, and feed their young with gnats. In ≈øummer the males perch on trees, and animate the fore≈øts with their crowing. In winter they lie on the ground, become buried in the ≈ønows, and form walks beneath, in which they
often continue forty daysAmoen. Acad. iv. 591. . They are at pre≈øent taken in ≈ønares; but in Lapland were formerly ≈øhot with arrowsOlaus Gent. Septr. lib. xix. c. 13. .

During winter, there is at pre≈øent a very ≈øingular way of taking the BLACK GROUS in Sibiria. In the open fore≈øts of birch, a certain number of poles are placed horizontally on forked ≈øticks: by way of allurement, ≈ømall bundles of corn are placed on them; and not remote, are ≈øet certain tall ba≈økets of a conic ≈øhape, with the broade≈øt part uppermo≈øt: within the mouth is placed a ≈ømall wheel, through which pa≈ø≈øes an axis fixed ≈øo nicely as to admit it to play very readily, and permit one ≈øide or the other, on the lea≈øt touch, to drop down, and again recover its ≈øituation. The BLACK GROUS are ≈øoon attracted by the corn on the horizontal poles; fir≈øt alight on them, and after a ≈øhort repa≈øt fly to the ba≈økets, attempt to ≈øettle on their tops, when the wheel drops ≈øideways, and they fall headlong into the trap, which is ≈øometimes found half full.

list.item: D. PTARMIGAN, Br. Zool. i. No 95.
Tetrao Lagopus. Suecis Snoripa. Lappis Cheruna, Faun. Suec. No 203.
Le Lagopede, De Buffon, ii. 264. tab. ix.

div.p: GR. With the head, neck, back, ≈øcapulars, and ≈øome of the coverts of the wings, marked with narrow lines of black, a≈øh-color, and ru≈øt, intermixed with ≈øome white: wings and belly white: outmo≈øt feathers of the tail black; tho≈øe of the middle cinereous, mottled with black, and tipt with white. The male has a black ≈øpot between the bill and the eye; which in the female is ≈øcarcely vi≈øible. One which I weighed in Scotland was nineteen ounces. Another weighed by Mr. Ray, in the Gri≈øons country, only fourteen. It regularly changes its colors at approach of winter.

PLACE.Inhabits Greenland, Iceland, Lapland, all Scandinavia, and Ru≈ø≈øia; but I believe does not extend to Sibiria or Kamt≈øchatka. This, from its haunts, is called by the Norwegians, Fiaelde Rype, or Mountain Grous. But in Ru≈ø≈øia it inhabits indifferently woods, mountains, plains, and mar≈øhes. Its feathers were formerly an article of commerce. It is taken among the Laplanders, by the ≈øame ≈øtratagem as the WHITE GROUS, No 183.

The Greenlanders catch it in noo≈øes hung to a long line, drawn between two men, dropping them over the neck of this ≈øilly bird. They ≈øometimes kill it with ≈øtones; but of late oftener by ≈øhooting. It is ≈øaid, that when the female is killed the male unwillingly de≈øerts the bodyFaun. Groenl. p. 117. .

The Greenlanders eat it either dre≈ø≈øed, or half rotten, or raw, with ≈øeals lard. The inte≈øtines, e≈øpecially tho≈øe next to the rump, and fre≈øh drawn, are reckoned great delicacies. They al≈øo mix the contents with fre≈øh train-oil and berries; a luxury frequent among the≈øe people. The ≈økins make a warm and comfortable ≈øhirt, with the feathers placed next to the body. The women formerly u≈øed the black feathers of the tail as ornaments to their head-dre≈ø≈øes.

list.item: E. REHUSAK. Montin, in Act. Phy≈øiogr. Lund. i. 150.

div.p: GR. With neck ru≈øt-colored, ≈øpotted with black: back and coverts of tail black, varied with ru≈øty ≈øtreaks: brea≈øt divided from the lower part of the neck by a dark ≈øhade: re≈øt of the brea≈øt and vent white; the hen ≈øpotted with yellow: primaries white: tail black; end whiti≈øh: thighs white, with ≈øome ru≈øty ≈øpots: legs feathered to the toes: toes naked, covered with large brown ≈øcales. SIZE of a ≈ømall Hen.

Inhabits both the woods and alps of Lapland. PLACE. Lays thirteen or fourteen reddi≈øh eggs, marked with large brown ≈øpots. When di≈øturbed, flies away with a loud noi≈øe, like a coar≈øe laugh. The Keron, or common Ptarmigan, on the contrary, is ≈øilent. The Keron inhabits the Alps only.

list.item: F. HAZEL GR. Will. Orn. 175.
Tetrao bona≈øia. Hiarpe, Faun. Suec. No 204.

div.p: GR. With the chin black, bounded with white: head and upper part of the neck cro≈ø≈øed with du≈øky and cinereous lines: behind each eye a white line: coverts of wings and ≈øcapulars ≈øpotted with black and ru≈øt-color: brea≈øt and belly white, marked with bright bay ≈øpots: feathers of the tail mottled with a≈øh and black; and, except the two middlemo≈øt, cro≈ø≈øed with a broad ≈øingle bar of black: legs feathered half way down. FEMALE wants the black ≈øpot on the chin, and white ≈øtroke beyond the eyes.SIZE. Its ≈øize ≈øuperior to an Engli≈øh Partridge.

Inhabits the birch and hazel woods of many parts of Europe, PLACE. as high as the dioce≈øe of Drontheim, and even Lapland Scheffer Lapl. 138. ; and is not unfrequent in the temperate parts. Paul≈øen Catalogue of Iceland Birds, MS. ≈øays that it migrates into the ≈øouth of Iceland in April, and departs in September? It lays from twelve to twenty eggs: perches u≈øually in the mid≈øt of a tree: is attracted by a pipe, imitative of its voice, to the nets of the ≈øport≈ømen, who lie concealed in a hovelGe≈øner Av. 230. . Is excellent meat, in≈øomuch that the Hungarians call it T≈øcha≈øarmadar, or the bird of Cae≈øar, as if it was only fit for the table of the Emperor. Is found in mo≈øt parts of the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions with the Ptarmigan, but grows ≈øcarcer towards the ea≈øt of Sibiria.

div.head: 185. MARYLAND.

list.item: American Partridge, Clayton, Ph. Tr. abridg. iii. 590.‚ÄîLaw≈øon, 140.‚ÄîCate≈øby, App. plate xii.‚ÄîDu Pratz, ii. 86.
Tetrao Virginianus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 277.
Le Perdrix d'Amerique, Bri≈ø≈øon, i. 231.‚ÄîEt de la Nouvelle Angleterre, 229.‚ÄîDe Buffon, ii. 447.

div.p: P. With white cheeks and throat, bounded by a line of black on all ≈øides, and marked with another pa≈ø≈øing beneath each eye: brea≈øt whiti≈øh, prettily marked with ≈øemicircular ≈øpots of black: upper part of the brea≈øt, coverts of wings, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of tail, bright bay, edged with ≈ømall black and white ≈øpots; ≈øcapulars ≈øtriped with yellowi≈øh white: primaries and tail of a light a≈øh color.

The head of the female agrees in the white marks of the male, but the boundaries are ferruginous. There is al≈øo more red on the brea≈øt. In other re≈øpects the colors nearly corre≈øpond. In SIZE, above half as big again as the Engli≈øh Quail.

PLACE.Frequent from Canada to the mo≈øt ≈øouthern parts of North America, perhaps to Mexico. Are great breeders, and are ≈øeen in covies of four or five and twenty. Breed the latter end of April, or beginning of May. Collect, towards the beginning of June, in great flocks, and take to the orchards, where they perch when di≈øturbed. Feed much on buck-wheat; grow fat, and are excellent meat. Migrate from Nova Scotia, at approach of winter, to the ≈øouthern provinces; but numbers re≈øide in the latter the whole year. The males have a note twice repeated, which they emit, while the females are
≈øitting, u≈øually perched on a rail or gate. Make a va≈øt noi≈øe with the wings when they ari≈øe.

Of late they have been introduced into Jamaica; IN JAMAICA: are naturalized to the climate, and increa≈øe greatly in a wild ≈øtate; and, as I am informed, breed in that warm climate twice in the year.

list.item: A. COMMON PARTRIDGE. Tetrao Perdix. Rapphona. Faun. Suec. No 205.

div.p:
INHABITS as high as Sweden; but has not yet reached Norway
Brunnich, No 201.. Found in the we≈øt, and all the temperate parts of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, and even beyond lake Baikal, where it winters about ≈øteep rocky mountains expo≈øed to the ≈øun, and where the ≈ønow lies le≈øt.
During winter, in Sweden it burrows beneath the ≈ønow; and the whole covey retires there, leaving a ≈øpiracle at each end of their lodge.

list.item: B. QUAIL, Br. Zool. i. No 97.‚ÄîWachtel, Faun. Suec. No 206.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: IS found no further north than Sweden. It appears there in the beginning of the leafing month (May); and is neither heard or ≈øeen there in autumn or winter, unle≈øs it ≈øhould, as Linnaeus ≈øuppo≈øes, migrate to the ≈øouthern province, or Schonen, or retire to the Ukraine, Wallachia, &cAmoen. Acad. iv. 592. .

Quails ≈øwarm ≈øo greatly, at the time of their migration, about the Dnieper, and in the ≈øouth of Ru≈ø≈øia, that they are caught by thou≈øands, and ≈øent to Mo≈øcow and Peter≈øburgh in ca≈øks. They are common in all parts of Great Tartary; but in Sibiria only in the ≈øouth, as their pa≈ø≈øage is hindered by the lofty ≈ønowy mountains. It is ≈øaid they winter beneath the ≈ønow; and in great fro≈øts, to be found torpid in the Ant-hills. Beyond lake Baikal, the Quails exactly re≈øemble tho≈øe of Europe, but are quite mute. The≈øe are u≈øed by the Chine≈øe in fighting, as we do Cocks.

div.head: 186. NORTON SOUND.
div.p: I Am ≈øorry that I have it not in my power to do more than a≈øcertain that a bird of the BUSTARD genus is found in North America. Captain KING was ≈øo obliging as to inform me, that he ≈øaw on the plains near Norton Sound, N. lat. 64 ¬Ω, great flocks of a large kind. They were very ≈øhy; ran very fa≈øt, and for a con≈øiderable way before they took wing; ≈øo that he never could get one ≈øhot.
I often meet with the word Outarde, or Bu≈øtard, among the French voyagers in North America; but believe it to be always applied to a ≈øpecies of Goo≈øe.

The Great Bu≈øtard, Br. Zool. i. No 98, is frequent over all the de≈øert of Tartary, and beyond lake Baikal. Is a ≈øolitary bird; but collects into ≈ømall flocks at the time of its ≈øouthern migration, and winters about A≈øtracan Extracts, 143. .

list.item: ‚Ä¢ . LESSER BUSTARD, Br. Zool. i. No 99.

div.p: B. With crown, back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of the wings, ferruginous and black; primaries black at their ends, white at their bottoms; the ≈øecondaries quite white: neck black, marked near the top and bottom with a white circle: brea≈øt and belly white: middle feathers of the tail cro≈ø≈øed with ru≈øt and black, the re≈øt white. FEMALE entirely ferruginous and black, except wings and belly. SIZE of a Phea≈øant.

Appears in Sweden rarely in the ≈øpring: not traced further north.PLACE. Very frequent in the ≈øouthern and ≈øouth-we≈øt plains of Ru≈ø≈øia, and in ≈ømall flocks when it migrates. Continues a good way into the de≈øerts of Tartary; but is never ≈øeen in Sibiria.

div.head: 187. PASSENGER.

list.item: Pigeon, Jo≈ø≈øelyn's Voy. 99.
