div.p: P. With a black bill: red irides: head, and hind part and ≈øides of the neck, of a ≈ølaty blue; on each of the la≈øt a large ≈øhining golden ≈øpot: coverts of the wings of a dark bluei≈øh grey, marked with a few black ≈øpots: quil feathers brown: tail of a great length, and cuneiform: the middle feathers du≈øky grey, the next paler, the outmo≈øt white. WEIGHT nine ounces.

MANNERS.The≈øe birds vi≈øit the provinces of North America in mo≈øt amazing numbers every hard winter. They appear in greater or le≈ø≈øer numbers, according to the mildne≈øs or ≈øeverity of ≈øea≈øon; for when the weather proves mild, few or none are ≈øeen in the ≈øouthern parts. Nece≈ø≈øity alone obliges them to change their quarters, in ≈øearch of acorns,FOOD. ma≈øt, and berries, which the warmer provinces yield in va≈øt abundance. When they alight, the ground is ≈øoon cleared of all e≈øculent fruits, to the great lo≈øs of the hog, and other ma≈øt-eating animals. When they have devoured every thing which has fallen on the ≈øurface, they form them≈øelves into a great perpendical column, and by rotation keep flying among the boughs of the trees, from top to bottom, beating down the acorns with their wings, and ≈øome
or other, in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, alight on the earth and eatDu Pratz.. The ≈øpecies of food they are fonde≈øt of is the ≈ømall acorn, called the Turkey acorn, it being al≈øo a favorite food of tho≈øe birds. In Canada they do va≈øt damage in autumn, by devouring the corn, before they begin their ≈øouthern flightThe ≈øame..

They build their ne≈øts in trees,NESTS. and coo like the Engli≈øh Wild Pigeon; and lay two eggs. They breed in the more northern parts, from the country ≈øouth of Moo≈øe Fort, in Hud≈øon's Bay
Ph. Tr. lxii. 398., to that between Fort Frederick and Fort Anne, and the woods about the river Onandago Bartram's Journey to Onandago, 36.‚ÄîKalm's Travels, ii. 311. . During the time of incubation and nutrition, they feed fir≈øt on the ≈øeeds of the Acer Rubrum, Lin. ‚ÄîCate≈øby, i. 62. red maple, which ripens in May; and after that, on tho≈øe of the elmUlmus Americana, Lin. . It appears by tho≈øe accurate ob≈øervers, Mr. Bartram and Mr. Kalm, that they continue in their breeding-places till the middle at le≈øt of July: the fir≈øt having ≈øeen them in June; the la≈øt, the 19th of July. Mr. Hutchins a≈ø≈øures me, that they continue in the inland parts of Hud≈øon's Bay till December; and when the ground is covered with ≈ønow, feed on the buds of juniper.

As ≈øoon as the≈øe birds find a want of food,MIGRATIONS. they collect in va≈øt flocks, and migrate to ≈øuch places as are likely to ≈øupply them with ≈øub≈øi≈øtence.VAST NUMBERS. The multitudes which appear during the rigorous ≈øea≈øons are ≈øo immen≈øe, that the mention of them, unle≈øs ≈øupported by good authority, would ≈øeem incredible. They fly by millions in a flock; and in their pa≈ø≈øage literally intercept the light of the ≈øun for a con≈øiderable ≈øpace. As ≈øoon as one flock has pa≈ø≈øed, another ≈øucceeds, each taking a quarter of an hour before the whole flock is gone. This continues, in ≈øome ≈øea≈øons, for three days without any intermi≈ø≈øionCate≈øby..

The inhabitants of New York and Penn≈øylvania are frequent witne≈ø≈øes of the phaenomenon, and kill numbers of the≈øe migrants from
their balconies, and the roofs of their hou≈øes. When they alight on trees to roo≈øt, they often break the limbs of ≈øtout oaks, unable to ≈øupport the weight of the crowds which perch on them. The ground beneath the trees on which they have lodged a night, is covered with their dung to a con≈øiderable depth Law≈øon, 44.‚ÄîThe Rev. Mr. Burnaby relates the prodigious flights he ≈øaw pa≈ø≈øing in September, ≈øoutherly, over New England. He adds, he ≈øcarcely met with any other food in the inns he was at. p. 132..

Jo≈ø≈øelyn, who ob≈øerved the≈øe Pigeons in 1638, in New England, before they were di≈øturbed by population, ≈øays, he has ≈øeen flights of them moving at Michaelmas to the ≈øouthward, four or five miles long, ≈øo thick that he lo≈øt ≈øight of the ≈øun. He adds, that they return in ≈øpring;RETURN. and that they join ne≈øt to ne≈øt, and tree to tree, by their ne≈øts, for many miles together, in the woodsVoy. 99. . Kalm mentions their pa≈ø≈øage through Jer≈øey in March.

The inhabitants of North America profit by this kind gift of Providence, and ≈øhoot them in their pa≈ø≈øage; for they are very fat, and excellent meat. The Indians watch the roo≈øting-places; go in the night, and, knocking them down with long poles, bring away thou≈øands. Formerly, you could not go into a little Indian town, in the interior parts of Carolina, THEIR OIL. but you would find a hundred gallons of Pigeons oil or fat, which they u≈øe with their mayz, as we do butterLaw≈øon, 44. . They ≈øcorn to obtain that u≈øeful article from the quiet employ of the dairy; but are fond of the ≈øimilitude, provided it could be obtained by any means ≈øuitable to their active ≈øpirit.

M. du Pratz hit upon an ingenious expedient of taking them on roo≈øt, by placing under the trees ve≈ø≈øels filled with flaming ≈øulphur; the fumes of which a≈øcending, brought them ≈øen≈øele≈øs to the ground in perfect ≈øhowers.

I ≈øhall conclude this account with what was communicated to me by the late Mr. A≈øhton Blackburne, from his own ob≈øervations, or tho≈øe of his friends, who were eye-witne≈ø≈øes to the wondrous facts related of the≈øe birds.

body.p:
I think, ≈øays Mr. Blackburne, this as remarkable a bird as any in America. They are in va≈øt numbers in all parts, and have been of great ≈øervice at particular times to our garri≈øons, in ≈øupplying them with fre≈øh meat, e≈øpecially at the out-po≈øts. A friend told me, that in the year in which Quebec was taken, the whole army was ≈øupplied with them, if they cho≈øe it. The way was this: every man took his club (for they were forbid to u≈øe their firelocks) when they flew, as it was termed, in ≈øuch quantities, that each per≈øon could kill as many as he wanted. They in general begin to fly ≈øoon after day-break, and continue till nine or ten o'clock; and again about three in the afternoon, and continue till five or ≈øix: but what is very remarkable, they always fly we≈øterly. The times of flying here are in the ≈øpring, about the latter end of February or the beginning of March, and continue every day for eight or ten days; and again in the fall, when they begin the latter end of July or the beginning of Augu≈øt. They catch va≈øt quantities of them in clap-nets, with ≈øtale pigeons. I have ≈øeen them brought to this market by ≈øacks-full. People in general are very fond of them; and I have heard many ≈øay they think them as good as our common Blue Pigeon; but I cannot agree with them by any means. They ta≈øte more like our Quee≈øt, or Wild Pigeon; but are better meat. They have another way of killing them‚ÄîThey make a hut of boughs of trees, and ≈øix ≈øtale Pigeons on the ground at a ≈ømall di≈øtance from the hut. They plant poles for the Wild Pigeons to light on when they come a ≈øalting (as they term it) which they do every morning in the ≈øea≈øon, repairing to the mar≈øhes near the ≈øea-≈øide; then the per≈øons in the hut pull the ≈øtale Pigeon, when the birds will alight in va≈øt numbers on the poles, and great multitudes are ≈øhot. Sir William John≈øon told me, that he killed at one ≈øhot with a blunderbu≈øs, a hundred and twenty or thirty.
Some years pa≈øt they have not been in ≈øuch plenty as they u≈øed to be. This ≈øpring I ≈øaw them fly one morning, as I thought in great abundance; but every body was amazed how few there were; and wondered at the rea≈øon.

p.q: I mu≈øt remark one very ≈øingular fact: that, notwith≈øtanding the whole people of a town go out a pigeoning, as they call it, they will not on ≈øome days kill a ≈øingle hen bird; and on the very next day, not a ≈øingle cock (and yet both ≈øexes always fly we≈øterly); and when this is the ca≈øe, the people are always a≈ø≈øured that there will be great plenty of them that ≈øea≈øon. I have been at Niagara when the centinel has given the word that the Pigeons were flying; and the whole garri≈øon were ready to run over one another, ≈øo eager were they to get fre≈øh meat.

Inhabits Carolina the whole year; and is found as far ≈øouth as the We≈øt Indies and Bra≈øil. Feeds much on the berries of the poke or Phytolacca Decandria Phytolacca Decandria, Lin. Sp. Pl. 631., and the ≈øeeds of the mug-apple or Podophyllum

The French i≈ølanders call them Ortolans, from their exce≈ø≈øive fatne≈øs and great delicacy. They take them young, when they will become very tame.

THERE is not a ≈øingle ≈øpecies of Pigeon to be found in Kamt≈øchatka; a proof that the birds of this genus do not extend far to the north-we≈øt of America: otherwi≈øe the narrow ≈øea between the two continents could never confine birds of ≈øo ≈øwift and ≈øtrong a flight.

No Pigeons are ≈øeen in Sibiria, till you come beyond lake Baikal, where a very ≈ømall variety (with a white rump) breeds in great plenty about the rocks. None of the Pigeon tribe inhabit the arctic zone, by rea≈øon not only of the cold, but of defect of food.

div.p: WITH a ≈øpotted brea≈øt; probably a young bird of one of the others.

The≈øe birds ≈øhun the cold parts of America; PLACE. and are found from the province of New York as far ≈øouth as Mexico and the Antilles. They are ≈øo impatient of the rigorous ≈øea≈øon, as to retire at approach of winter from all the provinces north of Carolina or Virginia. In the fir≈øt they inhabit the whole year. They vi≈øit New York in April, or the beginning of May, but are rather ≈øcarce in that part of America: they breed there in June, and lay five or ≈øix blue eggs, thickly ≈øpotted with dull red.

They build often in fruit treesLaw≈øon.; are very familiar, and love to be conver≈øant about dwellings; and, during ≈øummer, u≈øually deliver
their ≈øong perched on the chimney's top. During breeding ≈øea≈øon, are very ≈øhy, and will de≈øert their ne≈øt if any one looks on the eggs Kalm, i. 218.: but are ≈øometimes pre≈øerved, and brought alive to England.

During ≈øummer they feed on berries, mulberries, and other fruits, and in≈øects. In winter, when other food is ≈øcarce, on the berries of the Dogwood Cornus Florida, Lin. Sp. Pl. . When tamed, feed on every thing.

VARIOUS SONG.The≈øe birds are perhaps the fir≈øt among the chori≈øters of the woods; and are ju≈øtly famed not only for the variety, fulne≈øs, and melody of their own notes, but their imitative faculty of the notes of all other birds or animals, from the Humming-bird to the Eagle. They will even imitate the ≈øound of other things. I have heard of one, confined in a cage, that would mimic the mewing of a cat, the chattering of a magype, and the creaking of a ≈øign in high winds. The Mexicans call them Cencontlatolli Fernandez, p. 20. , or the birds of four hundred tongues, on account of their va≈øt variety of notes and imitative powers. In the warmer parts of America they ≈øing ince≈ø≈øantly from March to Augu≈øt, day and night, beginning with their own compo≈øitions, and then fini≈øhing by borrowing from the whole feathered choir, and repeat their tunes with ≈øuch artful ≈øweetne≈øs, as to excite plea≈øure and ≈øurprize. The ≈øuper-excellence of their ≈øongs makes ample amends for the plainne≈øs of their plumage.

They may be ≈øaid not only to ≈øing, but dance: for, as if excited by a ≈øort of exta≈øy at their own admirable notes, they gradually rai≈øe them≈øelves from the place where they ≈øtand, with their wings extended, drop with their head down to the ≈øame ≈øpot, and whirl round with di≈øtended wings, accompanying their melody with variety of pretty ge≈øticulationsCate≈øby.. They are birds of va≈øt courage; and will attack any large bird.

Inhabits North America, from New York to Carolina. PLACE. In the former, arrives in May, and migrates to the ≈øouth in Augu≈øt: continues in Virginia and Carolina the whole year: builds in low bu≈øhes, and (in New York) breeds in June, and lays five white eggs, clo≈øely ≈øpotted with ru≈øt-colour.

It feeds on berries, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the clu≈øter bird-cherry, of which all the Thru≈øh kind are very fond. It is called in America the French Mocking-bird, from the variety of its notes; but they are far inferior to the real.

PLACE.Inhabits North America, from Hud≈øon's Bay to Natka Sound, on the we≈øtern coa≈øt; and ≈øouth as low as Carolina. Quits the warmer parts in the ≈øpring, and retires north to breed. At Moo≈øe Fort, the≈øe birds build their ne≈øt, lay their eggs, and hatch their young, in fourteen days; but at Severn ≈øettlement, which lies in 55, or four degrees more north, the ≈øame is not effected in le≈øs than twenty-≈øix daysPh. Tran≈øact. lxii. 399. . They are al≈øo very common in the woods near St. John's, in Newfoundland.

They arrive in New York in February, and lay their eggs in May, and quit the country in October: in each country where they pa≈øs the ≈øummer, they adapt their retreat to the time in which winter ≈øets in.

NESTS.They make their ne≈øts with roots, mo≈øs, &c.; and lay five eggs, of a mo≈øt lively ≈øea-green colour. The cock is mo≈øt a≈ø≈øiduous in a≈ø≈øi≈øting its mate in making the ne≈øt and feeding the young; and in the intervals chears her with its mu≈øical voice.

Like the Engli≈øh Fieldfare, they come and go in large flocks. They have two notes; one a loud ≈øcream, like the Mi≈ø≈øel-bird: the other, a very ≈øweet ≈øong, which it delivers from the ≈øummit of ≈øome lofty tree.

They feed on worms, in≈øects, and berries. Mr. Cate≈øby brings a proof, that it is not the heat of the ≈øea≈øon alone that forces them away. He had, in Virginia, ≈øome trees of the Aluternus, in full berry; the fir≈øt which were known in America: a ≈øingle Fieldfare was ≈øo delighted with them, as never to quit them during the whole ≈øummer.
They are called in America, the Robin; not only from the redne≈øs of the brea≈øt, but from their actions and tamene≈øs, as I have ob≈øerved in tho≈øe kept in aviaries.

PLACE.The≈øe birds ≈øwarm in the woods of Sweden and Norway: breed in the highe≈øt trees; and continue, at le≈øt in Sweden, the whole yearAmoen. Acad. iv. 594. . In Norway, I do not trace them further north than the dioce≈øe of
Bergen. They migrate in great numbers into Britain at Michaelmas, and depart about the beginning of March; but I have no certainty of the place they come from. They appear con≈øtantly in the Orknies, near the approach of winter, in their way ≈øouth, and feed during their re≈øidence in tho≈øe i≈øles on the berries of empetrum nigrum, arbutus alpina, and uva ur≈øi, and tho≈øe of the juniper. They arrive in England about Michaelmas, and leave it early in March. They are frequent in the fore≈øts of Ru≈ø≈øia, Sibiria, and even Kamt≈øchatka, as is the REDWING THRUSH. div.p:
B. With a ≈øhort yellow bill, tipt with black: crown tawny: neck of the ≈øame color: brea≈øt and belly of a dull yellow, declining into white towards the vent: back and ≈øcapulars black, edged with reddi≈øh brown: the coverts of the tail white on their lower, yellowi≈øh on their upper parts: on the wings is a large bed of white: the other parts black and reddi≈øh brown: tail a little
forked; three outmo≈øt feathers white; the third black, tipt with white; the re≈øt wholly black: legs black: hind claw long, but not ≈øo ≈øtrait as that of the Lark. WEIGHT one ounce five drams: LENGTH ≈øix inches and a half: EXTENT ten.

PLACE. HUDSON'S BAY.The earlie≈øt of the migratory birds of Hud≈øon's Bay. Appeared in 1771, at Severn ≈øettlement, on April 11th; ≈øtayed about a month or five weeks; then proceeded farther north to breedPhil. Tran≈ø. lxii. 403.. Return in September; ≈øtay till November, when the ≈øevere fro≈øts drive them ≈øouthward. Live in flocks: feed on gra≈øs ≈øeeds, and are conver≈øant about dunghills: are ea≈øily caught, under a ≈ømall net baited with oatmeal, and are very delicate meat. I am not certain of the winter retreat of the≈øe birds out of Hud≈øon's Bay; but having ≈øeen one of this ≈øpecies among tho≈øe ≈øent to Mrs. Blackburn from New York, I imagine that they ≈øpread over the more ≈øouthern parts of North America in the rigorous ≈øea≈øon, as they do over Europe in the ≈øame period.

CHANGE OF COLOR.The≈øe birds have a ≈øummer and a winter dre≈øs. The fir≈øt we have de≈øcribed. Again≈øt the rigorous ≈øea≈øon they become white on their head, neck, and whole under ≈øide: great part of their wings, and the rump, a≈ø≈øumes the ≈øame color: the back, and middle feathers of the tail, are black. But Linnaeus, who was very well acquainted with this ≈øpecies, ≈øays, that they vary according to age and ≈øea≈øon. Mr. Graham ≈øent to the Royal Society two ≈øpecimens; one in its ≈øummer feathers, which exactly an≈øwered to our TAWNY BUNTING, No 121; the other, to our SNOW BUNTING, No 122, in its winter feathers. On this evidence, I beg the readers of the Briti≈øh i≈øles to con≈øider the above as one and the ≈øame ≈øpecies.

GREENLAND. Hud≈øon's Bay is not the farthe≈øt of their northern migrations. They inhabit not only Greenland Crantz, i. 77. , but even the dreadful climate of Spitzbergen, where vegetation is nearly extinct, and ≈øcarcely any but cryptogamious plants are found. It therefore excites wonder, how
birds, which are graminivorous in every other than the≈øe fro≈øt-bound regions, ≈øub≈øi≈øt: yet are there found in great flocks, both on the land and ice of Spitzbergen Lord Mulgrave's Voy. 188.‚ÄîMarten's Voy. 73. . They annually pa≈øs to this country by way of Norway: for in the ≈øpring, flocks innumerable appear, e≈øpecially on the Norwegian i≈øles: continue only three weeks, and then at once di≈øappearLeems, 256. . As they do not breed in Hud≈øon's Bay, it is certain that many retreat to this la≈øt of lands, and totally uninhabited, to perform in full ≈øecurity the duties of love, incubation, and nutrition. That they breed in Spitzbergen is very probable; but we are a≈ø≈øured that they do ≈øo in Greenland. They arrive there in April, and make their ne≈øts in the fi≈ø≈øures of the rocks, on the mountains, in May: the out≈øide of their ne≈øt is gra≈øs; the middle of feathers; and the lining the down of the Arctic Fox. They lay five eggs, white, ≈øpotted with brown: they ≈øing finely near their ne≈øt.
They are caught by the boys in autumn, when they collect near the ≈øhores in great flocks in order to migrate; and are eaten driedFaun. Greenl. 118. .

In Europe they inhabit, during ≈øummer, the mo≈øt naked Lapland Alps; and de≈øcend, in rigorous ≈øea≈øons, into Sweden, and fill the roads and fields; on which account the Dalecarlians call them Illwarsfogel, or bad-weather birds. The Uplanders, Hardvarsfogel, expre≈ø≈øive of the ≈øame. The Laplanders ≈øtyle them Alaipg. Olaus Magnus ≈øpeaks of them under the name of Aviculae nivales De Gent. Septentr. lib. xix. p. 156. , but mixes much fable in his narrative: he perches them al≈øo on trees; whereas they always ≈øit upon the ground.

Leems Finmark, 255. remarks, I know not with what foundation, that they fatten on the flowing of the tides, in Finmark, and grow lean on the ebb. The Laplanders take them in great numbers in hair ≈øpringes, for the tables, their fle≈øh being very delicate.

They ≈øeem to make the countries within the whole arctic circle
their ≈øummer re≈øidence; from whence they overflow the more ≈øouthern countries in amazing multitudes, at the ≈øetting in of winter in the frigid zone. In the winter of 1778-9, they came in ≈øuch multitudes into Bir≈øa, one of the Orkney i≈ølands, as to cover the whole barony; yet, of all the numbers, hardly two agreed in colors.

NORTH OF BRITAIN. Lapland, and perhaps Iceland, furni≈øhes the north of Britain with the ≈øwarms that frequent tho≈øe parts during winter, as low as the Cheviot hills, in lat. 55. 32. Their re≈øting-places, the Feroe i≈øles, Schetland, and the Orknies. The highlands of Scotland, in particular, abound with them. Their flights are immen≈øe; and they mingle ≈øo clo≈øely together, in form of a ball, that the fowlers make great havock among them. They arrive lean, ≈øoon become very fat, and are delicious food. They either arrive in the highlands very early, or a few breed there; for I had one ≈øhot for me at Invercauld, the 4th of Augu≈øt. But there is a certainty of their migration, for multitudes of them often fall, wearied with their pa≈ø≈øage, on the ve≈ø≈øels that are ≈øailing through the Pentland Frith Bi≈øhop Pocock's Journal, MS..

In their ≈øummer dre≈øs they are ≈øometimes ≈øeen in the ≈øouth of England Morton's Northamp. 427. , the climate not having ≈øeverity ≈øufficient to affect the colors; yet now and then a milk-white one appears, which is u≈øually mi≈øtaken for a white Lark.

RUSSIA. SIBIRIA. Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria receive them, in their ≈øevere ≈øea≈øon, annually, in amazing flocks, overflowing almo≈øt all Ru≈ø≈øia. They frequent the villages, and yield a mo≈øt luxurious repa≈øt. They vary there infinitely in their winter colors; are pure white, ≈øpeckled, and even quite brownBell's Travels, i. 198. . This ≈øeems to be the influence of difference of age more than of ≈øea≈øon.
GERMANY. Germany has al≈øo its ≈øhare of them. In Au≈øtria they are caught, and fed with millet, and afford the epicure a treat equal to that of the Ortolan Kramer Anim. Au≈øtr. 372. .

div.p: B. With a white ≈øhort bill: blue eye: head, neck, wings, body, and tail, of a footy blackne≈øs, edged with ru≈øt: brea≈øt, belly, and vent, of a pure white: exterior ≈øides of the primaries edged with white; of the ≈øecondaries, with pale brown: exterior webs of the outmo≈øt feathers of the tail white: of the ≈øpecimen de≈øcribed in the Tran≈øactions, the two outmo≈øt are wholly white, and the third marked with a white ≈øpot; the re≈øt du≈øky. LENGTH ≈øix inches and a half: EXTENT nine: WEIGHT half an ounce.

Appears near Severn ≈øettlement not ≈øooner than June: PLACE. ≈øtays a fortnight: frequents the plains: feeds on gra≈øs ≈øeeds: retires into the arctic parts to breed. Returns to Hud≈øon's Bay in autumn, in its pa≈ø≈øage to the ≈øouth. Migrates into New York, where it continues the whole winter. Appears in the ≈øouthern provinces, as low as Carolina, but chiefly in ≈ønow, or when the weather is harder than ordinaryLaw≈øon, 146. . Arrive in millions, in very rigorous ≈øea≈øons, and fly about the hou≈øes and barns to pick up the corn. Frequent the gardens, and the ≈ømall hills, to feed on the ≈øcattered ≈øeeds of gra≈øs. Are called by the Swedes, Snovogel, or Snow-bird; by the Americans, Chuck-bird
Kalm, ii. 51, 81.. They do not change their colors in any ≈øea≈øon of the year. Are e≈øteemed very delicate meat.

LENGTH ≈øeven inches and a quarter.

Head, upper part of the neck, and back, of the FEMALE, yellowi≈øh brown, ≈øpotted with black: under part of a dull yellow: ≈øides thinly ≈øtreaked with black. The bird de≈øcribed by le Comte de Buffon, under the title of l'Agripenne de la Loui≈øiane Hi≈øt. d'Oi≈ø. iv. 339.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 388. fig. 2. , ≈øeems to be no other than a female of this ≈øpecies, varied by having ≈øome of the ≈øecondary feathers wholly white.

PLACE.The≈øe birds inhabit in va≈øt numbers the i≈øland of Cuba, where they commit great ravages among the early crops of rice, which precede tho≈øe of Carolina. As ≈øoon as the crops of that province are to their palate, they quit Cuba, and pa≈øs over the ≈øea, in numerous flights, directly north; and are very often heard in their pa≈ø≈øage by ≈øailors frequenting that cour≈øe. Their appearance is in
September, while the rice is yet milky; and commit ≈øuch deva≈øtations, that forty acres of that grain have been totally ruined by them in a ≈ømall time.

They arrive very lean; but ≈øoon grow ≈øo fat, as to fly with difficulty; and, when ≈øhot, often bur≈øt with the fall. They continue in Carolina not much above three weeks, and retire by the time the rice begins to harden. They are e≈øteemed to be the mo≈øt delicate birds of the country. I am informed, that the male birds have a fine note.

It is very ≈øingular, that, among the myriads which pay their autumnal vi≈øit, there never is found a ≈øingle cock-bird. Mr. Cate≈øby verified the fact by di≈ø≈øecting numbers, under a ≈øuppo≈øition, that there might have been the young of both ≈øexes, which had not arrived at the full colors; but found them all to be females, which are properly the RICE-BIRDS. Both ≈øexes make a tran≈øient vi≈øit to Carolina in the ≈øpring. It is ≈øaid, that a few ≈øtragglers continue in that country the whole year.

RICE, the periodical food of the≈øe birds, is a grain of India Raii Hi≈øt. Pl. ii. 1446. : it probably arrived in Europe (where it has been much cultivated) by way of Bactria, Su≈øia, Babylon, and the lower Syria
Strabo, lib. xv. p. 1014.. The time in which it reached Italy is uncertain: for the Oryza of Pliny is a very different plant from the common Rice; but the la≈øt has been ≈øown with great ≈øucce≈øs about Verona for ages pa≈øt; and was imported from thence, and from Egypt Ander≈øon's Dict. ii. 327. , into England; until, by a mere accident, it was introduced into Carolina. It was fir≈øt planted there about 1688, by Sir Nathaniel John≈øon, then governor of the province; but the ≈øeed being ≈ømall and bad, the culture made little progre≈øs.

Chance brought here, in 1696, a ve≈ø≈øel from Madaga≈øcar; the ma≈øter of which pre≈øented a Mr. Woodward with about half a bu≈øhel, of an excellent kindThe ≈øame, 238‚Äîand Cate≈øby, ii. Account of Carolina, xvii.; and from this ≈ømall beginning ≈øprung an
immen≈øe ≈øource of wealth to the ≈øouthern provinces of America; and to Europe relief from want in times of dearth. Within little more than half a century, a hundred and twenty thou≈øand barrels of Rice have been in one year exported from South Carolina; and eighteen thou≈øand American Traveller, 95, 101.‚ÄîIn a news-paper of la≈øt year, I met with the following article:‚ÄîA Gentleman died lately in Carolina, without any nearer relation than a third cou≈øin. He determined to leave his e≈øtate, con≈øi≈øting of three fine plantations, to ≈øome per≈øon who≈øe public de≈øerts would ju≈øtify ≈øuch a ≈øtep. The Gentleman, on con≈øideration, determined in favour of Mr. A≈øhby, a gentleman in the province, who≈øe ance≈øtor had introduced the culture of rice, by which Carolina had increa≈øed ≈øo amazingly in wealth, declaring at the ≈øame time in his will, that if there had been any living per≈øon to whom his country was equally obliged, in the ≈øame line of peace, he would have preferred him. Mr. A≈øhby, on his death, which happened lately, took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Gentleman's e≈øtate, in con≈øequence of this will.‚ÄîHow much more rational is ≈øuch a conduct, than endowing colleges or ho≈øpitals! from Georgia: and all from the remnant of a ≈øea ≈øtore, left in the bottom of a ≈øack!‚ÄîOught I not to retract the word chance, and a≈øcribe to PROVIDENCE ≈øo mighty an event from ≈øo ≈ømall a cau≈øe?

The≈øe are a ≈øouthern ≈øpecies; but ≈øometimes wander into Sweden, PLACE. in March. Breed, and quit the country in autumnAmoen. Acad. iv. 595. . Are common in Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, but not further than the Oby. Arrive in France with the SwallowsDe Buffon, iv. 309. . In Italy, about Padua, in May, and retire in September M. SCOPOLI'S Li≈øt of Italian birds, MS. with which he favored me.. I cannot trace their winter re≈øidence. They come rather lean. Make an artle≈øs ne≈øt: lay four or five greyi≈øh eggs: and u≈øually lay twice in the ≈øummer. The≈øe birds ≈øing prettily, and in the nightKram. Au≈øtr. 371. : but, by epicures, are valued more as a delicious mor≈øel, than for their ≈øong. They are taken and placed in a chamber lightened by lanthorns; ≈øo that, not knowing the vici≈ø≈øitudes of day and night, they are not agitated by the change. Are
fed with oats and millet; and grow ≈øo fat, that they would certainly die, if not killed in a critical minute. They are a mere lump of fat; of a mo≈øt exqui≈øite ta≈øte; but apt ≈øoon to ≈øatiate.

The≈øe birds receive both their Greek and their Latin name from their food, the millet. Ari≈øtotle calls them Cynchromi; and the Latins, Miliariae Ari≈øt. Hi≈øt. An. lib. viii. c. 12: and Varro de re Ru≈øt. lib. iii. c. 5.‚ÄîFicedulae et miliariae dictae √† cibo, quod alterae fico: alterae milio fiant pingues. Varro de Ling. Lat. iv. . The latter kept and fattened them in their ornithones, or fowl-yards, as the Italians do at pre≈øent; which the antients con≈øtructed with the utmo≈øt magnificence, as well as conveniencySee a plan in the Leip≈øic edition of Var. de re Ru≈øt, lib. iii. v..

Inhabits from New York to the Bra≈øils. PLACE. In New York it appears in May, and retires in Augu≈øt. Is a very ≈øhy bird, and lives in the deepe≈øt woods.

div.head: 238. OLIVE.
div.p:
T. With the head, whole upper part of the body, and coverts of the wings, of an olive green, fading into cinereous towards the rump: wings and tail brown, edged with white: throat and brea≈øt of a fine yellow: belly white: legs brown. Wings and tail
of the FEMALE du≈øky, edged with olive: under ≈øide of the body of a very pale yellow.

Arrives in New York in May: lays five eggs in June: PLACE. and migrates ≈øouthward in Augu≈øt. Appears in flights in winter, in Virginia and Carolina, and a≈ø≈øociates with the Redwing Orioles, and Purple Grakles. It delights much to feed about the pens of cattle; which gave occa≈øion to the name.

FEMALE wants the black mark on the head: whole upper part of an olive green; lower part of a pale yellow: in other marks the ≈øexes agree: on coverts of wings two bars of yellow.

The crown of the FEMALE wants the black: its colors al≈øo in general are le≈øs brilliant than tho≈øe of the male. Superior in ≈øize to the European kind; but ≈øeems only a variety.

Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay during ≈øummer.PLACE. Comes to Severn ≈øettlement in May. Advances farther north to breed; and returns in autumn, in its way ≈øouthward. Found al≈øo in Pen≈øylvania. No 128; but as I have had opportunity of ≈øeeing ≈øpecimens of this bird from Hud≈øon's Bay, Newfoundland, and New York BL. MUS., all of which agreed in marks and colors, I have no doubt but that it is a di≈øtinct ≈øpecies.

I have likewi≈øe de≈øcribed them from Newfoundland, where they are found during ≈øummer: one, which I ≈øuppo≈øe to be the female, had the yellow ≈øpot at the ba≈øe of the bill very ob≈øcure, nor had it the white ≈øpot on the chin.

A bird of a plain du≈øky ru≈øt-color above, and white beneath, ≈øpotted like the former, ≈øhot at Unala≈øcha, ≈øeems a variety.

LENGTH five inches: EXTENT ≈øeven: WEIGHT half an ounce.
A bird of a hardy con≈øtitution.PLACE. Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay during winter. Appears in November, and lives among the juniper bu≈øhes. Is called by the natives, Tecurma≈øhi≈øh.

It al≈øo inhabits Greenland, but continues there only in the ≈øummer. Makes an artle≈øs ne≈øt of mo≈øs and gra≈øs, lined with a few feathers; and lays in June five or ≈øix eggs, of a clay-color, clouded: departs earlyFauna Greenl. 119. . Is found in Lapland, in the Feroe i≈øles, the northern parts of Sibiria, and near the Urallian chain, where it breeds. Arrives in flocks, from the ≈øouth, and frequent the fields at the fir≈øt flowering of the Draba verna, or Whitlow-gra≈øs. Has nearly the note of a Linnet; but its flight is higher, and more la≈øting. It runs on the ground like a Lark: and feeds on ≈øeeds.

With the head, upper part of the body, wings, and tail, deep cinereous brown, edged with ob≈øcure ru≈øt-color: at the corner of the upper mandible is a light grey line; another bounds the cheeks beneath; and a du≈øky line bounds that: the throat is of a light grey: under ≈øide of the neck pale cinereous, marked with great du≈øky black ≈øpots: middle of the belly whiti≈øh: bill long: that and the legs du≈øky.

div.p: F. With body and tail du≈øky cinereous: chin white: brea≈øt and ≈øhoulders ferruginous: belly whiti≈øh: primaries du≈øky: on part of the wings two black lines, one ru≈øty, and a fourth white.
PLACE.Inhabits about Lulea, in We≈øt Bothnia.

list.item: C. TWITE, Br. Zool. i. No 133.

About the SIZE of the greater Red-headed Linnet.

PLACE.Is ≈øeen in northern Europe as high as Finmark Gran-Iri≈øk, Leems: well de≈øcribed, p. 256.. I di≈øcover it only in the Fauna of that country, of Sile≈øia Linaria Saxatilis. Stein-henffling, Schwenckfelt. Av. Sile≈øiae, 294., and of Great Britain. It flits in great numbers, in ≈øpring and fall, in the neighborhood of London, to and from its breeding place.

list.item: E. BRAMBLING, Br. Zool. i. No 126.

div.p: F. With head and back of a glo≈ø≈øy black, edged with dull yellow: brea≈øt, and le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings, orange: inner coverts rich yellow: primaries du≈øky; exterior ≈øides edged with yellow: tail a little forked; black, with the outmo≈øt webs of the outmo≈øt feather white.
Breeds in the woods of Nordland and Drontheim. PLACE. In hard winters de≈øcends into Ea≈øt Gothland Amoen. Acad. iv. 596. .

list.item: F. CHAFFINCH. Br. Zool. i. No 125.
Finke. Bofinke, Faun. Suec. No 232.‚ÄîDe Buffon, iv. 109.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 54.‚ÄîLatham, ii. 257.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: F. With the front black: crown bluei≈øh-grey: cheeks, throat, and brea≈øt, reddi≈øh: upper part of the back tawny; lower, green: wings and tail black, marked with white. FEMALE of duller colors: brea≈øt of a dirty white.

Is found as high as Drontheim. PLACE. Both ≈øexes continue in England the whole year. By admirable and unu≈øual in≈øtinct, in Sweden the females, to a bird, collect in va≈øt flocks at the latter end of September, de≈øert their mates, and, pa≈ø≈øing through Schonen, Denmark, Hol≈øtein, and Holland, vi≈øit ≈øeveral parts of Europe. They reach Holland about a fortnight after Michaelmas, and at that time afford great amu≈øement to the gentry at their country hou≈øes, in taking them while they ≈øit at tea in their pavilions. They ≈øpread nets among their plantations, and ≈øtrew the ground with hemp-≈øeed, by way of bait. The birds arrive, and perch by thou≈øands in the trees: then alight on the ground, hungry, and inattentive to the danger. The nets are clo≈øed by the pulling of a cord by the per≈øons in the pavilions; and
multitudes are thus taken. Tho≈øe which e≈øcape, continue their route to Flanders, France, and Italy. The males continue in Sweden, and enliven its rigorous winter with their chearful twitter. Towards ≈øpring, they receive additional ≈øpirits; perch on every tree, and animate with their notes every ≈øpray, expecting the arrival of ≈øpring, and of their mates. The la≈øt return invariably the beginning of April, in ≈øuch numbers as almo≈øt to darken the ≈økies; join their con≈øorts, perform their nuptials, retire to the woods, increa≈øe and multiplyAmoen. Acad. iv. 595. .

France has its re≈øident Chaffinches, as well as England: many al≈øo winter in Italy: many come there in April, and migrate in October M. Scopoli, MS. Li≈øt, & Av. 148. ; perhaps into Minorca, where it arrives in October, and continues in that i≈øland the whole winterCleghorn, 56. .

div.p: PLACE.INHABITS Europe in plenty as high as Drontheim Aves Nidr. Enum. MS. ; infe≈øts the corn, in the Orknies, by thou≈øands: is native among the rocks beyond lake Baikal; but it is ≈øaid, that they were unknown in the greate≈øt part of Sibiria before the Ru≈ø≈øians attracted them by the cultivation of corn. By a wonderful in≈øtinct, the≈øe and many other birds di≈øcover the effects of rural oeconomy, which draws various ≈øpecies, unknown before, from di≈øtant parts, to ≈øhare with mankind the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of grain or ≈øeeds which are grateful to them. Partridges keep pace with the ≈øpreading of corn over many parts of the earth, and appear where they were never ≈øeen before: and RICE-BIRDS quickly di≈øcovered the cultivation of rice in South Carolina, and come annually ≈øome hundreds of miles to feed on it.

This elegant bird is found as high as Sondmor Strom. 225. :PLACE. whether it goes farther north, is rather doubtfulGunner, in Leems, 256. . In Italy, appears in April: breeds; and retires in October and November. Is common in Ru≈ø≈øia, and the greate≈øt part of Sibiria. None beyond the Lena, and lake Baikal.

PLACE.This ≈øpecies appears in New York in April: lays five white eggs, ≈øpotted with ru≈øt-color: builds in low bu≈øhes: makes its ne≈øt with wool, and ≈øome mo≈øs, and lines it with ≈ømall fibres of roots: leaves the country in Augu≈øt: ob≈øerves the ≈øame time of migration in the ≈øouthern provinces. Mr. Cate≈øby gives ≈øo very good an account of its manners, and ≈øingular ≈øpirit, that I beg leave to expre≈øs it in his own words:‚ÄîThe courage of this little bird is ≈øingular. He pur≈øues and puts to flight all kinds of birds that come near his ≈øtation, from the ≈ømalle≈øt to the large≈øt, none e≈øcaping his fury; nor did I ever ≈øee any that dared to oppo≈øe him while flying, for he does not offer to attack them when ≈øitting. I have ≈øeen one of them fix on the back of an Eagle, and per≈øecute him ≈øo, that he has turned on his back into various po≈øtures in the air, in order to get rid of him; and at la≈øt was forced to alight on the top of the next tree, from whence he dared not to move, till the little Tyrant was tired, or thought fit to leave him. This is the con≈øtant practice of the cock, while the hen is brooding: he ≈øits on the top of a bu≈øh, or ≈ømall tree, not far from her ne≈øt; near which, if any ≈ømall birds approach, he drives them away; but the great ones, as Crows, Hawks, and Eagles, he won't ≈øuffer to come within a quarter of a mile of him without attacking them.
They have only a chattering note, which they utter with great vehemence all the time they are fighting.

p.q: When their young are flown, they are as peaceable as other birds. It has a tender bill; and feeds on in≈øects only. They are tame and harmle≈øs birds. They build their ne≈øt in an open manner, on low trees and ≈øhrubs, and u≈øually on the ≈øa≈ø≈øafras-tree.

country in Augu≈øt. They often ≈øtick clo≈øe to the chimney-wall by their feet, and ≈øupport them≈øelves by applying their ≈øharp tail to the ≈øides. They make all day a great thundering noi≈øe, by flying up and down the funnel.

It is remarkable, that three ≈øpecies of the American Swallows, in general ≈øeek the protection of hou≈øes for their places of building their ne≈øts, ovation, and nutrition; yet it is very certain, that before the arrival of the Europeans they mu≈øt have had recour≈øe to rocks or hollow trees for tho≈øe purpo≈øes; for the mi≈øerable hovels of the Indians had neither eaves for the u≈øes of the 331≈øt and 330th ≈øpecies, nor chimnies for that of the bird in que≈øtion. The two fir≈øt mu≈øt therefore have fixed their ne≈øt again≈øt the face of ≈øome precipice, as ≈øome of the Hou≈øe Swallows do at pre≈øent in America, and this ≈øpecies does about the ≈øteep rocks about Irkut≈øk in Sibiria. IN SIBIRIA. The in≈øtinct that directs part of this genus to fly to the protection of mankind, as ≈øoon as opportunity, unknown to preceding broods, offered, is as wonderful as it is inexplicable.

The Comte De Buffon mentions another of this ≈øpeciesvi. 700.,LOUISIANE. A VARIETY. which is found in Loui≈øiana. It differs only in the ≈øuperior length of the wings, from the bird I de≈øcribe: I therefore can con≈øider it but as a mere variety.

div.head: 336. SHORT-WINGED.

list.item: Goat≈øucker of Carolina, Cate≈øby, i. 8.
Ea≈øt India Bat, or Mu≈øqueto Hawk, Law≈øon, 144.
L'Engoulevent dela Caroline, De Buffon, vi. 532.‚ÄîLatham, ii. 592.

div.p: G. With the head, back, brea≈øt, and coverts of the wings, elegantly mottled with black and bright ru≈øt-color, and ≈øpotted with large ragged black marks: the ≈øcapulars of the ≈øame color, here and there ≈øpotted with white: on the lower part of the back is a mixture of a≈øh-color: primaries and ≈øecondaries mo≈øt beautifully varied with narrow bars of black and ferruginous; the four middle feathers of the tail barred and mottled with the ≈øame colors; as are the external webs of the three outmo≈øt on each ≈øide; but the inner webs of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs. Wings, when clo≈øed, reach little farther than half the length of the tail.SIZE. LENGTH twelve inches: EXTENT twenty-four.

PLACE.I received this ≈øpecies from Doctor GARDEN of Charle≈øtown, South Carolina; where it is called, from one of its notes, Chuck, Chuck Will's widow; and in the northern provinces, Whip poor Will, from the re≈øemblance which another of its notes bears to tho≈øe words. This, Mr. Kalm ≈øays, is the fancy of the Europeans; for the real ≈øound is like≈øt to Whipperiwhip, with a ≈øtrong accent on the fir≈øt and la≈øt ≈øyllable Kalm, ii. 152.. It begins its note about the time that the cherry-trees begin to blo≈ø≈øom, or near the 22d of April, in the Jer≈øies; probably ≈øooner in the ≈øouthern provinces. Mr. Blackburne ob≈øerved them fir≈øt,EGGS. in the province of New York, in May. Adds, that they lay two eggs on the bare ground; and that they will ≈øcarcely quit them on the neare≈øt approach. They di≈øappear in Augu≈øt.

FOOD.Their food is entirely in≈øects, which they catch night and morning, at the time in which they emit their ≈øong. They never ≈øettle
on high trees; but on bu≈øhes, rails, or the ≈øteps of hou≈øes, which they frequent, as in≈øects ≈øwarm more, near to habitations, than other places. They give their note ≈øitting: if they ≈øee an in≈øect pa≈øs, they fly up, catch it, and then ≈øettle again, and renew their ≈øong. Oft-times numbers perch near one another, make a va≈øt noi≈øe, repeating their ≈øong as if in emulation. They continue their call till it is quite dark: their note cea≈øes during night; but commences at the dawn, and is continued till the ≈øun ri≈øes, when they again de≈øi≈øt for the whole day Kalm, ii. 153.. I mu≈øt add, that, be≈øides the≈øe notes, it has that ≈øtrange ≈øound re≈øembling the turning of a great ≈øpinning-wheel; probably common to the whole genus Br. Zool. i. p. 352, 4to‚Äî417, 8vo..

They are extremely rare towards the ≈øea-≈øide; but ≈øwarm towards the mountains. Doctor Garden never got but this one. Mr. Clayton confirms their ≈øcarcity in the maritime parts of the provinces; and favors us with the following account of them.

p.q: I never heard but one in the maritime parts; though my abode has been always there; but near the mountains, within a few minutes after ≈øun-≈øet, they begin, and make ≈øo ≈øhrill and loud a noi≈øe, which the echoes from the rocks and ≈øides of the mountains increa≈øe to ≈øuch a degree, that the fir≈øt time I lodged there I could hardly get any ≈øleep. The ≈øhooting them in the night is very difficult; they never appearing in the day. Their cry is pretty much like the ≈øound of the pronunciation of the words Whip poor Will, with a kind of a chucking between every other, or every two or three cries; and they lay the accent upon the la≈øt word Will, and le≈øt of all upon the middle one.

The Indians ≈øay, the≈øe birds were never known till a great ma≈ø≈øacre was made of their country folks by the Engli≈øh, and that they are the departed ≈øpirits of the ma≈ø≈øacred Indians. Abundance of people here look upon them as birds of ill omen, and are very
melancholy if one lights on their hou≈øe or near their door, and ≈øets up its cry (as they will ≈øometimes upon the very thre≈øhold); for they verily believe one of the family will die very ≈øoon afterCate≈øby, App. 16. .

list.item: Whip poor Will, or le≈ø≈øer Goat≈øucker, Edw. 63.‚ÄîCate≈øby, App. 16.‚Äî Latham, ii. 595.

With the head and body du≈øky, mottled with white and pale ru≈øt-color: primaries black, marked near the middle with a white bar: under the throat is a white cre≈øcent, with the ends pointing upwards; brea≈øt barred with dirty white and du≈øky: tail black, marked regularly on each web with ≈øpots, mottled with black and white: near the ends of each feather is a large white ≈øpot, the ends quite black: wings, when clo≈øed, extend beyond the end of the tail. LENGTH nine inches and a half: EXTENT about twenty-three.

PLACE.Inhabits the ≈øame provinces with the former, and ≈øeems to have the ≈øame manners and notes; for, according to Doctor Garden, each are known in different places, by the name of Whip poor Will. It is found as far north as Henly Hou≈øe, a ≈øettlement for about a hundred miles up Albany river in Hud≈øon's Bay, where it is called the Mu≈øquets Hawk.

With head and back elegantly ≈øtreaked with narrow lines of black and grey, and with a few long oblong ≈øtrokes of black and ru≈øt: belly barred with black and grey: wings black; each web finely marked with ru≈øty ≈øpots: near the ends of the three fir≈øt primaries, a large oval white ≈øpot: tail du≈øky, with regular ≈øpots, mottled with ru≈øt and black; ends of the two fir≈øt feathers white. FEMALE wants the ≈øpots on the wings and tail.

It is found in Europe as far north as Sondmor, PLACE. and is common all over Sibiria and Kamt≈øchatka; and lives not only in fore≈øts,IN KAMTSCHATKA. but in open countries, where it finds rocks or high banks for ≈øhelter.

div.p: SP. B. Wholly white, with a pendent cre≈øt: legs and bill black: at the angles of the bill, on each cheek, a bright orange ≈øpot. From the end of the bill to end of the claws, forty inches. EXTENT fifty-two.

With a yellowi≈øh brown bill, ≈øerrated near the end: crown covered with a red ≈økin, thinly be≈øet with black bri≈øtles: from the bill, beneath each eye, extends a ≈øimilar ≈øtripe: on the hind part of the head a triangular black ≈øpot: quil feathers, and a few of the greater coverts, black: ≈øecondaries, and the whole plumage, of a pure white: webs of the tertials elegantly loo≈øe and unconnected, and, falling over the primaries, almo≈øt conceal them: legs and feet black and ≈øcaly. PLACE.Inhabits all parts of North America, from Florida to Hud≈øon's Bay. Is migratory: appears early in the ≈øpring about the Alatamaha, and other rivers near St. Augu≈øtine, and then quits the country in great numbers, and flies north in order to breed in ≈øecurity. They appear in ≈øummer in Hud≈øon's Bay, and return ≈øouthward with their young on approach of winter. They make a remarkable hooping noi≈øe: this makes me imagine the≈øe to have been the birds, who≈øe clamor Captain Philip Amidas (the fir≈øt Engli≈øhman who ever ≈øet foot on North America) ≈øo graphically de≈øcribes, on his landing on the i≈øle of Wokokou, off the coa≈øt of North Carolina: "WHEN," ≈øays he, ≈øuch a flock of Cranes (the mo≈øt part white) aro≈øe under us, with ≈øuch a cry, redoubled by many ecchoes, as if an armie of men had ≈øhowted all together. This was in the month of July Smith's Hi≈øt. Virgin. &c. 2. ; which proves, that in tho≈øe early days this ≈øpecies bred in the then de≈øert parts of the ≈øouthern provinces, till driven away by population, as was the ca≈øe with the common Crane in England; which abounded in our undrained fens, till cultivation forced them entirely to quit our kingdom.

They arrive in May about Severn river in Hud≈øon's Bay. Frequent lakes and ponds. Feed on fi≈øh and in≈øects. Hatch two young; and retire ≈øouthward in autumn

I mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that they formerly made a halt in the Hurons country, at the ≈øea≈øon in which the Indians ≈øet their maiz; and again on their return from the north, when the harve≈øt was ready, in order to feed on the grain. The Indians, at tho≈øe times, were u≈øed to ≈øhoot them with arrows headed with ≈øtone; for Theodat As quoted by De Buffon. , my authority, made his remarks in that country in the beginning of the la≈øt century.

div.p:
H. With a black, ≈øtrong, and thick bill: crown of a pale yellow: from the hind part i≈ø≈øue three or four long ≈ølender white feathers, erigible at plea≈øure; ≈øome are ≈øix inches long: a broad white ≈øtripe runs from the corner of the lower mandible as far as the ears: the re≈øt of the cheeks and head are of a bluei≈øh black: head, brea≈øt, belly, and coverts of wings, of a du≈øky blue: the primaries brown, tinged with blue: the back ≈øtriped with black, mixed with
white: from the upper part ari≈øe tufts of elegant ≈ølender ≈øilky feathers, falling beyond the tail: the legs and feet yellow. WEIGHT one pound and a half.

This ≈øpecies appears in Carolina in the rainy ≈øea≈øons:PLACE. but their native places are the Bahama i≈ølands, where they breed in amazing numbers, amid≈øt the bu≈øhes in the rocks. They are called by the i≈ølanders Crab-catchers, as they chiefly live on tho≈øe cru≈øtaceous animals. They are of great u≈øe to the inhabitants; who take the young birds before they can fly, and find them delicious eating. They ≈øwarm ≈øo on ≈øome of the rocky i≈øles, that two men, in a few hours, will fill a ≈ømall boat with them, taking them when perched on the rocks or bu≈øhes; for they will make no attempt to e≈øcape, notwith≈øtanding they are full grown.

div.head: 353. ASH-COLORED.
div.p: H. With a black ≈øtrong bill: crown du≈øky: cheeks and chin whiti≈øh: neck of a pale cinereous brown, ≈øtreaked before with white: back, wings, and tail, cinereous, clouded round each feather with du≈øky: feathers on the ≈øides of the back long and broad, hanging over the ends of the wings: belly white: legs yellowi≈øh. LENGTH two feet one inch.
Inhabits New York. Arrives there in May: breeds,PLACE. and leaves the country in October.‚ÄîBL. MUS.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.head: 354. STREAKED.
div.p: H. With a bill about two inches long: crown, back, and tail, of an uniform du≈øky color: hind part of the neck and cheeks ru≈øty and black: chin and throat white: fore part of the neck marked with ≈øtreaks of white and black: coverts of the wings, with ≈øtreaks of black and yellowi≈øh white: ridge of the wing white: primaries du≈øky.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

Another, in the ≈øame Mu≈øeum and ≈øame ca≈øe (probably differing only in ≈øex) has, from the lower mandible, a white line bounding the lower part of each cheek: the greater coverts of the wings and
≈øcapulars du≈øky, each feather tipt with white. In other re≈øpects it agrees with the former: the legs of each are greeni≈øh: the form of their bodies ≈ølender and elegant. LENGTH, from bill to the tip of the tail, about ≈øeventeen inches.
PLACE.Sent to Sir A≈øhton Lever from North America.

div.head: 355. GARDENIAN.

list.item: Le Pouacre de Cayenne? Pl. Enl. 939.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: H. With a du≈øky ≈øtrong bill: head, neck, brea≈øt, and belly, whiti≈øh, elegantly ≈øtreaked downwards with ≈øhort fine lines of black; the crown and hind part the darke≈øt: upper part of the back ≈øtreaked with white; the lower du≈øky and plain: the whole wing of the ≈øame color: the le≈ø≈øer coverts marked with ≈ømall yellowi≈øh ≈øpots; the greater coverts marked with a white ≈øpot at the end of each feather, forming, acro≈øs the wings, two rows: the primaries edged with dull white; the ends tipt with the ≈øame: tail du≈øky: legs of a deep dirty yellow. LENGTH about twenty-two inches.

PLACE.Doctor GARDEN, of South Carolina, favoured me with this bird. From the characteri≈øtic lines of white ≈øpots in the wings, I do not doubt but that the Brown Bittern of Cate≈øby, i. 78, is the ≈øame Al≈øo l'Etoile of De Buffon, vii. 428. with this: notwith≈øtanding, it would hardly be known, had he not pre≈øerved the ≈øpots in his very bad figure of it. He ≈øays it frequents ponds and rivers in the interior part of the country remote from the ≈øea.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.head: 356. NIGHT.

list.item: Ardea Nycticorax, Lin. Sy≈øt. 135.‚ÄîWill. Orn. 279.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Le Bihoreau. Le B. de Cayenne, De Buffon, vii. 435. 439. tab. xxii.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 758. 759. 899.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p:
H. With a black bill, crown, back, and ≈øcapulars; the la≈øt broad and long: forehead, cheeks, neck, and under ≈øide of the body, white: wings and tail of a very pale a≈øh-color: the hind part of the
head is mo≈øt ≈øpecifically di≈øtingui≈øhed by three very ≈ølender white feathers, five inches long, forming a pendent cre≈øt: legs of a yellowi≈øh green. The LENGTH, to the tip of the tail, one foot ≈øeven inches.

Inhabits New York; and a variety is found as low as Cayenne. PLACE. Is common to Europe. Is frequent in the ≈øouthern parts of the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions; but does not extend farther than lat. 53. It mu≈øt not at this time be ≈øought for in the wood near Sevenhuys in Holland, ≈øo noted in the days of Mr. Willughby for the va≈øt rendezvous of Shags, Herons, Spoon-bills, and the≈øe birds, be≈øides Ravens, Woodpigeons, and TurtlesRay's Travels, i. 33. , it being now cut down. When Mr. Willughby vi≈øited the place it was rented, for the birds and gra≈øs, for three thou≈øand gilders a year.

This bird is not the Nycticorax of the Antients; which was ≈øome rapacious fowl, probably of the Owl kind. It is the Nacht-rab, or Night-Raven of the Germans; ≈øo called from its nocturnal cry, re≈øembling the ≈øtraining of a per≈øon to vomit.

div.head: 357. BITTERN.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 174.‚ÄîArdea Stellaris. Rordrum, Faun. Suec. No 164.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Bittern from Hud≈øon's Bay, Edw. 136.‚ÄîLe Butor, De Buffon, vii. 411. 430.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 789.‚ÄîLEV. MUS‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: H. With the upper mandible du≈øky; lower yellow: feathers on the crown black and long; on the cheeks tawny; on the throat white: hind part of the neck browni≈øh red; fore part white, beautifully marked with ≈øhort ≈øtripes of red, bounded on each ≈øide with one of black: feathers on the brea≈øt very long: the belly of the colors of the fore part of the neck: back, coverts of wings, and the tail, are ferruginous, traver≈øed with du≈øky lines: primaries black: legs yellowi≈øh green. Rather inferior in SIZE to the European Bittern; but ≈øo like, as not to merit ≈øeparation.

PLACE.It inhabits from Hud≈øon's Bay to Carolina Law≈øon, 148. . In the former, it appears the latter end of May: lives among ≈øwamps and willows: lays two eggs. Like the European ≈øpecies, is very indolent; and, when di≈øturbed, takes but a ≈øhort flightPh. Tran≈ø. lxii. 410. .

That of the old continent is found in Ru≈ø≈øia; and, in A≈øia, in Sibiria, as far north as the river Lena, and is continued con≈øiderably to the north. Inhabits Sweden Faun. Suec. No 164. ; but, with all the other Herons, di≈øappears at approach of winterAmoen. Acad. iv. 588. .

The ≈øecond ≈øpecies of Bittern, mentioned by Law≈øon, p. 148. as being le≈ø≈øer than the former, with a great topping, of a deep brown color, and a yellowi≈øh white throat and brea≈øt, is at pre≈øent unknown to us.

div.head: 358. RUSTY-CROWNED.
div.p: H. With yellow irides: very ≈ømall cre≈øt: the bill ≈øeven inches long, ≈ølender, and of the ≈øame color with the former: forehead du≈øky: throat white: cre≈øt and hind part of the neck of a deep ferruginous color: the fore part of the neck marked with four rows of black ≈øpots: the feathers towards the brea≈øt long: a dark line pa≈ø≈øes from the brea≈øt upwards to the back of the neck: the upper part of the body, and coverts of the wings, deep ferruginous, marked with a few large black ≈øpots: primaries du≈øky: tail ≈øhort, and of a lead color: belly and brea≈øt of a dirty white, ≈øtriped with black: legs of a dirty yellow. The cre≈øt on the head is very ≈ømall, and the feathers lie univer≈øally ≈ømooth. SIZE of the European Bittern.
PLACE.Inhabits North America; the province unknown. De≈øcribed from a live bird at Am≈øterdam.‚ÄîLEV. MUS?‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.head: 359. LITTLE.

list.item: Little Bittern, Br. Zool. ii. App. No x. tab. viii.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 323.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Ardea Minuta, Lin. Sy≈øt. 240.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: H. With a ≈ømooth head: crown black: hind part of the neck and cheeks ferruginous: coverts on the ridge of the wing, and ends of the greater, of a bright bay; the re≈øt of the coverts of a very pale clay color: primaries and ≈øecondaries du≈øky, with ferruginous tips: lower ≈øide of the neck and belly of a yellowi≈øh white: brea≈øt cro≈ø≈øed with a band of black: tail black: legs of a du≈øky green. LENGTH, to the end of the tail, fifteen inches. The body narrow: neck very long.
Inhabits from New York to South Carolina, PLACE. and many parts of Europe. Extends to, and perhaps winters in Jamaica. Its eggs are of a ≈øea-green color.

list.item: A. COMMON CRANE, Br. Zool. ii. App. No vi.‚ÄîArdea Grus, Trana, Faun. Suec. No 161. ‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLa Grue, De Buffon, vii. 286. tab. xiv.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 769. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: H. With a bald crown: fore part of the neck black: primaries black: a large tuft of elegant unwebbed curling feathers ≈øpringing from one pinion of each wing: tho≈øe, and all the re≈øt of the plumage, cinereous. LENGTH ≈øix feet. WEIGHT about ten pounds.

Cranes arrive in Sweden in great flocks in the ≈øpring ≈øea≈øon; pair,PLACE. and di≈øper≈øe over the whole country; and u≈øually re≈øort to breed to the very ≈øame places which they had u≈øed for many years pa≈øtAmoen, Acad. iv. 588. .
No augural attention is paid to them there; yet He≈øiod directs the Grecian farmer to think of ploughing whenever he hears the annual clamor of the Cranes in the clouds
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . II. v. 66..

PLACE.Inhabits all Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, even as far ea≈øt as the river Anadyr; and migrates even to the Arctic circle. None ≈øeen in Kamt≈øchatka, except on the very ≈øouthern promontory, which they probably make a re≈øting-place, on their re-migration; Kamt≈øchatka being de≈øtitute of ≈øerpents and frogs, on which they feed in countries where corn is unknown. They lay two bluei≈øh eggs on the ru≈øhy ground: the young are hatched late; and as ≈øoon as they can fly attend their parents in their ≈øouthern migration: Poturae te, Nile, GRUES. For Egypt is generally ≈øuppo≈øed to be the great winter quarters of the≈øe birds. Previous to their retreat, they a≈ø≈øemble in amazing numbers, choo≈øe their leader, ≈øoar to a con≈øiderable height, and then, with continued clamor, proceed to their de≈øigned place. Milton, when he touches on this wonderful in≈øtinct of nature, de≈øcribes their progre≈øs with equal truth and elegance.

q.l: Part loo≈øely wing the region: part more wi≈øe,
In common, rang'd in figure () wedge their way,
Intelligent of ≈øea≈øons, and ≈øet forth
Their aery caravan, high over ≈øeas
Flying, and over lands with mutual wing
Ea≈øing their flight. So ≈øteers the prudent CRANE
Her annual voyage, borne on winds;
The air flotes as they pa≈øs, fann'd with unnumber'd plumes.

list.item: B. SIBIRIAN CRANE. Grus Leucogeranos, Pallas Itin. ii. 714.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: H. With a red bill like the former, ≈øerrated near the end: face naked beyond the eyes: coverts and primaries black: all the re≈øt of the bird of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs: legs red. Its HEIGHT is four feet and a half.

Inhabits the va≈øt mora≈ø≈øes of Sibiria, PLACE. and every part where lakes abound; and penetrates far north into the boggy fore≈øts about the I≈øchim, Irti≈øh, and Oby. Makes its ne≈øt among the inacce≈ø≈øible reeds, with layers of plants. Lays two great grey eggs, ≈øtreaked with numerous du≈øky lines. Makes a clamorous noi≈øe, and that frequently, e≈øpecially during its flight. Feeds on ≈ømall fi≈øh, frogs, and lizards. Winters u≈øually about the Ca≈øpian ≈øea. Ob≈øerved to migrate in ≈øpring northward along the cour≈øe of the Wolga, always in pairsExtracts, ii. 146. .

list.item: C. WHITE STORK. Ardea Ciconia. Storck, Faun. Suec. No 162.‚ÄîLa Cigogne, De Buffon, vii. 253.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 866.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: H. With red bill and legs: primaries black: the re≈øt of the plumage white: ≈økin of the color of blood. Larger than the common Heron.

Inhabits mo≈øt parts of Europe, except England. PLACE. In the we≈øt of Ru≈ø≈øia, is not found beyond 50 degrees north, nor to the ea≈øt of Mo≈øcow. It appears in Sweden in April; retires in Augu≈øt Amoen. Acad. iv. 588. : does not reach Norway, unle≈øs tempe≈øt-driven.

This ≈øpecies is ≈øemi-dome≈øtic: haunts towns and cities; and in many places ≈øtalks unconcerned about the ≈øtreets, in ≈øearch of offals and other food. Removes the noxious filth, and clears the fields of ≈øerpents and reptiles. They are, on that account, protected in Holland; held in high veneration by the Mahomedans; and ≈øo greatly
re≈øpected were they in old times by the The≈ø≈øalians, that to kill one of the≈øe birds was a crime expiable only by death Pliny, lib. x. c. 23..

The Storks ob≈øerve great exactne≈øs in the time of their autumnal departure from Europe to more favorable climates. They pa≈øs a ≈øecond ≈øummer in Egypt, and the mar≈øhes of Barbary Shaw's Trav. 428. : in the fir≈øt they pair, and lay again, and educate a ≈øecond broodBelon Oy≈ø. 201. . Before each of their migrations they rendezvous in amazing numbers; are for a while much in motion among them≈øelves; and after making ≈øeveral ≈øhort flights, as if to try their wings, all of a ≈øudden take flight with great ≈øilence, and with ≈øuch ≈øpeed, as in a moment to attain ≈øo great a height as to be in≈øtantaneou≈øly out of ≈øight. The beautiful and faithful de≈øcription which the NATURALIST'S POET THOMSON. gives of this annual event, ought not by any means to be omitted.

q.l: Where the Rhine lo≈øes his maje≈øtic force
In Belgian plains, won from the raging deep
By diligence amazing, and the ≈øtrong
Unconquerable hand of Liberty,
THE STORK-ASSEMBLY meets; for many a day
Con≈øulting deep and various, ere they take
Their arduous voyage thro' the liquid ≈øky.
And now, their route de≈øign'd, their leaders cho≈øe,
Their tribes adju≈øted, clean'd their vigorous wings;
And many a circle, many a ≈øhort e≈ø≈øay,
Wheel'd round and round, in congregation full
The figur'd flight a≈øcends, and riding high
The aerial billows, mixes with the clouds.

list.item: D. BLACK STORK. Ardea nigra. Oden≈øwala, Faun. Suec. No 163.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
La Cigogne noire, De Buffon, vii. 271.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 399.

div.p: H. With the bill, legs, and ≈økin, red: head, neck, body, and wings, black, glo≈ø≈øed with blue: brea≈øt and belly white. About the SIZE of the former.

Inhabits many parts of Europe. PLACE. It is not uncommon in the temperate parts of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, as far as the Lena, where lakes and mora≈ø≈øes abound. Migrates to warmer countries in autumn. Is a ≈øolitary ≈øpecies. Preys on fi≈øh, which it not only wades for, but, after hovering over the waters, will ≈øuddenly plunge on its prey. It al≈øo eats beetles and other in≈øects. Perches on trees: and builds its ne≈øt in the depths of fore≈øts.

The≈øe birds pa≈øs over Sweden in the ≈øpring in va≈øt flocks, flying towards the extreme north. They ≈øometimes re≈øt in the moors at night; but it is reckoned a wonder, if any one is found to make its ne≈øt in the country. They return ≈øouthward in autumn; but, in both their pa≈ø≈øages, ≈øoar ≈øo high as to appear ≈ømall as ≈øparrowsAmoen. Acad. iv. 589. .

div.head: 360. WOOD.

list.item: Wood Pelecan, Cate≈øby, i. 81.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Curicaca, Marcgrave, 191.‚ÄîDe Buffon, vii. 276.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 868.‚ÄîBri≈ø≈øon, v. 335.

div.p: I. With a bill near ten inches long; near ≈øeven in girth at the ba≈øe; ≈øtrait till near the end, where it bends downwards: fore part of the head and face covered with a bare du≈øky blue ≈økin: hind part of the head, and the whole neck, of a pale yellowi≈øh brown: under the chin is a pouch capable of containing half a pint: the greater primaries, and ≈øome of the greater coverts, are black glo≈ø≈øed with green; the re≈øt of the wing, back, and belly, white: tail ≈øquare, ≈øhort, and black: legs very long, black, and ≈øemi-palmated. The body of the SIZE of a Goo≈øe.

PLACE.Appears in Carolina, at the latter end of ≈øummer, during the great rains, when they frequent the overflown ≈øavannas in va≈øt flocks; but retire in November. They perch erect on tall cypre≈øs and other trees, and re≈øt their mon≈øtrous bills on their brea≈øts for their greater ea≈øe. They are very ≈øtupid and void of fear, and ea≈øily ≈øhot. Fly ≈ølowly. Their food is herbs, fruits and ≈øeeds, fi≈øh, and water in≈øects; notwith≈øtanding which they are excellent eating.
The re≈øidence of the≈øe birds, the re≈øt of the year, is Bra≈øil, Guiana Des Marchais, iii. 326. , and perhaps other parts of South America.

div.head: 361. SCARLET.

list.item: Guara, Marcgrave, 203.‚ÄîDe Buffon, vii. 35.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 81.

div.p: I. With a ≈ølender incurvated bill, and naked ≈økin on the face, both of a pale red color: the whole plumage of the riche≈øt ≈øcarlet, only the ends of the wings are black: legs pale red. In SIZE ≈øomewhat larger than the Engli≈øh CURLEW.

Frequent the coa≈øts of the Bahama i≈ølands.PLACE. Are common in Ea≈øt Florida: in Georgia are frequent in the months of July and Augu≈øt, after which they retire ≈øouthward. A few are ≈øeen in the ≈øouth of Carolina, and the parts of America within the tropics, and very ≈øeldom to the north. The≈øe birds perch, like the former, upon trees, and make a mo≈øt re≈øplendent appearance. They lay their eggs in the tall gra≈øs. When fir≈øt hatched, the young are of a du≈øky color: their fir≈øt change is to a≈øh-color; then to white; and, in their ≈øecond year, to columbine; and with age acquire their brilliant red. In Guiana it is often dome≈øticated, ≈øo as never to leave the poultry yard. It ≈øhews great courage in attacking the fowls, and will even oppo≈øe it≈øelf to the cat. The fle≈øh is e≈øteemed excellent. Its rich plumage is u≈øed by the Bra≈øilians for various ornaments.

div.head: 362. BROWN.

list.item: Brown Curlew, Cate≈øby, i. 83.‚ÄîDe Buffon, vii. 42.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: I. With the bill ≈øix inches and a half long, re≈øembling the former: bill, face, and legs, red: neck, upper part of the back, and tail, of a cinereous brown: lower part of the back, brea≈øt, and belly, white.

div.head: 363. WHITE.

list.item: White Curlew, Cate≈øby, i. 82.‚ÄîDe Buffon, vii. 41.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 915.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

The≈øe birds arrive in South Carolina, PLACE. with the Wood Ibis and the Brown Curlew, in great numbers, in September, and frequent the low watery tracts: continue there about ≈øix weeks, and then retire ≈øouth to breed. This ≈øpecies goes away with egg. There was a ≈øu≈øpicion, that the BROWN and the WHITE differed only in ≈øex; but experiment proved the contrary. The white kind are twenty
times more numerous than the others; the fle≈øh of the latter al≈øo differs, being of a dark color.
All the≈øe ≈øpecies frequent the ≈øides of rivers, and feed on ≈ømall fi≈øh, cru≈øtaceous animals, and in≈øects.

list.item: A. BAY IBIS. Tantalus Falcinellus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 241.‚ÄîMuller, No 178.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: I. With a black face: violet-colored wings and tail: blue legs.
In≈øerted here on the authority of Mr. Muller; but this ≈øpecies has hitherto been known only to ≈øouthern Europe, and about the Ca≈øpian and Black Seas.

div.head: 364. ESKIMAUX.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 177.‚ÄîE≈økimaux Curlew, Faun. Am.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: C. With a du≈øky bill, near three inches long: crown of a deep brown, divided lengthways by a white ≈øtripe: cheeks, neck, and brea≈øt, of a very pale brown, marked with ≈ømall du≈øky ≈øtreaks, pointing down the back: ≈øcapulars and coverts ≈øpotted with black and pale reddi≈øh brown: primaries du≈øky; ≈øhafts white; inner webs marked with red oval ≈øpots: tail barred with black and light brown: legs blue. Larger than the Engli≈øh WHIMBREL, of which it is a variety; and differs only in having its back brown in≈øtead of white.

Were ≈øeen in flocks innumerable, on the hills about Chateaux Bay, PLACE. on the Labrador coa≈øt, from Augu≈øt the 9th to September 6th, when they all di≈øappeared, being on the way from their northern breeding-place. They kept on the open grounds, fed on the empetrum nigrum, and were very fat and delicious. They arrive in Hud≈øon's Bay in April or the beginning of May: pair and breed to the north of Albany Fort, among the woods: return in Augu≈øt to the mar≈øhes; and all di≈øappear in September
Ph. Tran≈ø. lxii. 411. where it is called the E≈økimaux Curlew..

list.item: A. CURLEW, Br. Zool. ii. No 176.‚ÄîScolopax arquata, Faun. Suec. No 168.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Le Courlis, De Buffon, viii. 19.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 818.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: C. With an incurvated bill, ≈øeven inches long: head, and upper part of the wings, pale brown, ≈øpotted with black: back white: tail white, barred with black: legs bluei≈øh. WEIGHT from twenty-two to thirty-≈øeven ounces.
PLACE.Inhabits Europe, as high as Lapmark Leems, 249. and Iceland Brunnich, p. 49. ; and is found on the va≈øt plains of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria, quite to Kamt≈øchatka.

list.item: B. WHIMBREL, Br. Zool. ii. No 177.‚ÄîScolopax Phaeopus. Wind≈øpole. Spof. Faun. Suec. No 169.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Le Courlieu, ou petit Courlis, De Buffon, viii. 27.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 842.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: C. With a bill near three inches long: head marked lengthways by a whiti≈øh line, bounded on each ≈øide by one of black: neck, coverts of wings, and upper part of the back, pale brown, ≈øpotted with black: lower part of the back and the belly white: tail light brown, barred with black: legs bluei≈øh grey. WEIGHT twelve ounces.
PLACE.Inhabits the ≈øame places with the former.

Eskimaux Curlew No. 364. Little Woodcock No
‚Ä¢

div.head: 365. LITTLE WOODCOCK.
div.p: SN. With the upper mandible of the bill two inches and a half long; the lower much ≈øhorter: forehead cinereous; hind part black, with four tran≈øver≈øe yellowi≈øh bars: from bill to the eye a du≈øky line: chin white: under ≈øide of the neck, brea≈øt, belly, and thighs, of a dull yellow, pale≈øt on the belly: hind part of the neck black, edged with yellowi≈øh red: back, and le≈ø≈øer coverts, of the ≈øame colors; re≈øt of the coverts marked with zigzags of black and dull red: primaries du≈øky: inner coverts ru≈øt-colored: tail black, tipped with brown: legs ≈øhort, pale brown. LENGTH, from tip of the bill to the end of the tail, eleven inches and a half.

This ≈øpecies has entirely the form of the European Woodcock;PLACE. but differs in ≈øize and color. They appear in the province of New York in the latter end of April, or beginning of May. They lay, the latter end of the la≈øt month or beginning of June, from eight to ten eggs? and u≈øually in ≈øwampy places. Mr. Law≈øon P. 44. found them in Carolina in September. He prefers them, in point of delicacy, to the European kind.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.head: 366. COMMON SNIPE.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 187.‚ÄîScolopax gallinago, Hor≈øgjok, Faun. Suec. No 173.‚Äî Latham, iii.
La Beca≈ø≈øine, De Buffon, vii. 483.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 883.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: SN. With head divided lengthways with two black lines, and three of reddi≈øh brown: throat white: neck mottled with brown and te≈øtaceous: ridge of the wing du≈øky: greater coverts and primaries du≈øky, tipt with white: belly white: lower half of the tail black; upper orange, with two du≈øky ≈øtripes: toes divided to the origin. The American is le≈ø≈øer than the Briti≈øh.

PLACE.Inhabits Europe as far as Iceland: extends even to Greenland Faun. Greenl. No 71. ; and common in all parts of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria. Is found all over North America, and ≈øwarms in South Carolina. The lines on the head are le≈øs di≈øtinct in the American kind: the bill is al≈øo ≈øhorter than that of the Engli≈øh.

div.head: 367. JACK.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 189.‚ÄîPetite Beca≈ø≈øine, ou le Sourde, De Buffon, vii. 490. ‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: SN. With crown of the head black, tinged with ru≈øt: a yellow ≈øtroke over each eye: neck mottled with white, brown, and te≈øtaceous: rump of a glo≈ø≈øy purpli≈øh blue: tail brown, edged with tawny. WEIGHT under two ounces.
PLACE.The≈øe two inhabit Europe, North America, and Sibiria.

div.head: 368. RED-BREASTED SNIPE.

With a bill like the common kind, two inches one-eighth long: head, neck, and ≈øcapulars, varied with black, a≈øh-color, and red: under ≈øide of the neck and brea≈øt ferruginous, thinly ≈øpotted with black: coverts and ≈øecondaries dark cinereous; the la≈øt tipt with white: back and rump white, concealed by the ≈øcapulars: tail barred with du≈øky and white: legs dark green: middle and outmo≈øt toe connected by a ≈ømall web. SIZE of the Engli≈øh Snipe.
PLACE.Inhabits the coa≈øt of New York.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.head: 369. BROWN.
div.p:
SN. With a bill like the former: from that to each eye a white bar: head, neck, and ≈øcapulars, of a fine uniform cinereous brown, in a very few places marked with black: coverts and primaries dark brown; ≈øhaft of the fir≈øt primary white: ≈øecondaries light brown, edged with white: back white: rump and tail barred
with black and white: brea≈øt mottled with brown and white: belly white: legs and toes like the former. Its SIZE the ≈øame.‚ÄîBL. MUS.
Inhabits the ≈øame place.PLACE.

div.head: 370. NODDING.
div.p: SN. With the bill very ≈ølender, long, and black: the crown, and upper part of the back, du≈øky, ≈øtreaked with red: cheeks cinereous, ≈øtreaked with black: neck and brea≈øt cinereous, mixed with ru≈øt-color, and marked ob≈øcurely with dark ≈øpots: belly white: thighs ≈øpotted with black: le≈ø≈øer coverts of wings a≈øh-colored; greater du≈øky, edged with brown: primaries and ≈øecondaries du≈øky; the la≈øt tipt with white: lower part of the back white, ≈øpotted with black: tail barred with black and white; tips reddi≈øh: legs greeni≈øh: the toes bordered by a narrow plain membrane. SIZE of the Engli≈øh Snipe.
Ob≈øerved in Chateaux Bay, on the coa≈øt of Labrador, in September. PLACE. Are perpetually nodding their heads.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

list.item: Edw. 137.‚ÄîScolopax Fedo ‚Ä¢ , Lin. Sy≈øt. 244.‚ÄîLa Barge rou≈ø≈øe de Baie de Hud≈øon, De Buffon, vii. 507.‚ÄîLatham, iii.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

With a bill three inches three quarters long, reflecting a little upward; yellow near the ba≈øe; du≈øky towards the end: head, neck, brea≈øt, and upper part of the back, ferruginous, and ≈øtreaked with black, excepting the neck, which is plain: lower part of the back white: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings cinereous brown: exterior webs of the primaries black; the lower parts white: the lower part of the tail white; the upper black; the tips white: the legs du≈øky. PLACE.Is common to the north of Europe and of America. Very numerous, in ≈øummer time, in the fens of Hud≈øon's Bay; where they breed, and then retire. Appear about the Ca≈øpian ≈øea in the ≈øpring; but never in Sibiria, nor in the north of A≈øia.

With the bill turning a little up; four inches long; pale purple at the ba≈øe; du≈øky at the end: head, neck, back, and coverts of the wings, of a very light brown, with a brown ≈øpot in the middle of each feather: primaries du≈øky; inner webs of a reddi≈øh brown: tail barred with black and white: belly and vent white: legs du≈øky; in ≈øome of a greyi≈øh blue. LENGTH, to the tip of the tail, near ≈øixteen inches.

Arrives in Hud≈øon's Bay in ≈øpring.PLACE. Feeds on ≈ømall ≈øhell-fi≈øh and worms; and frequents the banks of rivers. Called there, by the natives, from its noi≈øe, Sa-≈øa-≈øhew; by the Engli≈øh, Yellow legs. Retires in autumn. Makes a ≈øtop in the province of New York, on its return, but does not winter there. This, and ≈øeveral other ≈øpecies of Snipes and Sandpipers, are called, in North America, Humilities.

PLACE.Inhabits North America, in common with the north of Europe, as high as Finmark Leems, 253. ; and is found in Sibiria. Grows le≈øs common towards the north of that country. Is ≈øometimes found, in Hud≈øon's Bay, quite white Edw. 139..

With a ≈ølender black bill, an inch and a half long, a little bent at the end: head, hind part of the neck, back, and greater coverts of the wings, dirty white, ≈øpotted with black: le≈ø≈øer coverts plain brown: primaries du≈øky: brea≈øt and fore part of the neck ≈øpotted with black and white: belly and coverts of the tail pure white: tail barred with brown and white: legs yellow. With a bill two inches long, and du≈øky: head and neck ≈øtreaked with black and white: brea≈øt white, with round brown ≈øpots: belly and ≈øides white; the la≈øt marked with tran≈øver≈øe bars of brown: back and coverts of the wings cinereous, with great ≈øagittal ≈øpots of black: primaries du≈øky, with a tran≈øver≈øe white bar: ≈øecondaries white: the middle feathers of the tail cinereous, barred with black; outmo≈øt white: legs du≈øky: toes ≈øemipalmated. It migrates in America as low as Florida. In ≈øpring it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes it≈øelf of the i≈øles of the Baltic, till it quits them in autumnAmoen. Acad. iv. 590. .

fro≈øty climate of Greenland; but retires to breed into the bottom of the bays: flies very ≈øwiftly along the ≈øurface of the water, catching the in≈øects on the ≈øurface. Never touches the water with its feet or body; but dexterou≈øly avoids the ri≈øing of the highe≈øt waves. Twitters with the note of the SwallowFaun. Groenl. No 73. .

div.head: 389. GREEN.

With head and upper part of the neck cinereous brown, ≈øtreaked with white: lower part of neck mottled with brown and white: back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of wings, of a du≈øky green, glo≈ø≈øy as ≈øilk, and elegantly ≈øpeckled with white: primaries du≈øky: rump, brea≈øt, and belly, white: tail white, the feathers marked with different numbers of ≈øpots: legs a cinereous green. I have ≈øeen this ≈øpecies in Mr. Kuckan's collection,PLACE. which he made in North America. It is al≈øo found in Iceland; and is very common in all the watery places of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria. The Tringa Littorea is ≈øaid to migrate from Sweden to England, at approach of winterAmoen. Acad. iv. 590. .

div.p:
S. With a black bill: crown and brea≈øt black: head adorned with a very long ≈ølender cre≈øt, horizontal, but turning up at the end: cheeks and ≈øides of the neck, and belly, white: back and ≈øcapulars glo≈ø≈øy green; the la≈øt: varied with purple: primaries and ≈øecondaries black, marked with white: coverts of tail, and vent, orange: outmo≈øt feathers of the tail white, marked with one du≈øky ≈øpot: the upper half of the re≈øt black; the lower of a pure white. WEIGHT
eight ounces. LENGTH thirteen inches and a half. EXTENT two feet and a half.

The Lapwing is common in mo≈øt parts of Europe. PLACE. Extends to the Feroe i≈øles, and even to Iceland Brunnich.. Is very frequent in Ru≈ø≈øia; but becomes very rare beyond the Urallian chain; yet a few have been ob≈øerved about the rivers Ob and Angara, and beyond lake Baikal; but never farther to the ea≈øt. They extend ≈øouthward as far as Per≈øia and Egypt Ha≈ø≈øelqui≈øt, 288. , where they winter; but, unable to bear the va≈øt heats of the ≈øummer, migrate to the countries about Worone≈øch and A≈øtracan
Extracts, i. 107. ii. 147.. Appears in Lombardy, in April; retires in September. Continues in England, and I believe in France, the whole year; but con≈øtantly ≈øhifts its quarters in ≈øearch of food, worms and in≈øects. In France, multitudes are taken for the table in clap-nets, into which they are allured by the playing of a mirror.

No 79. . Arrives in New York in May: breeds there, and di≈øappears in the latter end of October, after collecting in va≈øt flocks. Is reckoned mo≈øt delicious eating.

Found in Iceland and the north of Europe; but are ≈øcarcely ≈øeen in Ru≈ø≈øia. Very frequent in Sibiria, where they breed in the north. They extend al≈øo to Kamt≈øchatka, and as far ≈øouth as the Sandwich i≈øles: in the la≈øt it is very ≈ømall. The climate had almo≈øt de≈øtroyed the ≈øpecific marks; yet, in the bill and habit, pre≈øerved ≈øufficient to make the kind very ea≈øily a≈øcertained. Is found in ≈øummer in Greenland: migrates from thence in autumn. Is common in every part of Ru≈ø≈øia and Sibiria.
