div.p:
PL. With the bill an inch long; black towards the end; red towards the ba≈øe: forehead black: crown black, ≈øurrounded with a circle of white: throat white: neck and brea≈øt of a very light a≈øh-colored brown, divided from the belly by a du≈øky tran≈øver≈øe ≈øtroke: belly and vent white: back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of the wings, cinereous

With a black ≈øtrait bill, an inch long: head, neck, brea≈øt, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of wings and tail, of a ruddy color, ≈øpotted with black, and powdered with white; in the ≈øcapulars and coverts of wings the black prevails: the outmo≈øt web of the four fir≈øt quil feathers brown; the internal white, tipt with brown: the upper part of the others white; the lower brown: the two middle feathers of the tail brown, edged with ru≈øt; the others of a dirty white: legs black: toes divided to their origin.

Av. 193. .

PL. With bill and crown black: from the bill, over each eye, a white line: brea≈øt and belly dull orange; the fir≈øt cro≈ø≈øed with a white line: vent white: back, coverts of wings, and tail, olivaceous, edged

div.head: 422. RED.

list.item: Flamingo, Cate≈øby, i. 73.‚ÄîPhaenicopterus ruber, Lin. Sy≈øt. 230.‚ÄîLe Flammant, ou le Ph√®nicoptere, De Buffon, viii. 475.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 63.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: FL. With the upper mandible extremely convex, ridged, and ≈øloping to a point; the under very deep, and convex on the upper part; the edges of both furni≈øhed with numerous teeth: ≈øpace between it and the eyes naked: neck very long: tail ≈øhort: primaries black: all the re≈øt of the plumage of a fine crim≈øon color; but the European birds, which are the only I have ≈øeen, are ro≈øeate: legs very long: toes webbed: hind toe very ≈ømall. The attitude is erect: and its HEIGHT u≈øually five feet.

PLACES IN AMERICA.The≈øe birds inhabit Loui≈øiana Du Pratz, ii. 81. , the Bahama i≈ølands, and tho≈øe of the We≈øt Indies; and frequent only ≈øalt waters. They live in flocks, and are uncommonly tame, or rather ≈øtupid. A per≈øon who can ≈øtand concealed may ≈øhoot as many as he plea≈øes; for they will not ari≈øe at the report of the gun; but the ≈øurvivors will ≈øtand as if a≈øtoni≈øhed: nor will they take warning at the ≈øight of the ≈ølain; but continue on the ≈øpot till mo≈øt of them are killed. Such is Cate≈øby's account. But the hone≈øt and intelligent Dampier gives a very different one; and ≈øays that they are extremely ≈øhy, and very difficult to be ≈øhot.

NESTS.They build their ne≈øts in ≈øhallow ponds; and form, for that purpo≈øe, with mud, hillocks with a broad ba≈øe, which appear about a foot and a half above the water: the≈øe taper to the top, in which the birds make a hollow for the eggs. They lay two, and cover them with their rump, their legs re≈øting beneath the water. As ≈øoon as the young are hatched they run very fa≈øt, but cannot fly till they are full grownVoyages, i. 71. . They are for a long time of a grey color, nor do they attain that of red till near two years.

They ≈øtand upright, and in a row; ≈øo at a di≈øtance look like a file of ≈øoldiers. They feed on the ≈øeeds of water-plants: not fi≈øh. Their fle≈øh is good, notwith≈øtanding it is lean, and looks black. Dampier al≈øo bears witne≈øs to the delicacy of the tongues; which, ≈øays he, are large, and furni≈øhed with a knob of fat at the root, the ≈øo much boa≈øted mor≈øel. Apicius, a Roman, probably cotemporary with Tiberius, had the honor of fir≈øt introducing them to table: the ≈øame per≈øon whom Pliny ≈øo forcibly ≈øtigmati≈øes with the title of Nepotum alti≈ø≈øimus gurges
Lib. x. c. 48..

The FLAMMANT inhabits ≈øeveral parts of the old world:PLACES IN EUROPE AND ASIA. ≈øuch as ≈øome of the coa≈øts of the Mediterranean ≈øea; the Cape De Verd i≈ølands; and the Cape of Good Hope. They are common on the ≈øhores of the Ca≈øpian ≈øea, on the Per≈øian and Turcomannian coa≈øts: repairing in flocks to the mouth of the river Yemba; and ≈øometimes to that of the Yaik; and al≈øo to that of the Volga, below A≈øtracan.

div.head: 423. WANDERING.

list.item: Diomedea Exulans, Lin. Sy≈øt. 214.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 237.‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Albatro≈øs, Edw. 88.‚ÄîPallas, Spicil. Zool. Fa≈øc. v. 28.
T≈øchaiki of the Kamt≈øchatkans, LEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: ALB. With a ≈øtrong bill, ≈øinking a little in the middle; hooked at the end of the upper mandible, abrupt at that of the lower; no≈øtrils covered with a ≈øtrong guard, and opening forward; color red; tip du≈øky: the plumage, in ≈øome, wholly du≈øky, with the color mo≈øt inten≈øe on the upper part; others again have their under ≈øide entirely white: the tail is rounded: legs and feet of a du≈øky red: the webs du≈øky.

SIZE.ALBATROSSES differ greatly in ≈øize. Whether they differ in ≈øpecies I cannot determine. They weigh from twelve to twenty-eight pounds: and vary in extent of wings, from ≈øeven feet ≈øeven inches to ten feet ≈øeven.

PLACE.The white and the brown variety or ≈øpecies appear annually in flocks of thou≈øands, about the end of June, and ≈øpread over the whole Ochot≈øchan ≈øea, the gulph of Pen≈øchin≈øhi, and the Kurile i≈ølands; but very rarely on the ea≈øtern coa≈øt of Kamt≈øchatka. They al≈øo arrived in great numbers about Bering's I≈øland, at the time when Steller was preparing to depart from his long confinement, after the ≈øhipwreck of his illu≈øtrious commander. He ≈øailed from thence on the 10th of Augu≈øt. This coincides with the re-migration of the≈øe birds, who retire from the former places about the end of July or the middle of Augu≈øt. Their arrival is the certain forerunner of fi≈øh. It is probable that they pur≈øue their prey northward, as they do not return the ≈øame way. They ≈øpread to the coa≈øts of America Seen the 4th of July, in lat. 56. 30, off the we≈øtern coa≈øt of America.‚ÄîEllis's Voy. i. 292., and tend
from each continent to their breeding-places in the ≈øouthern hemi≈øphere, which they may arrive at by the ≈øea≈øon of ≈øummer in that adver≈øe part of the globe.

They ≈øeek the northern ≈øhores,MANNERS. in pur≈øuit of the va≈øt ≈øhoals of ≈øalmon which frequent tho≈øe di≈øtant places. They are the mo≈øt voracious of birds; and will ≈øo fill them≈øelves with fi≈øh, that ≈øometimes a large one will hang half out of their mouths till tho≈øe in their ≈øtomach are dige≈øted. They will be at times ≈øo loaden with food as to become incapable of flying; and even ≈øo ≈øtupified, as to be readily hunted down by boats, or transfixed in the water by darts: neither can they ari≈øe till they have vomited up their prey, which they ≈øtrive to do with all their might.

The Kamt≈øchatkans are very ≈øolicitous about the capture of the≈øe birds,CAPTURE. not ≈øo much for the ≈øake of their fle≈øh (which is very tough and dry, and never eaten unle≈øs hunger compels) but on account of the inte≈øtines, which they blow into bladders, in order to form floats for their nets. They angle for the Albatro≈ø≈øes as they do for the ≈øcaly race, baiting with a whole fi≈øh, a large hook fixed to a long cord. This they fling into the water, when there is an in≈øtant conte≈øt among the≈øe greedy birds, which ≈øhall fir≈øt lay hold of itHi≈øt. Kamt≈øchatka, Engl. edit. 155. .
They have only the ve≈øtige of a tongue; which is one of the characters of the Gannet, Corvorants, and other voracious birds. Their voice, like that of the Pelecan, re≈øembles the braying of an a≈øs.

The voyage which the≈øe birds undertake,MIGRATIONS. from perhaps almo≈øt the extremity of the ≈øouthern hemi≈øphere to that of the northern, urged by in≈øtinct, to attend the migration of certain fi≈øhes, is very amazing. They are, indeed, ≈øeen in April and May off the Cape of Good Hope Dampier, i. 531.‚ÄîO≈øbeck, i. 109. , ≈øometimes ≈øoaring in the air with the gentle motion of a Kite, at a ≈øtupendous height; at others, nearer the water, watching the motions of the Flying Fi≈øh, which they catch while tho≈øe mi≈øerable beings ≈øpring out of their element to ≈øhun the jaws of the Coryphenes.
I have not authority to ≈øay that ≈øome of them do not re≈øide about the Cape the whole year: but I am acquainted with only two places in which they breed; one is the Falkland i≈ølands, the other the coa≈øt of Patagonia This account is given by a di≈øtingui≈øhed officer in our navy, who had vi≈øited the≈øe i≈ølands.. In the fir≈øt, they begin to lay their eggs in October, the ≈øpring of tho≈øe regions, and continue that function about a month.NESTS AND EGG. They build their ne≈øts with ≈øedges, in form of a haycock, about three feet high, leaving a hollow in the ≈øummit for the egg; for they lay but one, which is four inches and a half long, white, with ≈øome ≈ømall ob≈øcure ≈øpots at the thicker end. They are con≈øtantly watched while on their ne≈øts by multitudes of Hawks, who no ≈øooner ≈øee the Albatro≈øs quit its ne≈øt, but they in≈øtantly dart down and carry off the egg. This obliges them to lay another, and prolong the ≈øea≈øon of incubation.

The remaining part of the ≈øummer they wander over all parts of the Antarctic ≈øeas; and were ≈øeen as low as lat. 67. 20. in the middle of our January Cook's Voy. S. Pole, i. 256. ; and have been ≈øeen in ≈øeveral ≈øucce≈ø≈øive months to the northward, ≈øhunning the winter of their native hemi≈øphere, and ≈øeeking warmth and food in the remote climate of Kamt≈øchatka.

STELLER takes notice of ≈øome birds which the Ru≈ø≈øians rank under the name of Gloughpichi. He ≈øays they are found in great numbers on the i≈øles between A≈øia and America; that they were of the ≈øize between an Eagle and a Goo≈øe, had a yellow crooked bill, and their plumage of the color of umber, ≈øpotted with white. He al≈øo ≈øaw numbers feeding on a dead whale. And in cro≈ø≈øing the Penchian ≈øea, he ob≈øerved ≈øeveral flying: ≈øome white, others blackDe≈øcr. de la Kamt≈øchatka, 492. . All the≈øe I ≈øu≈øpect to have been different ≈øorts of ALBATROSSES, which may have wandered here; for the Antarctic voyagers ob≈øerved at le≈øt three ≈øpecies in their approaches towards the ≈øouthern poleCook's Voy. towards the S. Pole, i. 43, 256, 258. .

div.p: A. With a ≈øtrong bill, bending at the end; black, and furrowed tran≈øver≈øely: between that and the eyes, a bean-≈øhaped white ≈øpot: above, the whole plumage is of a glo≈ø≈øy black; the ≈øecondaries alone tipt with white: brea≈øt and belly white: wings very ≈øhort, and u≈øele≈øs for flight, covered with very ≈øhort feathers: legs black. To the end of the toes, three feet.

Inhabits (but not very frequently,PLACE. the coa≈øts of Norway) the Feroe i≈ølands (in a certain number of years, St. Kilda) Iceland, Greenland, and Newfoundland. It lives chiefly on the ≈øea; but never wanders beyond the ≈øoundings. Feeds much on the Lump-fi≈øh, Br. Zool. ii. No 57. and Father La≈øher, Br. Zool. iii. No 99. and other fi≈øh of that ≈øize. Builds on rocks remote from ≈øhore. Lays one egg, ≈øix inches long, irregularly marked with purpli≈øh lines on a white ground, or blotched near the thicker end with black or ferruginous ≈øpots. Hatches late. The young, in Augu≈øt, are only covered with grey down. Their food, at that period, is vegetable, the Rhodiola Ro≈øea, and other plants, having been found in their ≈øtomachs. The Greenlanders u≈øe the gullet as a bladder to ≈øupport their dartsFaun. Groenl. p. 82. : and I think I have ≈øeen ≈øome habits of the E≈økimaux made of the ≈økins.

div.p:
A. With a white line from the bill to the eyes: bill thick, bent at the end, cro≈ø≈øed with tran≈øver≈øe groves; the large≈øt white, and pa≈ø≈øing over each mandible: head, back, wings, and tail black:
≈øecondaries tipt with white: brea≈øt and belly white: legs black. WEIGHT near twenty-three ounces. LENGTH eighteen inches. EXTENT twenty-≈øeven.

PLACE.Inhabits the north of Europe, Iceland, Greenland, and the coa≈øt of Labrador Doctor PALLAS; to whom it was ≈øent by a Moravian mi≈ø≈øionary.. Extends in Europe, along the White ≈øea, into the Arctic A≈øiatic ≈øhores; and from thence to Kamt≈øchatka and the gulph of Ochot≈øk, wherever there are lofty rocksIn the Briti≈øh Zoology, ii. No 230, I made matter of wonder, the manner in which this bird placed its egg on the naked rock, with ≈øo ≈øecure a balance that it would not roll off. Mr. Aikin referred me to the following pa≈ø≈øage in HARVEY de Generatione Anim. which mo≈øt clearly expalins the cau≈øe: "In the ≈øame i≈øland" (the Ba≈øi), ≈øays he, una mihi mon≈øtratur avis, quae ovum duntaxat ≈øingulare, ≈øive unicum, parit, idemque ≈øuper cuju≈ødam lapidis acuti fa≈øtigium collocat (nullo nido, aut conqui≈øit√¢ ≈øtrue ≈øuppo≈øit√¢), idque tam firmiter, ut mater abire & redire, ≈øalvo ovo, po≈ø≈øit. Hoc autem ≈øi quis loco dimoveat, null√¢ arte po≈øtea ≈øtabiliri pote≈øt; quin inde devolutum praeceps in mare ruat. Locus nemp√® (ut dixi) caemento albo incru≈øtatur; ovumque, cum na≈øcitur, lent√¢ & vi≈øco≈ø√¢ madet humiditate, qu√¢ cit√≤ concre≈øcente, tanquam ferrumine quodam ≈øub≈øtrato ≈øaxo agglutinatur. . It is the only one of this ≈øpecies which reaches the inland Baltic. It is found there on the Carls-Ozar i≈øles, near Gothland, and the i≈øle of Bondon off Angermanland.

div.head: 426. BLACK-BILLED.

div.p: A. With a black bill, marked with one furrow: whole upper ≈øide of the body black; the under, from chin to tail, white. WEIGHT only eighteen ounces. LENGTH fifteen inches and a half. EXTENT twenty-five.

PLACE.Inhabits the north of Europe, and the ≈øame countries with the former. It extends farther ≈øouth than any of the genus; being found on the coa≈øts of Candia, the antient Crete; where it is called Vuthamaria, and Calicatczu Belon. Ob≈ø. 12. . In Greenland neither of them frequent the bays till the inten≈øe cold ≈øets in; but live in the ≈øea, re≈øorting, in the
breeding ≈øea≈øon, to the cliffs in flocks, where each knows its ≈øtation. Feed on the cancer pedatus, and other marine in≈øects; and grow very fat. In winter, re≈øort to the bays to feed; but at night return to ≈øea. Vie with the Eider-duck, in point of utility to the Greenlanders. The ≈økins are u≈øed for cloathing: the raw fat is ≈øucked as broth: the fle≈øh, half putrid, is much admired: and the whole fowl, dre≈ø≈øed with the inte≈øtines in it, e≈øteemed a high delicacy.

They are taken in the ≈øea with darts; or, chaced in canoes, are driven on ≈øhore, and killed by the per≈øons who wait for them; or are taken in nets made of ≈øplit whalebone. They are the chief food of the natives during February and March Crantz, i. 48. .

In the ≈øame ≈øea≈øon, numbers of the≈øe birds, and the RAZOR-BILLS, frequent the coa≈øt of Andalu≈øia; but di≈øappear in the ≈øpring. It is ≈øuppo≈øed that they continue ≈øwimming from the northern parts in ≈øearch of food; the fi≈øh of the ≈øofter latitudes not retiring to the great deeps out of their reach, as is the ca≈øe with the fi≈øh of more rigorous climates.

With a bill about an inch and a quarter long, much carinated at top, not very deep, a little convex; upper mandible du≈øky, lower whiti≈øh, marked with a black ≈øpot, and angulated like that of a Gull: crown, and upper part of the body, wings, and tail, du≈øky: lower part white: legs red. PLACE.Inhabits the north of Europe, as far as Spitzbergen; but I believe does not extend to A≈øia. Frequent in Greenland. Dives well. Is always putting its bill to the water as if drinking. Grows very fat in ≈øtormy weather, when the waves bring ≈ømall Crabs and little fi≈øh near the ≈øurface. Is called in Newfoundland the Ice-bird, being the harbinger of iceCrantz, i. 85. . Varies to quite white; and ≈øometimes is found with a reddi≈øh brea≈øt. Is called by the Dutch, Rottet, from its note.

div.p: A. With a black bill, crown, and throat: on each ≈øide of the head a ≈øhort whiti≈øh cre≈øt: on the hind part of the neck are numbers of white, long, loo≈øe, and very narrow feathers, which give it an aged look: wings, back, and tail, ≈øooty: brea≈øt and belly white. SIZE of the former.

div.p: A. With a ≈øtrong thick bill, of a ≈øub-triangular form, arched, hooked near the end; the lower mandible truncated; the upper mandible, near the ba≈øe, ri≈øing into a di≈øtinct prominence: the bill of the male marked with three furrows; of the female with two: its colors a fine red, yellow, and corneous: from the ≈øides of the head are two long ≈øilky tufts of a yellow color, falling down the ≈øides of the neck to the back: cheeks white: the re≈øt of the plumage entirely black; lighte≈øt beneath: legs of a bright red. In SIZE ≈øuperior to the Puffin Auk.
Inhabits only the ≈øhores of Kamt≈øchatka, the Kurile i≈ølands,PLACE. and tho≈øe intervening between Kamt≈øchatka and America.

In manners this ≈øpecies greatly re≈øembles the Puffin.MANNERS. Lives all day at ≈øea, but at no great di≈øtance from the rocks: comes on ≈øhore at night: burrows a yard deep under ground, and makes there a ne≈øt, with feathers and ≈øea plants: is monogamous, and lodges there the whole night with its mate. Lays one white egg, in the latter end of May or beginning of June. Bites fiercely when taken. Feeds on Crabs, Shrimps, and ≈øhell-fi≈øh, which it forces from the rocks with its ≈øtrong bill.

The females of Kamt≈øchatka copy from this bird the fa≈øhion of hanging, from behind each ear, tufts made of ≈ølips of the white part of the ≈økins of the Glutton. The≈øe are reckoned the mo≈øt valuable
pre≈øent a lover can give his mi≈øtre≈øs, or a hu≈øband to his wife, and the ≈øtronge≈øt proof of affection.

Their magicians formerly u≈øed to recommend the bills of this bird, mixed with tho≈øe of the Puffin, and the parti-colored hairs of Seals, as a powerful amulet. The di≈øtant i≈ølanders ≈øtill bear the bills in their helmets and caps, and make their garments of the ≈økins; but the Kamt≈øchatkans at pre≈øent make no u≈øe of any part but the eggs, which are a common food; the fle≈øh being hard and in≈øipid.

With an oval bill, or the upper and lower parts convex, and of a bright red color: from the remote corner of each eye is a very ≈ølender tuft of fine white feathers, hanging down the neck: the head and upper part of the body du≈øky; the lower whiti≈øh, varied with black edges: legs dirty yellow: webs du≈øky. PLACE.Inhabits Kamt≈øchatka, the i≈øles towards Japan, tho≈øe towards America, and the we≈øtern ≈øhores of America, in great abundance. They ≈øwim in flocks; but never, unle≈øs tempe≈øt-driven, go far from the rocks, to which they re≈øort towards night, and ≈øhelter them≈øelves in the fi≈ø≈øures or holes, without keeping any certain ne≈øt. Are the mo≈øt ≈øtupid of all birds, and caught by the natives in this ridiculous manner:‚Äîtowards evening they put on their garment with great ≈øleeves, pull out their arms, and leave the ≈øleeves di≈øtended, which the birds will creep into by flocks, and thus become an ea≈øy prey.

The ≈øtupidity of this ≈øpecies has often been the ≈øalvation of mariners ≈øailing by night in the≈øe dangerous parts; being often warned of the neighborhood of a dreadful rock, by the≈øe birds flying on board their ve≈ø≈øel, mi≈øtaking it for their de≈øigned lodging. They lay one egg, uncommonly great for their ≈øize; it is of a whiti≈øh color, ≈øpeckled with brown, du≈øky, or yellow; and is e≈øteemed for its delicacy.

With a ≈ømall arched bill, du≈øky and yellow: above the ba≈øe, on the forehead, the feathers divide into two points: beyond each eye is a whiti≈øh de≈øcending line, in which are a few ≈øetaceous feathers: general color of the bird du≈øky: belly hoary: on the hind part of the head and neck, and near the tail, a few ru≈øty marks: tail very ≈øhort, du≈øky, and ≈øome of the feathers tipt with ferruginous: legs livid: webs inten≈øely black. div.p: G. With the bill an inch and a half long: in≈øide of the mouth of a fine red: bill, head, neck, back, tail, and under ≈øide of the body, black: wings du≈øky; the coverts marked with a bed of white; ≈øecondaries tipt with white: legs ≈øcarlet. LENGTH fourteen inches. EXTENT twenty-two.

PLACE.Found in all the ≈øame places with the former, except Italy; doubtful as to Newfoundland. Inhabits Hud≈øon's Bay the whole year. The young are mottled with black and white, and ≈øometimes are quite whiteMr. Hutchins a≈ø≈øures me, that the old birds do not vary, as has been imagined.. Are excellent divers; therefore called ≈øometimes Diving Pigeons. Make a twittering noi≈øe. The Greenlanders eat the fle≈øh, u≈øe the ≈økin for cloathing, and the legs as lures for fi≈øh.
In Kamt≈øchatka is a variety, with a white oblique line i≈ø≈øuing from the white ≈øpot on the wings.

div.head: 438. MARBLED.
div.p: G. With a black bill: crown du≈øky: throat, brea≈øt, and belly, mottled with black and white: back and ≈øides very glo≈ø≈øy, and marbled with black and ru≈øt-color: wings du≈øky; greater coverts edged with white: tail black: legs yellow: webs black. LENGTH nine inches.
Inhabits Prince William's Sound, PLACE. on the we≈øtern coa≈øt of North America, and probably Kamt≈øchatka.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.head: 439. NORTHERN.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 237.‚ÄîL'Imbrim, ou grand Plongeon de la Mer de Nord, De Buffon, viii. 258.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 952.
Colymbus Glacialis, Lin. Sy≈øt. 221.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: D. With head and neck black: throat, and hind part of the neck, marked with a ≈øemilunar ≈øpot of white, and with white ≈øtreaks pointing downwards: upper part of the body and wings black, varied with white ≈øpots: tail du≈øky: brea≈øt and belly white: legs black. LENGTH three feet five inches. EXTENT four feet eight. WEIGHT ≈øixteen pounds.

PLACE.Inhabits the north of Europe, and ≈øpreads along the Arctic coa≈øts, as far as the mouth of the Ob only. Is found about Spitzbergen, Iceland, Hud≈øon's Bay, and as low as New York. Makes its ne≈øt, in the more northern regions, on the little i≈øles of fre≈øh-water lakes. Every pair keeps a lake to it≈øelf. Sees well: flies very high, and, darting obliquely, falls ≈øecure into its ne≈øt. Tries to ≈øave it≈øelf by diving, not flying. The young defend them≈øelves ≈øtoutly with their bills. Appears in Greenland in April or the beginning of May. Goes away in September or October, on the fir≈øt fall of ≈ønow. The natives u≈øe the ≈økins for cloathing; and the Indians about Hud≈øon's Bay adorn their heads with circlets of their feathers.

PLACE.Inhabits New York during winter. Extends to Kamt≈øchatka; but in no part of Sibiria or Ru≈ø≈øia. Found in Iceland, and mo≈øt parts of northern Europe.

div.p: D. With the bill turning a little upwards: head dark grey, ≈øpotted with white: hind part of the neck of an uniform grey: back, coverts of wings, primaries, and tail, du≈øky; the two fir≈øt ≈øpotted with white: from chin to tail a fine ≈øilvery white. WEIGHT two pounds and a half. LENGTH two feet three. EXTENT three feet nine.

The≈øe three ≈øpecies vi≈øit New York in the winter,PLACE. and return very far north to breed. This is common about the Baltic and White Sea; but not ob≈øerved in other parts of Ru≈ø≈øia; yet is a native of Kamt≈øchatka Steller, in Nov. Com. Petrop. iv. 424. . It lays two eggs in the gra≈øs, on the borders of the lakes, not far from the ≈øea. The eggs are exactly oval, of the ≈øize of tho≈øe of a Goo≈øe, du≈øky, marked with a few black ≈øpots.

div.head: 442. STRIPED.
div.p: D. With a ≈øtrong black bill, three inches long: head and neck light grey, ≈øtriped regularly downwards with long narrow black lines: back and ≈øcapulars du≈øky and plain: primaries, tail, and legs, du≈øky: cheeks, and whole under ≈øide of the body, of a glo≈ø≈øy white. WEIGHT between two and three pounds.

Inhabits the inland lakes of Hud≈øon's Bay, PLACE. about a hundred miles ≈øouthward of York Fort. Lays, in June, two eggs. Flies high, and pa≈ø≈øes backwards and forwards, making a great noi≈øe; which is ≈øaid to portend rain. Dete≈øted by the natives, who look on this note as ≈øupernatural.‚ÄîMr. Hutchins.

With head and chin of an uniform grey: throat, and lower ≈øide of the neck, of a dull red: upper part grey, ≈øtreaked with black: upper part of body, wings, and tail, du≈øky: back and coverts of wings ≈øpotted with white: brea≈øt and belly white: legs du≈øky. WEIGHT three pounds. EXTENT three feet five. LENGTH, to the tip of the tail, two feet.

PLACE.Found in the north of Europe and Iceland, along the northern coa≈øt of Ru≈ø≈øia, Sibiria, and Kamt≈øchatka; but does not haunt the inland lakes. Inhabits the rivers of Hud≈øon's Bay during ≈øummer. Prey much on the fi≈øh entangled in the nets; but are often caught them≈øelves in their rapid pur≈øuit of the fi≈øh. Mr. Hutchins took fourteen out of a ≈øingle net in one tide. Numbers of every ≈øpecies of Diver are frequently taken in this manner about Hud≈øon's Bay.

div.head: 444. BLACK-THROATED.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 241.‚ÄîColymbus Arcticus, Lomm. Faun. Suec. No 150.

div.p: D. With bill, forehead, and cheeks, black: hind part of the neck cinereous: ≈øides of the neck ≈øtreaked downwards with black: fore part varying with black, purple, and green: back and coverts of wings du≈øky; the fir≈øt marked with ≈øquare, the la≈øt with round white ≈øpots: brea≈øt and belly white: tail black: legs partly red, partly du≈øky.

PLACE.This, and the preceding, inhabit Hud≈øon's Bay Edwards, 147. , the north of Europe, and Iceland. Few in Ru≈ø≈øia: but frequent in the inland lakes of Sibiria, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Arctic regions; but in the wandering ≈øea≈øon ≈øpread over all latitudes.

The Norwegians remark the ≈øagacity of the≈øe birds, in pre≈øaging the change of weather. When the ≈økies are big with rain, they fly wildly about, and make the mo≈øt horrible hoar≈øe noi≈øe, fearing that the ≈øwelled waters ≈øhould invade their ne≈øt; on the contrary, in fine weather, their note is different, and ≈øeemingly in an exulting ≈øtrain. The Norwegians think it impious, to de≈øtroy, or even to di≈øturb, this ≈øpeciesWorm. Mu≈ø. 304. .

The Swedes have le≈øs ≈øuper≈øtition: they dre≈øs the ≈økins; which, when prepared, ≈øhew in the cleare≈øt manner, on the in≈øide, the quincuncial di≈øpo≈øition of feathers. They are exceedingly tough, and are u≈øed for gun-ca≈øes and facings for winter-capsFaun. Suec..

LENGTH one foot eight inches. EXTENT three feet ≈øeven.

PLACE.Inhabits America, from New York to Guiana Barrera France Equin. 135. . Skims nimbly along the water, with its under mandible ju≈øt beneath the ≈øurface, feeding on the in≈øects and ≈ømall fi≈øh as it proceeds. Frequents al≈øo oy≈øter-banks; its bill being partly, like that of the Oy≈øter-catcher, adapted for preying on tho≈øe ≈øhell-fi≈øh. In Mr. Ray's Synop≈øis 194. No 5. tab. i. No 5. is a ≈øketch, ≈øent from Madras, of one of this ≈øpecies.

div.head: 446. NODDY.

list.item: Cate≈øby, i. 88.‚ÄîLe Noddi, De Buffon, viii. 461.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 461.
Sterna Stolida, Lin. Sy≈øt. 227.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: T. With a black long bill: crown white, gradually darkening to the hind part: whole plumage brown: wings and tail almo≈øt du≈øky. WEIGHT four ounces.

Inhabit, in va≈øt numbers, the Bahama i≈ølands,PLACE. where they breed on the bare rocks. In the breeding ≈øea≈øon they, and numbers of other birds, are ≈øeen in great flights, flying near the ≈øurface of the water, continually dropping on the ≈ømall fi≈øh which are driven to the top, to ≈øhun the per≈øecution of the greater. The whole air re≈øounds with the noi≈øe of the birds, who ≈øeem in full exultation on their ≈øucce≈øs; which is expre≈ø≈øed in va≈øt variety of notes. A rippling and whitene≈øs in the water marks the cour≈øe of the ≈øhoals of fi≈øh; and above them the air is animated with their feathered enemies. Where the ≈øtronge≈øt rippling is, there appear the thicke≈øt ≈øwarms of fowls. As ≈øoon as the time of nutrition is over, the≈øe birds di≈øper≈øe over the ocean ≈øeparately; and are ≈øeen at the di≈øtance of hundreds of leagues from land; but very ≈øeldom on the out≈øide of the tropics. Their ≈øtupidity is notorious; for they will ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be taken by the hand, when they ≈øettle, as they often do, on the yards of ≈øhips.

div.head: 447. SOOTY.
div.p: T. With a black bill, two inches long: forehead white: crown, hind part of the head and neck, back, and wings, of a ≈øooty blackne≈øs: cheeks, fore part of the neck, brea≈øt, belly, and ridge of the wings, white: tail greatly forked; tip of the exterior feathers white; the re≈øt of the tail du≈øky. Nearly the SIZE, of the Common Gull.

Sent from NEW YORK to Sir A≈øhton Lever. PLACE. The≈øe birds are found in very remote climates. They ≈øwarm in the i≈øle of A≈øcen≈øion, 8 ≈øouth latitude. Emit a mo≈øt ≈øharp and ≈øhrill cry: are quite fearle≈øs; and
fly ≈øo clo≈øe to the few men who vi≈øit that di≈øtant i≈øle, as almo≈øt to touch them. They lay only two or three eggs, which are of a ≈øurprizing ≈øize, yellowi≈øh, ≈øpotted with brown and pale violet. The flocks which po≈ø≈øe≈øs the different parts of the i≈øle, lay at different times. In ≈øome quarters the young were found very large; in others only a ≈øingle egg was found ju≈øt then layed. Mr. O≈øbeck and Doctor For≈øter, who were here in April and May, are ≈øilent about this ≈øpecies: po≈ø≈øibly it was then on its migrations. It is to the Comte de Buffon
Oi≈ø. viii. 345. we owe this account; who received it from that ob≈øervant nobleman the Marquis de Querho√´nt.

With bill and feet of a fine crim≈øon color: forehead, throat, and whole under ≈øide, of a pure white: crown black: upper part of the body, and coverts of the wings, an elegant pale grey: tail much forked, white, with the exterior edges of the three outmo≈øt grey. T. With a yellow bill and legs; the fir≈øt tipt with black: forehead and cheeks white: from the back to the eyes is a black line: crown black: brea≈øt and belly of the mo≈øt exqui≈øite and glo≈ø≈øy whitene≈øs, unequalled by the fine≈øt ≈øatin: back and wings of a pale grey: tail
white; le≈øs forked than that of the preceding. WEIGHT two ounces eight grains: LENGTH eight inches and a half: EXTENT nineteen and a half.

This ≈øpecies is too tender to endure the high northern latitudes,PLACE. nor even beyond the Baltic. Is met with in the ≈øouth of Ru≈ø≈øia, and about the Black and Ca≈øpian ≈øea; and in Sibiria about the Irti≈øh. In America is ≈øeen, during ≈øummer, about New York.

This is the ≈øpecies which I apprehend was ≈øent to the Royal Society from Hud≈øon's Bay; and was ≈øeen in va≈øt flocks beyond lat. 41 north,PLACE. long. 47 we≈øt from London, by Mr. Kalm Voyage, i. 23. , ≈øomewhat ≈øouth of the bank of Newfoundland. Is found in Europe, as far as Iceland. Very numerous in Sibiria, and about the ≈øalt lakes of the de≈øarts of Tartary, which they animate by their note and active flight and motions.

list.item: B. CASPIAN T. Terna Ca≈øpia, Mr. Lepechin, in Nov. Com. Petrop. xiv. 500. tab. xiii. ‚ÄîPALLAS, 483. tab. xxii.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

With a ≈øcarlet bill, three inches long: crown and hind part of the head of an inten≈øe black, hoared with white: ≈øpace round the eyes black; under each a white cre≈øcent: cheeks, lower ≈øide of the neck, and whole under ≈øide of the body, of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs: upper part cinereous and hoary: ≈øix fir≈øt primaries darker, edged and tipt with black: tall deeply forked, and of a pure white: legs black. Remains long ≈øu≈øpended in the air, then da≈øhes on its prey; and ≈økims the ≈øurface of the water like a Swallow. Lays, on the back of de≈øart i≈øles, two eggs marked with du≈øky ≈øpots. Wanders up the great river Oby, even, towards the frozen ocean PALLAS MS. Catalog..

Inhabits northern Europe, as high as Iceland, Lapmark, PLACE. and the White Sea; Greenland, and the coa≈øt of North America down to New York and South Carolina, where they are called Old Wives. Is ob≈øerved, in Greenland, to attack other birds, e≈øpecially the Eider Duck. The E≈økimaux and Greenlanders make their garments of the ≈økins of the≈øe, as well as other water fowl. This was a practice, in early times, with every people to whom manufactures were unknown. Non avium plumae in u≈øum ve≈øtis con≈øeruntur Senecae Epi≈øt. Ep. xc. ?

Inhabits the north of Europe, Iceland, and Greenland: PLACE. even in the la≈øt country a common ≈øpecies; and continues there the whole year.
Breeds among broken rocks: much upon wing: is caught in ≈ønares, or by a baited hook. The fle≈øh and eggs eaten; and the ≈økin u≈øed, like that of mo≈øt other Gulls, for garments. Is found in Hud≈øon's Bay during ≈øummer: breeds there, and retires at approach of winter. It breeds likewi≈øe on the i≈ølands on the coa≈øt of South Carolina. Is frequent about the Ca≈øpian and Black ≈øeas, and their great rivers: al≈øo about the greate≈øt lakes of Sibiria.

Its manners, ≈øuch as its great courage, and fiercene≈øs in defending its young, in driving away the eagle from its haunts, and, as is firmly a≈ø≈øerted by Mr. Schroter, a ≈øurgeon in the Feroe i≈øles, its preying on the le≈ø≈øer water fowl, like a rapacious land bird, are fully de≈øcribed in the Briti≈øh Zoology. They keep chiefly in the high ≈øeas, and feed on dead whales, or any thing that offers on the ≈øurface; but will, with their ≈øtrong bills, pick the fat out of the backs of living whales, e≈øpecially of the wounded; who≈øe bloody track they will follow by hundreds, to watch its ri≈øing. div.head: 469. WHISTLING SWAN.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 264.‚ÄîAnas Cygnus ferus. Swan, Faun. Suec. No 107.‚Äî Latham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: D. With the lower part of the bill black; upper part, and ≈øpace between that and the eyes, covered with a naked yellow ≈økin: eye-lids naked and yellow: whole plumage pure white: legs black. LENGTH, to the tip of the tail, four feet ten. EXTENT ≈øeven feet three. WEIGHT from thirteen to ≈øixteen pounds.

The≈øe birds inhabit the northern world, as high as Iceland, PLACE. and as low as the ≈øoft climate of Greece, or of Lydia, the modern Anatolia, in A≈øia Minor: it even de≈øcends as low as Egypt Cate≈øby, App. xxxvi.‚ÄîLaw≈øon, 146.‚ÄîDu Pratz, ii. 78. . They ≈øwarm, during ≈øummer, in the great lakes and mar≈øhes of the Tartarian and Sibirian de≈øarts; and re≈øort in great numbers to winter about the Ca≈øpian and Euxine ≈øeas. Tho≈øe of the ea≈øtern parts of Sibiria retire beyond Kamt≈øchatka, either to the coa≈øts of America, or to the i≈øles north of Japan. In Sibiria, they ≈øpread far north, but not to the Arctic circle. They arrive in Hud≈øon's Bay about the end of May: breed in great numbers on the ≈øhores, in the i≈ølands, and in the inland lakes; but all retire to the ≈øouthern parts of North America in autumn, even as low as Carolina and Loui≈øiana. Mr. Law≈øon, who was no inaccurate ob≈øerver, ≈øays, that there were two ≈øorts in Carolina: the larger is called, from its note, the Trumpeter. The≈øe arrive in great flocks to the fre≈øh rivers in winter; and, in February, retire to the great lakes to breed: the le≈ø≈øer are called Hoopers, and frequent mo≈øtly the ≈øalt water. The Cygnets are e≈øteemed a delicate di≈øh. The Indians of Loui≈øiana make diadems for their chieftains with the large feathers: the le≈ø≈øer are woven into garments for the women of rank. The young of both ≈øexes make tippets of the unplucked ≈økin.
They breed in great multitudes in the lakes of Lapland; and re≈øort towards the more ≈øouthern parts of Europe, during the ≈øevere ≈øea≈øon. Breed even in the Orkney i≈øles.

HOW TAKEN IN ICELAND.In Iceland they are an object of chace. In Augu≈øt they lo≈øe their feathers to ≈øuch a degree as not to be able to fly. The natives, at that ≈øea≈øon, re≈øort in great numbers to the places where they mo≈øt abound; and come provided with dogs, and active and ≈øtrong hor≈øes, trained to the ≈øport, and capable of pa≈ø≈øing nimbly over the boggy ≈øoil and mar≈øhes. The ≈øwans will run as fa≈øt as a tolerable hor≈øe. The greater numbers are taken by the dogs, which are taught to catch them by the neck, which cau≈øes them to lo≈øe their balance, and become an ea≈øy prey. Great u≈øe is made of the plumage: the fle≈øh is eaten; and the ≈økin of the legs and feet, taken off entire, looks like ≈øhagreen, and is u≈øed for pur≈øes. The eggs are collected in the ≈øpring for foodOlaffen, i. 118. .IN KAMTSCHATKA. In Kamt≈øchatka, where they abound both in winter and ≈øummer, they are al≈øo taken with dogs, in the moulting ≈øea≈øon; or killed with clubs. During winter they are taken in the unfrozen rivers, and form a con≈øtant di≈øh at the tables of the nativesDe≈øcr. Kamt≈øchatka, 495. . This ≈øpecies has ≈øeveral di≈øtinctions from the ≈øpecies which we,SPECIFIC DISTINCTIONS. in England, call the Tame Swan. In Ru≈ø≈øia this ≈øpecies more fitly clames the name, it being the kind mo≈øt commonly tamed in that empire. The Whi≈øtling Swan carries its neck quite erect: the other ≈øwims with it arched. This is far inferior in ≈øize. This has twelve ribs on a ≈øide; the MUTE We change the name of the Tame Swan into MUTE, as the former name is equivocal, and this ≈øpecies emits-no ≈øound. only eleven. But the mo≈øt remarkable is the ≈øtrange figure of the windpipe, which falls into the che≈øt, then turns back like a trumpet, and afterwards makes a ≈øecond bend to join the lungs. Thus it is enabled to utter a loud and ≈øhrill note. The other Swan, on the contrary, is the mo≈øt ≈øilent of birds; it can do nothing more than hi≈øs, which it does on receiving any provocation. The vocal kind emits its loud notes only when flying, or
calling: its ≈øound is, whoogh, whoogh, very loud and ≈øhrill, but not di≈øagreeable, when heard far above one's head, and modulated by the winds. The natives of Iceland compare it to the notes of a violin: in fact they hear it at the end of their long and gloomy winter, when the return of the Swans announces the return of ≈øummer: every note mu≈øt be therefore melodious which pre≈øages the ≈øpeedy thaw, and the relea≈øe from their tedious confinement.

It is from this ≈øpecies alone that the antients have given the fable of the Swan being endued with the powers of melody:VOCAL SWAN OF THE POETS. embracing the Pythagorean doctrine, they made the body of this bird the man≈øion of the ≈øouls of departed poets: and after that, attributed to the birds the ≈øame faculty of harmony which their inmates po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in a pre-exi≈øtent ≈øtate. The vulgar, not di≈øtingui≈øhing between ≈øweetne≈øs of numbers and melody of voice, thought that real which was only intended figuratively. The MUTE Swan never frequents the Padus; and I am almo≈øt equally certain that it never is ≈øeen on the Cay≈øter, in Lydia; each of them ≈øtreams celebrated by the poets, for the great re≈øort of Swans. The Padus was ≈øtyled Oloriferus, from the numbers which frequented its waters; and there are few of the poets, Greek or Latin, who do not truly make them its inhabitants. I ≈øhall give one reference only, out of re≈øpect to the extreme beauty of the imagery.

q.l: Haud ≈øecus Eridani ≈øtagnis ripave Cay≈øtri
Innatat albus Olor, pronoque immobile corpus
Dat fluvio: & pedibus tacitis emigrat in undas.

div.head: 470. MUTE SWAN.

list.item: Tame Swan, Br. Zool. ii. No 265.‚ÄîAn≈øer Cygnus, No 107. Œ≤.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p:
D. With a deep red bill, and black incurvated nail at the end: a triangular naked black ≈økin between the bill and the eyes: at the ba≈øe of the upper mandible a large black rounded protuberance:
legs black: whole plumage of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs. WEIGHT ≈øometimes twenty-five pounds.

PLACE.The Mute Swan, or that which we call Tame, is found in a wild ≈øtate in ≈øome parts of Ru≈ø≈øia; but far more plentiful in Sibiria. It arrives, in ≈øummer, later from the ≈øouth, and does not ≈øpread ≈øo far northDoctor PALLAS.. Tho≈øe which frequent the provinces of Ghilan and Ma≈øenderan, on the ≈øouth of the Ca≈øpian ≈øea, grow to a va≈øt ≈øize, and are e≈øteemed great delicacies. The Mahometans hold them in high venerationExtracts, iii. 78. .

div.head: 471. CANADA GOOSE.

list.item: Edw. 151.‚ÄîCate≈øby, i. 91.‚ÄîAnas Canaden≈øis, Lin. Sy≈øt. 198.‚ÄîPhil. Tran≈ø. lxii. 412.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: D. With an elevated black bill: head, neck, primaries, and tail, black: from the throat pa≈ø≈øes, along the cheeks to the hind part of each ≈øide of the head, a triangular white ≈øpot: bottom of the neck, vent feathers, lower belly, and coverts of the tail, white: brea≈øt, upper belly, back, and wings (except primaries) of a du≈øky brown: legs of a deep lead-color.

PLACE.Inhabit the northern parts of North America. Immen≈øe flocks appear annually in the ≈øpring in Hud≈øon's Bay, and pa≈øs far to the north to breed; and return ≈øouthward in the autumn. Numbers al≈øo breed about Hud≈øon's Bay, and lay ≈øix or ≈øeven eggs. The young are ea≈øily made tame. M. Fabricius ≈øu≈øpects that they are found, during ≈øummer, in Greenland Faun. Groenl. p. 66. . They proceed, in their ≈øouthern migration, as low as South Carolina, where they winter in the rice-grounds. The Engli≈øh of Hud≈øon's Bay depend greatly on Gee≈øe, of the≈øe and other kinds, for their ≈øupport; and, in favorable years, kill three or four thou≈øand, which they ≈øalt and barrel. Their arrival is impatiently attended; it is the harbinger of the ≈øpring, and the month named by the Indians the Goo≈øe moon. They appear u≈øually at our ≈øettlements in numbers, about St. George's day, O. S. and fly
northward to ne≈øtle in ≈øecurity. They prefer i≈ølands to the continent, as further from the haunts of men. Thus Marble I≈øland was found, in Augu≈øt, to ≈øwarm with Swans, Gee≈øe, and Ducks; the old ones moulting, and the young at that time incapable of flying Drage, i. 93..

The Engli≈øh ≈øend out their ≈øervants, as well as Indians, to ≈øhoot the≈øe birds on their pa≈ø≈øage. It is in vain to pur≈øue them: they therefore form a row of huts made of boughs, at mu≈øquet-≈øhot di≈øtance from each other, and place them in a line acro≈øs the va≈øt mar≈øhes of the country. Each hovel, or, as they are called, ≈øtand, is occupied by only a ≈øingle per≈øon. The≈øe attend the flight of the birds, and on their approach mimic their cackle ≈øo well, that the Gee≈øe will an≈øwer, and wheel and come nearer the ≈øtand. The ≈øport≈øman keeps motionle≈øs, and on his knees, with his gun cocked, the whole time; and never fires till he has ≈øeen the eyes of the Gee≈øe. He fires as they are going from him, then picks up another gun that lies by him, and di≈øcharges that. The Gee≈øe which he has killed, he ≈øets up on ≈øticks as if alive, to decoy others; he al≈øo makes artificial birds for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. In a good day (for they fly in very uncertain and unequal numbers) a ≈øingle Indian will kill two hundred. Notwith≈øtanding every ≈øpecies of Goo≈øe has a different call, yet the Indians are admirable in their imitation of every one.

The vernal flight of the Gee≈øe la≈øts from the middle of April until the middle of May. Their fir≈øt appearance coincides with the thawing of the ≈øwamps, when they are very lean. The autumnal, or the ≈øea≈øon of their return with their young, is from the middle of Augu≈øt to the middle of October Dobbs's Hud≈øon's Bay, 52. . Tho≈øe which are taken in this latter ≈øea≈øon, when the fro≈øts u≈øually begin, are pre≈øerved in their feathers, and left to be frozen for the fre≈øh provi≈øions of the winter ≈øtock. The feathers con≈øtitute an article of commerce, and are ≈øent into England.

div.head: 472. BEAN GOOSE.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 267.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: D. With a ≈ømall bill, much compre≈ø≈øed near the end; ba≈øe and nail black; middle of a pale red: head and neck cinereous brown, tinged with ru≈øt: brea≈øt and belly dirty white, clouded with a≈øh-color: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings very light grey: back plain a≈øh-color: ≈øcapulars darker, edged with white: primaries and ≈øecondaries grey, edged with black: tail edged with white: legs ≈øaffron-color: claws white. LENGTH two feet ≈øeven. WEIGHT ≈øix pounds and a half.

PLACE.Ob≈øerved by Mr. Hearne, in Hud≈øon's Bay. Is in Europe a northern bird. Breeds in great numbers in Lewis, one of the Hebrides, and is mo≈øt de≈øtructive to the green corn. Migrates at the latter end of Augu≈øt, in flocks innumerable, into the wolds of York≈øhire, and into Lincoln≈øhire; and among them are ≈øome white Li≈øter, in Ph. Tr. Abridg. ii. 852. I cannot but ≈øu≈øpect, that ≈øome of the SNOW GEESE, No 477, may mix with them, as none of this genus vary in color in the wild ≈øtate.. They all di≈øappear in the ≈øpring. The appearance and di≈øappearance of this kind in Au≈øtria is ≈øimilarKramer Anim. Au≈øtr. 339. . Wild Gee≈øe are ≈øeen flying over, but very rarely alight in the Orknies.

div.head: 473. GREY LAG GOOSE.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 266.‚ÄîAnas An≈øer. Willg√¢s, Faun. Suec. No 114.‚ÄîWild Goo≈øe of all authors.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p:
D. With an elevated bill, fle≈øh-colored, tinged with yellow, and with a white nail: head and neck cinereous, mixed with dirty yellow: neck ≈øtriated downwards: back and primaries du≈øky; the la≈øt tipt with black; ≈øhafts white: ≈øecondaries black, edged with white: le≈ø≈øer coverts du≈øky, edged with white: brea≈øt and belly whiti≈øh, clouded with
a≈øh-color: rump and vent white: middle feathers of the tail du≈øky, tipt and edged with white; the outmo≈øt almo≈øt entirely white: legs fle≈øh-colored: claws black. LENGTH two feet nine. EXTENT five feet. WEIGHT ≈øometimes ten pounds.

Inhabits the north of Europe, A≈øia, and America, PLACE. and migrates into Hud≈øon's Bay. Frequents, during winter, South Carolina, and particularly the rice grounds, where it gleans the droppings of the harve≈øt. This ≈øpecies breeds in the fens of Lincoln≈øhire, and never migrates from that county. They are ≈øeen, early in the ≈øpring, flying over Sweden, to the Lapland moors, and to the ea≈øtern and ≈øouthern parts of Iceland; in which quarters of that i≈øland alone they breedPaul≈øon.. Return in autumn: make a ≈øhort ≈øtay along the ≈øhores; but never winter in Sweden Amoen. Acad. iv. 585. . Abound in Ru≈ø≈øia, Sibiria, and Kamt≈øchatka; but breed chiefly in the north.

div.p: D. With a red elevated bill: crown yellowi≈øh; re≈øt of the head and neck white; the hind part of the la≈øt ≈øpotted with black; in ≈øome the ≈øpots are wanting: ba≈øe of the neck, brea≈øt, ≈øides under the wings, and back, of a deep brown: coverts of the wings and tail of a light bluei≈øh a≈øh-color: belly and vent white: primaries du≈øky: ≈øcapulars and tail white and grey, di≈øpo≈øed in ≈øtripes: legs red. In SIZE rather le≈ø≈øer than the common Tame Goo≈øe.

Migrates into Hud≈øon's Bay, and re-migrates like the former.PLACE. The Indians have a notion, that to avoid the cold, it flies towards the ≈øun, till it ≈øinges its pate again≈øt that luminary. Few go very far north; but are mo≈øt numerous about Albany Fort; where, on the contrary, the SNOW GEESE are very ≈øcarce.

div.head: 475. BERING.
div.p:
D. With a yellow excre≈øcence at the ba≈øe of the bill, radiated in the middle with bluei≈øh black feathers: round the ears a ≈øpace of greeni≈øh white: eyes black, encircled with yellow, and rayed with black: back, fore part of the neck, and belly, white: wings black: hind part of the neck bluei≈øh. SIZE of a common Wild Goo≈øe.‚ÄîSTELLER'S De≈øcr.
See De≈øcr. Kamt≈øchatka, 496, 7.

PLACE.Ob≈øerved by Mr. Steller, in July, on the i≈øle of Bering. They probably came from America. It is the remark of that great naturali≈øt, during his ≈øtay on that i≈øland, that Gee≈øe of various kinds migrated this way to and from America to A≈øia, in va≈øt flocks. In the ≈øpring they came from the we≈øt, in autumn from the ea≈øt; which proves, that the Water-Fowl of the≈øe latitudes prefer, for breeding-places, the A≈øiatic wa≈øtes to tho≈øe of America.

With a pale yellow elevated bill: forehead white: head and neck of a cinereous brown, darke≈øt on the crown: coverts of the wings grey, edged with brown: brea≈øt of an a≈øh-color, clouded with a deeper: belly white, marked with large black ≈øpots: coverts of the tail and the vent white: tail du≈øky, edged with white: legs orange.SIZE. LENGTH two feet four. EXTENT four feet ≈øix. WEIGHT five pounds and a half.

PLACE.Inhabits, during ≈øummer, Hud≈øon's Bay, and the north of Europe. Breeds al≈øo in the extreme north of A≈øia; and in its migration is very frequently ≈øcattered over Sibiria. Migrates over only the ea≈øt of Ru≈ø≈øia; and is very ≈øcarce in the we≈øt. Mr. Fabricius ≈øu≈øpects that they are found in Greenland Faun. Groenl. p. 66. .

div.head: 477. SNOW.

list.item: An≈øer Grandinis. Schnee Gans. Schwenckfelt Sile≈ø. 213.‚ÄîPhil. Tran≈ø. lxii. 413.
An≈øer Hyperboreus, Pallas Spicil. Zool. fa≈øc. vi. 26.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: D. With an elevated bill; upper mandible ≈øcarlet; lower whiti≈øh: forehead yellowi≈øh: head, neck, and body, of a ≈ønowy whitene≈øs: primaries white at the bottoms, black to the tips: le≈ø≈øer coverts u≈øually cinereous, with du≈øky tips: legs and feet deep red. The young Gee≈øe are blue, and do not attain their proper colors in le≈øs than a year. LENGTH two feet eight inches.SIZE. EXTENT three feet and a half. WEIGHT between five and ≈øix pounds.

This ≈øpecies is common to the north of A≈øia, PLACE. and to North America. They appear in flights about Severn river in Hud≈øon's Bay, in the middle of May, on their way northward; return in the beginning of September with their young, and ≈øtay about the ≈øettlement a fortnight; and proceed, about the tenth of October, flying very high, ≈øouthward to pa≈øs the winter. They come in flocks of thou≈øands; quite cover the country; ri≈øe in clouds, and with an amazing noi≈øe. They vi≈øit Carolina
Law≈øon, 147.‚ÄîQuere, The ≈øort of whiti≈øh fowl mentioned by Mr. Law≈øon, p. 150, which he calls Bull-necks, of the ≈øize of a Brant, which come to Carolina after Chri≈øtmas, and frequent the rivers: are excellent meat; but are very ≈øhy, and ≈øuch good divers, as not to be ≈øhot without difficulty? in va≈øt flocks;FOOD. and feed on the roots of ≈øedge and gra≈øs, which they tear up like hogs. It u≈øed to be a common practice in that country, to burn a piece of a mar≈øh, which enticed the Gee≈øe to come there, as they could then more readily get at the roots; which gave the ≈øport≈øman opportunity of killing as many as he plea≈øed. In Hud≈øon's Bay thou≈øands are annually ≈øhot by the Indians for the u≈øe of the ≈øettlement; and are e≈øteemed excellent meat.

They arrive in the earlie≈øt ≈øpring,MIGRATIONS. before any other ≈øpecies of Water-fowl, in immen≈øe flights, fir≈øt about the river Kolyma. Their
cour≈øe is from the ea≈øt, tending to the frozen ocean; and ≈øpreading to the e≈øtuaries of the Jana and Lena before the ice is broken up. Finding the want of ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, they bend their journey a little ≈øouthward, in ≈øearch of the in≈øects and plants which abound in the inland lakes and moors. In this manner they penetrate as low as Jakut, and very rarely farther, except in very ≈ømall detachments, which ≈øtray towards the Olecma, and ≈øometimes by accident to the junction of the Witim with the Lena. They make very little ≈øtay in tho≈øe parts; but again tend directly to the Arctic coa≈øts of Sibiria, where they breed; but they do not take the ≈øame route, keeping more ea≈øterly, towards the Jana and Indigirka. It is ob≈øervable, that they never migrate we≈øtward beyond long. 130, a little beyond the mouth of the Lena; neither is their migration by ≈øo high a latitude as Kamt≈øchatka, where they are extremely rareDe≈øcr. Kamt≈øch. 496. ; or their flight over that country may be ≈øo lofty as to render their cour≈øe imperceptible. In the beginning of winter they are ≈øeen flying at a great height over Sile≈øia; but it does not appear that they continue there, being only on their pa≈ø≈øage to ≈øome other countrySchwenkfelt An. Sile≈øiae, 215. .
The general winter quarters of this ≈øpecies ≈øeems to be the temperate and warm part of North America.

STUPIDITY.They are the mo≈øt numerous and the mo≈øt ≈øtupid of all the Goo≈øe race. They ≈øeem to want the in≈øtinct of others, by their arriving at the mouths of the Arctic A≈øiatic rivers before the ≈øea≈øon in which they can po≈ø≈øibly ≈øub≈øi≈øt. They are annually guilty of the ≈øame mi≈øtake, and annually compelled to make a new migration to the ≈øouth in que≈øt of food, where they pa≈øs their time till the northern e≈øtuaries are freed from the bonds of ice.

MANNER OF TAKING.They have ≈øo little of the ≈øhyne≈øs of other Gee≈øe, that they are taken in the mo≈øt ridiculous manner imaginable, about Jakut, and the other parts of Sibiria which they frequent. The inhabitants fir≈øt place, near the banks of the rivers, a great net, in a ≈øtrait line,
or el≈øe form a hovel of ≈økins ≈øewed together. This done, one of the company dre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf in the ≈økin of a white rein-deer, advances towards the flock of Gee≈øe, and then turns back towards the net or the hovel; and his companions go behind the flock, and, by making a noi≈øe, drive them forward. The ≈øimple birds mi≈øtake the man in white for their leader, and follow him within reach of the net, which is ≈øuddenly pulled down, and captivates the whole. When he chu≈øes to conduct them to the hovel, they follow in the ≈øame manner; he creeps in at a hole left for that purpo≈øe, and out at another on the oppo≈øite ≈øide, which he clo≈øes up. The Gee≈øe follow him through the fir≈øt; and as ≈øoon as they are got in, he pa≈ø≈øes round, and ≈øecures every oneThe Kamt≈øchatkans u≈øe the ≈øame method in taking Gee≈øe. De≈øcr. Kamt≈øchatka, 496.. In that frozen clime, they afford great ≈øub≈øi≈øtence to the natives; and the feathers are an article of commerce. Each family will kill thou≈øands in a ≈øea≈øon. The≈øe they pluck and gut; then fling them in heaps into holes dug for that purpo≈øe, and cover them with nothing more than the earth. This freezes, and forms over them an arch; and whenever the family has occa≈øion to open one of the≈øe magazines, they find their provi≈øion ≈øweet and good.

div.head: 478. BRENT.

div.p: D. With a ≈øhort, black, elevated bill: head, neck, and upper part of the brea≈øt, black: a white ≈øpot marks each ≈øide of the neck near its junction with the head: primaries and tail black: belly, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of the wings, cinereous, clouded with a deeper: coverts of tail and the vent white: legs black.

Is frequent in Hud≈øon's Bay. Breed in the i≈ølands,PLACE. and along the coa≈øts; but never fly inland. Feed about high-water mark. Return towards the ≈øouth in va≈øt flocks in autumn. Probably they winter in Carolina; for Law≈øon mentions a Grey Brent frequent in
that ≈øea≈øonLaw≈øon, 147. . During winter, they ≈øwarm in Holland and in Ireland: in the fir≈øt, every eating-hou≈øe is full of them: in the la≈øt, they are taken in flight-time, in nets placed acro≈øs the rivers; are fattened, and reckoned great delicacies. They appear in ≈ømall flocks in Hoy Sound, in the Orknies; but do not continue there: on the contrary, they winter in Horra Sound, in Schetland, in flocks of two hundred, and are called Horra Gee≈øe Reverend Mr. Low. . They retire from Europe to breed in the extreme north. A few, after flying over Sweden, ≈øtop on the borders of Lapland; but the great bodies of them continue their flight even to the mo≈øt northern i≈øles of Greenland Faun. Groenl. No 41. , and to Spitzbergen. Fly in the ≈øhape of a wedge, and with great clamor. Feed on gra≈øs, water-plants, berries, and worms. Cannot dive. Barentz found multitudes ≈øitting on their eggs, about the 21≈øt of June 1595, in the great bay called Wibe Janz Water; and, to his amazement, di≈øcovered them to be the Rotgan≈øen, which his countrymen, the Dutch, ≈øuppo≈øed to have been generated from ≈øome trees in Scotland, the fruit of which, when ripe, fell into the ≈øea, and were converted into Go≈ø≈øings Navigation par la Nord, Am≈øtelredam, 1606, folio, p. 14.‚ÄîThe Engli≈øh fabled the ≈øame of the Bernacle. See Gerard's Herbal. . The≈øe birds arrive every year in the ea≈øt part of Sibiria, in order to breed; but are not ≈øeen to the we≈øt of the Lena, nor yet in Ru≈ø≈øia.

D. With white cheeks and forehead: from bill to the eyes runs a du≈øky line; the re≈øt of the head, neck, and part of the brea≈øt, black: belly, vent, and coverts of tail, white: back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of wings, barred with black, grey, and white:
tail and legs black. LENGTH two feet one inch. EXTENT four feet five. WEIGHT about five pounds.

The≈øe birds are ≈øeen, but extremely rarely, in Hud≈øon's Bay. PLACE. It is found, and I believe breeds, in the north of Ru≈ø≈øia and Lapland, in Norway, and in Iceland Not in Greenland or Spitzbergen, as I once conjectured. See Br. Zool. ii. p. 578.; but not in Sibiria. They appear on the Briti≈øh ≈øhores and mar≈øhes, in va≈øt flocks, during winter; but retire in February. div.head: 480. EIDER.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 271.‚ÄîAnas Molli≈ø≈øima, Ada, Eider, Gudunge, Faun. Suec. No 117. ‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: D. With a black bill, ≈øomewhat elevated: forehead of a velvet black: a broad black bar, glo≈ø≈øed with purple, extends from thence beyond each eye: middle of the head, whole neck, upper part of the back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of the wings, white: below the hind part of the head is a ≈øtain of pea-green: lower part of the back, tail, brea≈øt, and whole under ≈øide of the body, black: legs greeni≈øh. The FEMALE is almo≈øt entirely of a dull ru≈øt-color, barred with black: primaries and tail du≈øky. WEIGHT of the female is about three pounds and a half. The MALE is double the ≈øize of the common Tame Duck.

Inhabits the ≈øeas near New York, in the ≈øpring ≈øea≈øon;PLACE. and breeds on the de≈øert i≈øles of New England, and from thence as far as the extreme coa≈øts of the northern world, in America, Europe, and A≈øia; but never comes within land. Common in Kamt≈øchatka. The mo≈øt ≈øouthern of its breeding-places are the Fern i≈øles, on the coa≈øt of Northumberland. Lays ≈øeldom more than five eggs; tho≈øe large, and of a pale green color. The≈øe birds afford the mo≈øt luxurious of
down, which forms, in many of the regions, a con≈øiderable article of commerce. Mo≈øt Ducks pluck off a certain down to form its ne≈øt: the≈øe have the greate≈øt quantity, and the fine≈øt and mo≈øt ela≈øtic. It is cu≈øtomary in ≈øome places to take away the fir≈øt eggs, which occa≈øions a ≈øecond laying, and a ≈øecond deplumation. In Greenland they lay among the gra≈øs; in Sweden among the juniper bu≈øhes. Nature hath furni≈øhed them with ≈øo warm a cloathing, that they brave the ≈øevere≈øt winter, even of the Arctic regions. In Greenland, they are ≈øeen in that ≈øea≈øon by hundreds, or even thou≈øands, in the ≈øheltered ≈øouthern bays: their breeding-places are in the mo≈øt northern. They take their young on their backs in≈øtantly to ≈øea, then dive, to ≈øhake them off and teach them to ≈øhift for them≈øelves. It is ≈øaid, that the males are five years old before they come to their full color? that they live to a great age; and will at length grow quite grey. They are con≈øtant to their breeding-places: a pair has been ob≈øerved to occupy the ≈øame ne≈øt twenty years. They dive to great depths for their food, which is ≈øhells of all kinds. The Greenlanders kill them with darts; pur≈øue them in their little boats; watch their cour≈øe (when they dive) by the air-bubbles; and ≈øtrike them when they ari≈øe wearied. The fle≈øh is valued as a food. The ≈økin of this and the next ≈øpecies is the mo≈øt valuable of all, as a garment placed next to the ≈økin.

div.head: 481. KING.

list.item: Grey-headed Duck, Edw. 154.‚ÄîAnas Spectabilis, Faun. Suec. No 112.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p:
D. With a red bill, extending high up the forehead on each ≈øide, in form of a broad bean-≈øhaped plate: head, and part of the hind part of the neck, light grey, bounded by a line of black dots: cheeks and neck, as low as the grey color, pea-green: a narrow black line from the bar of the bill bounds the lower part of the cheeks: throat, neck, and brea≈øt, white: back, belly, and tail, black: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings, and primaries, du≈øky brown: ≈øecondaries black, glo≈ø≈øed with rich purple; coverts above them form
a great bed of white: legs dirty red. SIZE near double of the MALLARD. The FEMALE differs greatly in color, being mo≈øtly black and brown: the belly du≈øky: the plate on the bill ≈ølightly eminent.

This ≈øpecies is found in Hud≈øon's Bay; and, in winter,PLACE. as low as New York. Is as common in Greenland as the Eider. Yields almo≈øt as much down, and is as u≈øeful to the natives: has the ≈øame haunts, and is taken in the ≈øame manner. Inhabits the coa≈øt of Norway, and even has been killed in the Orknies. Is frequent on the Arctic ≈øhores of Sibiria, and extends to Kamt≈øchatka.

div.head: 482. VELVET.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 272.‚ÄîAnas Fu≈øca, Sw√¢rta, Faun. Suec. No 109.
La grande Macreu≈øe, Pl. Enl. 956.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: D. With a broad bill, elevated near the ba≈øe; black in the middle; yellow on the ≈øides; the nail red: behind each eye Read eye, in the Br. Zool. in≈øtead of ear. is a white ≈øpot: a bar of the ≈øame color cro≈ø≈øes each wing: all the plumage be≈øides is of a rich velvet black: legs red. The FEMALE is of a deep brown; but marked, like the male, with white.

Frequents the ≈øeas about New York. PLACE. Is very common in the great lakes and rivers of the north and ea≈øt of Sibiria, and on the ≈øhores. Extends to Kamt≈øchatka. Is le≈øs common in Ru≈ø≈øia. Lays from eight to ten white eggs. Notwith≈øtanding they are Ducks which at all other times frequent the ≈øea, yet, in the laying ≈øea≈øon, go far inland, and make their ne≈øts: as ≈øoon as that ta≈øk is over, the males fly away; but as ≈øoon as the young can fly, they are rejoined by their mates; followed by the broodSteller, in Nov. Com. Petrop. iv. 421.‚ÄîStrom. p. 230. .

With a compre≈ø≈øed bill, ri≈øing into a knob at the ba≈øe, each ≈øide of which is marked with a patch of black; middle white; ≈øides of a deep orange; the edges black; nail red: fore part of the head white: crown and cheeks black: ju≈øt beneath the hind part of the head, the neck is marked with a large white ≈øpot: re≈øt of the plumage of a dull black: legs and toes bright red; webs black. WEIGHT two pounds two ounces. LENGTH twenty-one inches. EXTENT thirty-five. The FEMALE is twenty inches long: of a ≈øooty color: has no white on the hind part of the head; but the cheeks are marked with two dull white ≈øpots.

PLACE.Appears in Hud≈øon's Bay as ≈øoon as the rivers are free from ice. Breed along the ≈øhores: make their ne≈øts with gra≈øs, and line them with feathers. Lay from four to ≈øix white eggs: hatch in the end of July. Feed on gra≈øs. Extends to New York, and even to South Carolina Cate≈øby, App. .

PLACE.Sent to Mrs. Blackburn, from New York. Abounds on the great lakes and rivers of the north and ea≈øt of Sibiria, and on the ≈øhores; but is le≈øs frequent in Ru≈ø≈øia. Inhabits Sweden and Norway Law≈øon, 151. . Lives much at ≈øea. Is of a very fi≈øhy ta≈øte.

Plumage of the FEMALE like that of the common Wild Duck; only the coverts of the wings are of the ≈øame colors with tho≈øe of the Drake. LENGTH twenty-one inches. WEIGHT twenty-two ounces.

Found about New York, and even as low as Carolina, PLACE. during winter. Is common in Kamt≈øchatka; and breeds in every latitude of the Ru≈ø≈øian dominions; but chiefly in the north. Inhabits Sweden and Norway. We are to ≈øeek for the Swaddle Bill, an a≈øh-colored Duck of Carolina, with an extraordinary broad bill, ≈øaid not to be very common there, but to be very good food; we mu≈øt therefore join it, for the pre≈øent, to this ≈øpecies.

WEIGHT two pounds.

PLACE.Inhabits from New York to Greenland: in the la≈øt is very rare; and arrives in the bay on the breaking up of the ice: di≈øappears on the return of fro≈øt. Frequents fre≈øh-water lakes: makes a regular ne≈øt of gra≈øs, and feathers from its own brea≈øt. Lays from ≈øeven to ten white eggs. Is expelled Sweden by the fro≈øt, except a few which haunt the unfrozen parts of rivers near the cataracts: there they live, diving continually for ≈øhells. Extends to Norway.

div.p: ‚Ä¢ With a black bill: crown and fore part of the head of a glo≈ø≈øy black, varying with green and purple: throat and upper part of the neck encircled with the ≈øame: cheeks and hind part of the head white: lower half of the neck, brea≈øt, belly, and ≈øcapulars, white: primaries, ≈øecondaries, and tertials, du≈øky; upper ends of the ≈øecondaries white; coverts incumbent on them white; on the others du≈øky: back and tail du≈øky: legs orange. In the FEMALE the head and upper part of the neck du≈øky: a large white oblong ≈øpot marks the ≈øides of the head, beginning behind each eye: back, tail, primaries, and le≈ø≈øer coverts, du≈øky: great coverts and ≈øecondaries white: brea≈øt and belly dirty white: legs orange. SIZE of a Wigeon.

PLACE.Inhabits North America, from Hud≈øon's Bay to Carolina. Called ≈øometimes the Spirit, as is ≈øuppo≈øed, from its ≈øuddenly appearing again at a di≈øtance, after diving. Vi≈øits Severn river, in Hud≈øon's Bay, in June: and makes its ne≈øt in trees, among the woods near fre≈øh waters.

div.head: 488. PIED.
div.p: D. With the lower part of the bill black, the upper yellow: on the ≈øummit of the head is an oblong black ≈øpot: forehead, cheeks, re≈øt of the head, and neck, white; the lower part encircled with black: ≈øcapulars and coverts of wings white: back, brea≈øt, belly, and primaries, black: tail cuneiform, and du≈øky: legs black. The bill of the ≈øuppo≈øed FEMALE? re≈øembles that of the male: head and neck mottled with cinereous brown and dirty white: primaries du≈øky: ≈øpeculum white: back, brea≈øt, and belly, clouded with different ≈øhades of a≈øh-color: tail du≈øky and cuneiform: legs black. SIZE of a common Wild Duck.

Sent from Connecticut, to Mrs. Blackburn. PLACE. Po≈ø≈øibly the great flocks of pretty Pied Ducks, which whi≈øtled as they flew, or as they fed, ≈øeen by Mr. Law≈øon Hi≈øt. Carolina, 148. in the we≈øtern branch of Cape Fear inlet, were of this kind.

div.head: 489. BUFFEL.

With a ≈øhort blue bill: head va≈øtly increa≈øed in ≈øize by the fullne≈øs of the feathers; black, richly glo≈ø≈øed with green and purple: neck white all round: upper part of the brea≈øt pure white; lower, and belly, clouded with pale brown: back, primaries, and ≈øecondaries, black: the coverts on the ridge of the wings mottled, bounding the others, which form a great bed of white: tail cinereous: legs orange.

With a ≈ømall black bill: between the ba≈øe and the eyes a great white patch: crown black, bounded by a light ru≈øty line: cheeks, chin, and neck, black; beneath each a white ≈øpot; below that a ≈øhort line of white, pointing down the neck: bottom of the neck, on each ≈øide, bounded by a tran≈øver≈øe line of white; beneath which is another of black: brea≈øt, back, ≈øcapulars, and part of the belly, of a plea≈øant ≈ølate-color: brea≈øt on each ≈øide marked with ≈øemilunar ≈øtripes of white, beginning at the ≈øhoulders, and bounded on each ≈øide with a ≈øtripe of black: wings and tail deep a≈øh: rump, above and below, of a full black‚ñ™ legs black. The FEMALE is almo≈øt wholly du≈øky, and is marked at the ba≈øe of the bill with a white ≈øpot, and another behind each ear. SIZE of a Wigeon.

PLACE.Inhabits from Carolina to Greenland: in the la≈øt frequents, during ≈øummer, the rapid rivers, and the mo≈øt ≈øhady parts. Ne≈øtles on the banks, among the low ≈øhrubs. Swims and dives admirably. In winter ≈øeeks the open ≈øea. Flies high and ≈øwiftly, and is very clamorous. Feeds on ≈øhell-fi≈øh, ≈øpawn, and the larvae of gnats. Is found in Iceland, and as low as Sondmor Strom. 243. . Is common from the lake Baikal to Kamt≈øchatka: breeds there, as well as every where el≈øe, about the mo≈øt rocky and rapid torrents.

div.head: 491. POCHARD.

D. With a lead-colored bill: head and neck bright bay: brea≈øt and upper part of the back black: re≈øt of the back, ≈øcapulars, and coverts of wings, pale grey, ≈øtreaked tranver≈øely with lines of black:

EXTENT two feet and a half. WEIGHT one pound twelve ounces.

Inhabits North America, in winter, as low as Carolina Cate≈øby, App. ; and,PLACE. I believe, is the Red-headed Duck of Law≈øon. Is found, in Europe, as high as Drontheim. Is met with in the great rivers and lakes in all latitudes of the Ru≈ø≈øian empire. A fre≈øh-water Duck, and of excellent ta≈øte.

div.head: 492. WHISTLING.

list.item: Black-billed Whi≈øtling Duck, Edw. 193Probably not the female of Edwards's Duck, 194..‚ÄîLatham, iii.
Anas Arborea, Lin. Sy≈øt. 207.‚ÄîWhi≈øtlers, Cate≈øby, App. xxxvii.‚ÄîLaw≈øon Carolina, 149.‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: D. With a black bill, and crown ≈ølightly cre≈øted: cheeks brown: hind part of the neck du≈øky; fore part white, ≈øpotted with black: back and wings brown; coverts ≈øpotted with black: tail and its coverts black: brea≈øt of a dark reddi≈øh color, ≈øpotted with black: belly white, mixed on the ≈øides with black: legs long, and of a lead-color; hind claw placed high up the leg. Le≈ø≈øer than a Tame Duck. De≈øcribed from Mr. Edwards.

Inhabits South Carolina and Jamaica. Is, from its voice,PLACE. called the Whi≈øtling Duck: perches on trees. Placed here merely on the authority of the name given it by Law≈øon and Cate≈øby. The la≈øt ≈øays, that it frequents the coa≈øts of Carolina during winter; which makes me doubt, whether Mr. Edwards's bird, a native of Jamaica, is the ≈øame: for it may be held as a rule, that the water-fowl of hot climates never retire in winter to colder; and that tho≈øe of Arctic climates almo≈øt generally retire from them into warmer. Clouds of birds annually quit Hud≈øon's Bay, and other ≈øevere climates, at approach of winter; ≈øtock the different latitudes of North America;
and return in ≈øpring to encrea≈øe and multiply. To the con≈øtitutions of the SUMMER DUCK, a very few other water-fowl, and to many land-birds, the warm temperature of the Carolinas is climate ≈øufficiently north. They are driven, by the exce≈ø≈øive heat and arid ≈øoil of the Antilles and Guiana, to the moi≈øt ≈øavannas and woods of the≈øe provinces, there to di≈øcharge the fir≈øt great command.

div.head: 493. SUMMER.

div.p: D. With the ridge and nail of the upper mandible black; lower part ≈øcarlet: on the head a beautiful cre≈øt, hanging half down the neck, and beginning at the ba≈øe of the bill; upper part ≈øhining purple; beneath that a line of white; then ≈øucceeds purple; and that again is bounded by white: cheeks purpli≈øh and green: throat, and part of the neck, pure white: from the hind part of the neck a bead of purple divides the white, and points towards the throat: re≈øt of the neck and brea≈øt ferruginous, ≈øpotted with white triangular ≈øpots: belly white: feathers of the ≈øides, which hide part of the wings, elegantly marked downwards with incurvated lines of black and white: back deep brown, glo≈ø≈øed with copper and green: primaries du≈øky: ≈øecondaries re≈øplendent blue: coverts of the tail, and tail it≈øelf, du≈øky, glo≈ø≈øed with green: legs dirty orange. Head of the FEMALE of a deep brown; cre≈øted, but not ≈øo much as the Drake: back deep brown: cheeks brown: behind each eye a white ≈øpot: throat white: neck and brea≈øt reddi≈øh brown, with white ≈øagittal ≈øpots: belly white. LENGTH, from the bill to the tip of the tail, near nineteen inches. EXTENT about thirty.

PLACE.This mo≈øt elegant ≈øpecies is found from New York to the Antilles, and al≈øo in Mexico. It pa≈ø≈øes the ≈øummer in Carolina; and in a ≈øingular manner makes its ne≈øt in the holes made by Woodpeckers in the loftie≈øt trees, which grow near the water, e≈øpecially the deciduous cypre≈øs. When the young are hatched, they are conveyed
down on the backs of the old ones, to whom the Ducklings adhere clo≈øely with their bills. It often ne≈øtles on the bodies or boughs of trees which have fallen over the ≈øtreams which run up the woods. It appears in New York, in the latter end of February or beginning of March, and retires towards the ≈øouth at approach of winter. They are very delicate eating. The Mexicans call it Yztactzonyayauhqui, or the bird of the various-colored head. It is there migratory. The natives feign that, from the ≈øituation of its legs, it cannot ≈øtand.

div.head: 494. MALLARD.

list.item: Br. Zool. ii. No 279.‚ÄîAnas Bo≈øchas. GraÃÑs-and, BlaÃÑnacke, Faun. Suec. No 131.‚Äî Ph. Tran≈ø. lxii. 419.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 776, 777.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS. ‚ÄîBL. MUS.

With a bill of a yellowi≈øh green: head and neck of a ≈øhining changeable green: on the front of the lower part of the neck is a ≈øemicircle of white: brea≈øt of a purpli≈øh red: lower part of the back, and belly, grey, cro≈ø≈øed with ≈øpeckled lines of black: ≈øpeculum purple: four middle feathers of the tail curled upwards: legs ≈øaffron-colored. FEMALE is of a pale reddi≈øh brown, ≈øpotted with black. LENGTH twenty-three inches. EXTENT thirty-five. WEIGHT about two pounds and a half.

Inhabits the northern parts of North America, PLACE. from Hud≈øon's Bay to Carolina Cate≈øby, App. : is frequent in Greenland, and continues there the whole year. Arrives in Hud≈øon's Bay in May: retires in October. Is common in all latitudes of the Ru≈ø≈øian empire: and was ob≈øerved by Steller in the Aleutian i≈ølands. In Sweden retires in winter to the ≈øhores of Schonen; but in ≈øevere ≈øea≈øons pa≈ø≈øes over to Denmark and Germany, po≈ø≈øibly to England; for this i≈øland can hardly ≈øupply the va≈øt wintery flocks.

With a large du≈øky blue bill; on the ba≈øe of the upper mandible a great triangular orange-colored ≈øpot: head, as far as the eyes, hind part of the neck, and back, of a mixed grey, inclining to yellow: fore part and ≈øides of the neck white: belly of the ≈øame color, ≈øpotted with darker: le≈ø≈øer coverts of the wings, and primaries, du≈øky; great coverts green, tipt with black: ≈øecondaries dull yellow: legs lead-colored. In SIZE ≈øomewhat le≈øs than the common Tame Duck.

PLACE.Inhabits the Bahama i≈ølands; but is very rare: extends to the Bra≈øils, where the Indians call it Marecu Marcgrave, 214. . This ≈øpecies, the Summer Duck, and the Whi≈øtling Duck, Edw. 193, perch and roo≈øt on trees; and are among the few of this cla≈øs which do not migrate northward to breed.

div.head: 496. DUSKY.
div.p: D. With a long and narrow du≈øky bill, tinged with blue: crown du≈øky: chin white: neck pale brown, ≈øtreaked downwards with du≈øky lines: back, and coverts of the wings, deep brown: brea≈øt and belly of the ≈øame color, edged with dirty yellow: primaries du≈øky: ≈øpeculum of a fine blue, bounded above with a black bar: tail cuneiform; du≈øky, edged with white: legs in one ≈øpecimen du≈øky, in another yellow. LENGTH near two feet.
PLACE.From the province of New York.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.head: 497. WESTERN.

D. With the head, cheeks, and upper part of the neck, white: between the bill and the eyes a mallard-green ≈øpot; another acro≈øs the hind part of the head: chin and throat of a full black:
around the neck a black glo≈ø≈øy color: back of the ≈øame color: coverts of the wings white: primaries du≈øky: ≈øecondaries black, tipt with white: brea≈øt and ≈øides of a light yellowi≈øh brown: belly, vent, and tail, black. SIZE of a Wigeon.

Brought by the late navigators from the we≈øtern ≈øide of America; PLACE. but had been before di≈øcovered by Steller to breed among the inacce≈ø≈øible rocks about Kamt≈øchatka; to flyin flocks, and never to enter the mouths of rivers.

div.p:
D. With bill black, orange in the middle: forehead, ≈øides of the head, and neck, pale brown, da≈øhed with ro≈øe-color: beneath each ear a large du≈øky ≈øpot points downwards: hind part of the head and neck, throat, and brea≈øt, white: back and belly black: ≈øides and vent feathers white: ≈øcapulars long and white: coverts of the wings glo≈ø≈øy black: primaries du≈øky: ≈øecondaries dark ru≈øty brown: two middle feathers of the tail black, and four inches longer than the others, which are white: legs red. FEMALE; crown du≈øky: cheeks
white: re≈øt of the head, neck, back, and brea≈øt, coverts of the wings, and primaries, deep brown: ≈øcapulars and ≈øecondaries ru≈øty: belly white: tail and legs like tho≈øe of the MALE.

Inhabits to the extreme north.PLACE. Breeds in Hud≈øon's Bay and Greenland, among the ≈øtones and gra≈øs: makes its ne≈øt, like the Eider, with the down of its own brea≈øt; which is equal in value to that of the Eider, if it could be got in equal quantity; but the ≈øpecies is ≈øcareer. It lays five eggs: ≈øwims and dives admirably: and feeds on ≈øhell-fi≈øh, which it gets in very deep water. Flies irregularly, ≈øometimes ≈øhewing its back, ≈øometimes its belly. Continues in Greenland the whole year, in unfrozen placesFaun. Groenl. p. 73. : but there are ≈øea≈øons ≈øo very ≈øevere, as at times to force them towards the ≈øouth. Tho≈øe which breed between Lapland and the polar circle, are often driven into Sweden, and the neighborhood of Peter≈øburg: tho≈øe from the coa≈øt of the Icy ≈øea, as low as lat. 55; but on the ≈øetting in of fro≈øt, retire ≈øtill further ≈øouth, unle≈øs where ≈øome open ≈øpots remain in the rivers. Vi≈øit the fre≈øh-water lakes in the Orknies, in October, and continue there till April. At ≈øun-≈øet they are ≈øeen, in great flocks, returning to and from the bays, where they frequently pa≈øs the night, and make ≈øuch a noi≈øe as to be heard ≈øome miles in fro≈øty weather. Their ≈øound is like Aan-gitche, and is ≈øaid not to be di≈øagreeable. Steller, who ob≈øerved them in Kamt≈øchatka De≈øcr. du Kamt≈øchatka, 498. , ≈øays, that their larynx has three openings, covered with a thin (I ≈øupo≈øe valvular) membrane, which forms the ≈øingularity of the voice. La Sarcelle de Feroe, or the Feroe Teal, of M. Bri≈ø≈øon vi. 466. tab. xl.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 999., is probably conjectured, by M. Brunnich, to be only a variety of this ≈øpecies: ≈øeemingly a female.

In Virginia, where there is no rice, it feeds on wild oats. Is reckoned mo≈øt delicious meat. Extends as far ≈øouth as Guiana.
