div.p: D. With head and upper part of the neck of a fine deep bay: from each eye to the hind part of the head is a broad bar of rich changeable green: wants the white line, which the European kind has above each eye, having only one below: lower part of the neck and brea≈øt dirty white, beautifully ≈øpotted with black: has over each ≈øhoulder a lunated bar, another di≈øtinction from our ≈øpecies: coverts of wings brown: upper part of the back marked with waved lines of white and black; lower part brown: tail du≈øky: ≈øpeculum green: legs du≈øky. Plumage of the FEMALE of a browni≈øh a≈øh, tinged with red, and ≈øpotted with black: wings re≈øemble tho≈øe of the male.

Inhabits America, as high as Hud≈øon's Bay, and as low as Carolina. PLACE. Is found plentifully about Severn river, in the woods and plains near the fre≈øh waters; and has from five to ≈øeven young at a time. Di≈øappears in autumn: and is found, during winter, as low as Carolina, and perhaps Jamaica. We ≈øeem here to have recovered the SUMMER TEAL of Mr. Willughby Ornith. 378. , to which the American kind has great affinity. He calls it the le≈øt of Ducks: and mu≈øt be the ≈øame with the ≈øecond kind de≈øcribed by Law≈øon Hi≈øt. Carol. 149. as frequenting fre≈øh waters; being le≈ø≈øer than the common ≈øort, and always nodding their heads.
A. GREAT GOOSE. With a black bill, tawny at the ba≈øe: a du≈øky body; white beneath: ≈øcarlet legs. Of a va≈øt SIZE, weighing near twenty-five or thirty Ru≈ø≈øian pounds.

PLACE.This ≈øpecies is found in the ea≈øt of Sibiria, from the Lena to Kamt≈øchatka: and is taken in great numbers, together with the RED-NECKED GOOSE,TAKEN IN GLADES. in glades, as we do Woodcocks in England. The Gee≈øe in the day-time repair to the corn-fields and meadows: in the evening re≈øort to the lakes, to wa≈øh them≈øelves and pa≈øs the night. The Sibirians generally fix on a place where there are two or three lakes near each other, and out between each an avenue through the thick birch woods of the country. If there is not the advantage of adjacent lakes, the avenue is made through the woods which border the ≈øides of any which the birds frequent. At the entrance of the glades, on each ≈øide, a tall birch-tree is left ≈øtanding, and all their branches ≈øtripped away: from the tops of the≈øe naked trees is placed a ≈øtrong net, which fills the breadth of the avenue: this net is capable of being dropped or rai≈øed at plea≈øure, by means of certain long cords which run along the top; and the ends of which are held by a man who conceals him≈øelf in the high gra≈øs. The Gee≈øe commonly leave the lakes an hour before ≈øun-ri≈øe; and, as they do not chu≈øe to fly high at that ≈øea≈øon, prefer going through the avenues; and with their long extended necks ≈øtrike into the nets, which are ≈øuddenly dropped; and twenty, and often more, of the Gee≈øe are taken at a time. All ≈øorts of Ducks, and other water-fowl, are taken in the ≈øame mannerPALLAS's Travels, ii. 325, 326..

div.p: OUR ≈øpecies in all re≈øpects re≈øembles the American, except in having a white line above and beneath each eye, and in wanting the humeral ≈øtripe of white, which the latter has.

In Europe it is found as high as Iceland; PLACE. and even in that ≈øevere climate lays from thirteen to nineteen eggsBiornc's Li≈øt.. The American ≈øpecies appears to be far le≈øs prolific. Found in the Ru≈ø≈øian empire, in the ≈øame places with the GARGANEY.

div.head: LVIII. PELECANThis genus, in the Br. Zool. is called by the more familiar name of Corvorant, there being none of the Pelecan ≈øpecies in Britain. . Gen. Birds, XCIII.
505. GREAT.

list.item: Pelecanus Onocratolus, Lin. Sy≈øt. 215.‚ÄîEdw. 92.‚ÄîPh. Tran≈ø. lxii. 419.
Le Pelican, De Buffon, viii. 282.‚ÄîPl. Enl. 87.‚ÄîLatham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.

div.p: P. With a bill fifteen inches long, flat, dilated near the point, with a hook at the end, and a ridge from that to the ba≈øe running along the middle; on the midway of the ridge ri≈øes a bony proce≈øs, an inch and ≈øeven tenths high, three inches broad at the ba≈øe, and only two tenths of an inch thick. In ≈øome are ≈øeveral le≈ø≈øer proce≈ø≈øes between this and the point: a va≈øt naked membranaceous pouch extends from the point of the lower mandible, widening gradually, and extending ten inches down the front of the neck: on the hind part of the head is a tuft of very narrow delicate feathers, not very di≈øcernible, as they u≈øually lie flat: the re≈øt of the head and neck is covered with mo≈øt exqui≈øitely fine down, and very thick ≈øet: the re≈øt of the plumage white, except the primaries and ba≈øtard wings, which are black: legs fle≈øh-color. The large≈øt of web-footed Water-Fowl. Some are ≈øuperior in SIZE to a SWAN. One was killed off Majorca, which weighed twenty-five pounds. Their extent of wings from eleven to fifteen feet. Notwith≈øtanding their great bulk, they ≈øoar to a mo≈øt ≈øurpri≈øing height. This is owing to the amazing lightne≈øs of the bones, which, all together, do not weigh a pound and a half. Add to this, the quantity of air with which its body is filled, which gives it a wonderful ≈øpecific lightne≈øs.

PLACE.One of the birds from which this de≈øcription was taken, was ≈øhot at Augu≈øta in South Carolina, a hundred and fifty miles from the
≈øea. It agrees entirely with the Pelecan of the old continent, except in the bony proce≈ø≈øes on the bill. The other was ≈øent, with other birds, from Hud≈øon's Bay, to the Royal Society. In≈øtead of the bony proce≈ø≈øes on the bill, was a tuft or fibrous fringe, ≈øufficient to identify the ≈øpecies. This ≈øpecies extends over mo≈øt parts of the torrid zone, and many parts of the warmer temperate. Is found in Europe on the lower parts of the Danube, and in all parts of the Mediterranean ≈øea, almo≈øt all Africa, and A≈øia Minor. Are ≈øeen in incredible numbers about the Black and Ca≈øpian ≈øeas; and come far up the rivers, and into the inland lakes of the A≈øiatic Ru≈ø≈øian empire; but grow ≈øcarcer ea≈øtward, and are ≈øeldom met with ≈øo far north as the Sibirian lakes; yet are not unknown about that of Baikal. They are common on the coa≈øt of New Holland, where they grow to an enormous ≈øizeCook's Fir≈øt Voy. iii. 627. . They feed upon fi≈øh; which they take ≈øometimes by plunging from a great height in the air, and ≈øeizing, like the GANNET: at other times, they fi≈øh in concert, ≈øwimming in flocks, and forming a large circle in the great rivers, which they gradually contract, beating the water with their wings and feet, in order to drive the fi≈øh into the center; which when they approach, they open their va≈øt mouths, and fill their pouches with their prey, then incline their bills, to empty the bag of the water; after which they ≈øwim to ≈øhore, and eat their booty in quiet. As the pouch is capable of holding a dozen quarts of water, a gue≈øs may be made of the quantity of fi≈øhes it can contain. The French very properly call them Grand-go≈øiers, or Great-throats. It is ≈øaid that when they make their ne≈øts in the dry de≈øerts, they carry the water to their young in their va≈øt pouches, and that the lions and bea≈øts of prey come there to quench their thir≈øt, ≈øparing the young, the cau≈øe of this ≈øalutary provi≈øion. Po≈ø≈øibly, on this account, the Egyptians ≈øtyle this bird the Camel of the River; the Per≈øians, Tacab, or the Water-carrier.

div.head: 506. DUSKY.

div.p: P. With a red bill and black hook: the pouch extending half way down the neck: between the bill and eyes naked and red: head mottled with a≈øh-color and white: the nape ≈ølightly cre≈øted: hind part of the neck covered with ≈øoft cinereous feathers: back, ≈øcapulars, primaries, and coverts, du≈øky, edged with dirty white: tail deep a≈øh: legs du≈øky green. In SIZE ≈øcarcely equal to a SWAN.

PLACE.Inhabits, during ≈øummer, Hud≈øon's Bay. One was ≈øent to Mrs. Blackburn, ≈øhot near New York, I think in the winter. Extends to Loui≈øiana Du Pratz, ii. 79. ; to Jamaica, the bay of Campechy Dampier's Voy. Campechy, 70. , and as low as Carthagena. They ≈øit on rocks in the ≈øea in a ≈øluggi≈øh manner, with their bills re≈øting on their brea≈øts.

div.head: 507. CHARLES-TOWN.
div.p: P. Du≈øky above: white on the brea≈øt and belly, with a pouch, beginning at the chin, and reaching to the brea≈øt-bone, capable of containing numbers of gallons of liquids. SIZE of a Canada Goo≈øe.

div.p: P. With head and neck black, glo≈ø≈øed like ≈øilk with green: the back and coverts of wings of the ≈øame color, edged with purpli≈øh black: belly du≈øky and dull; the middle cinereous: tail con≈øi≈øts of twelve feathers, du≈øky, glo≈ø≈øed with green: legs black: middle claw ≈øerrated. LENGTH two feet ≈øix. EXTENT three feet eight. WEIGHT four pounds.
Frequent in many parts of Great Britain. Found in Sweden, PLACE. Norway, and Iceland.

div.head: 509. CORVORANT.

list.item: Br. Zool. No 293.‚ÄîPelecanus Carvo, Haffs-tjader, Faun. Suec. No 145.‚Äî Latham, iii. ‚ÄîLEV. MUS.‚ÄîBL. MUS.

div.p: P. With a narrow bill, hooked at the end: a ≈ømall dilatable pouch under the chin; feathers at its ba≈øe white, in the male: head and neck of a ≈øooty blackne≈øs, ≈øometimes ≈øtreaked with white: coverts of wings, back, and ≈øcapulars, deep green, edged with black, glo≈ø≈øed with blue: brea≈øt and belly black: on the thighs of the male a tuft of white: tail con≈øi≈øts of fourteen feathers, and is rounded. WEIGHT ≈øeven pounds. LENGTH three feet four. EXTENT four feet two.

Extends over all parts of the northern hemi≈øphere,PLACE. even to Greenland, where it continues all the year. The natives u≈øe the jugular pouch as a bladder to float their darts after they are flung. The ≈økins are u≈øed in cloathing; the fle≈øh is eaten;GREENLAND. but the eggs are ≈øo fetid as to be rejected, even by the very Greenlanders. The≈øe birds are taken either by darts on the water; by ≈ønares dropt down the precipices, and placed before their haunts; or, in winter, they are taken while a≈øleep upon the ice. Are found in all the temperate latitudes of the Ru≈ø≈øian empire,RUSSIAN EMPIRE. and in immen≈øe numbers on the ≈øhores of the Ca≈øpian ≈øea Extracts. i. 164.‚Äîii. 405.. Reach even to Kamt≈øchatka. I believe this to be the
the kind which the Chine≈øe train for fi≈øhing. They keep numbers, which ≈øit on the edge of their boats; and, on a ≈øignal given, plunge under water, and bring up their prey, which they are unable to ≈øwallow, by rea≈øon of a ring placed by their ma≈øters round their necksDu Halde, i. 316. .

Mrs. Blackburn received this ≈øpecies from New York. There are great flocks in Carolina, e≈øpecially in March and April, when the herrings run up the creeks; at which time they ≈øit fi≈øhing on the logs of wood which have fallen into the waterLaw≈øon, 150. .

div.p: P. With a ≈øtrait dirty white bill, jagged at the edges: beneath the chin a naked black ≈økin, dilatable ≈øo as to contain five or ≈øix herrings: hind part of the head buff-colored: ba≈øtard wings and primaries du≈øky: all the re≈øt of the plumage pure white: toes black, marked before with a pea-green ≈øtripe: feathers of the tail ≈øharp-pointed. list.item: C. RED-FACED CORVORANT. Ouril of the Kamt≈øchatkans, De≈øcr. de la Kamt≈øchatka, 493.‚ÄîLatham, iii.

div.p: P. With a ≈ølender bill; upper mandible black; lower red: from the bill to the eyes is a ≈øpace covered with a bluei≈øh red naked ≈økin: round each eye a white cutaneous circle: head cre≈øted: head, neck, and middle of the back, of a deep glo≈ø≈øy green: on the fore part of the neck a few white ≈ølender feathers: ≈øides of the back and ≈øcapulars glo≈ø≈øed with purple: wings du≈øky: belly glo≈ø≈øed with green: tail, con≈øi≈øting of twelve feathers only, is du≈øky: over each thigh is a tuft of white feathers: legs black. LENGTH of one I mea≈øured thirty-one inches. Steller compares its ≈øize to that of a Goo≈øe.

PLACE.Inhabits the high precipices on the coa≈øts of Kamt≈øchatka. Is very ≈ølow in ri≈øing; but when on wing, flies mo≈øt rapidly. Feeds on fi≈øh. During night they ≈øit in rows on the cliffs, and often in their ≈øleep fall off, and become the prey of Arctic Foxes; who lie in
wait for the≈øe birds, which are a favorite food of tho≈øe animals. They lay in June. Their eggs are green, and of the ≈øize of tho≈øe of a Hen. They are very bad ta≈øted, and are not ea≈øily dre≈ø≈øed; yet are ≈øo acceptable to the Kamt≈øchatkans, that, at the hazard of their necks, they will climb to the mo≈øt dangerous places in ≈øearch of them, and often fall and lo≈øe their lives. They catch the≈øe birds with nets, in which they are entangled in the places where they re≈øt. They are al≈øo caught in ≈ønares, with a running noo≈øe hung to the end of a pole, with which the fowlers creep quietly towards the birds, and fling it round their necks, and draw them up the rock. The re≈øt of the flock are ≈øo ≈øtupid, that, notwith≈øtanding they ≈øee the fate of their companions, they remain, ≈øhaking their heads, on the ≈øame ≈øpot, till they are all taken. The fle≈øh is exce≈ø≈øively hard and ≈øinewy. The Kamt≈øchatkans cook it after their fa≈øhion, by putting the bird, without plucking or gutting, into a hole filled with fire: and when it is done enough, draw off the ≈økin, and make on it a ≈øavory repa≈øt.

HAVING gone through the cla≈øs of birds, let me remark, that there is the greate≈øt probability, that numbers of tho≈øe of Kamt≈øchatka are common to North America; and that they pa≈øs there the ≈øea≈øons of migration; but not having actual proof of their being found on the new continent, I am obliged to place them in the≈øe appendages to each genus. The time may come, when it will be found nece≈ø≈øary to remove them into the American ≈øections. It is al≈øo likely, that numbers may ≈øeek a more ≈øouthern retreat, and ≈øtock Japan and China with their periodical flocks. I have done as much as the lights of my days have furni≈øhed me with. In ≈øome remote age, when the Briti≈øh offspring will have pervaded the whole of their va≈øt continent, or the de≈øcendants of the hardy Ru≈ø≈øians colonized the we≈øtern parts from their di≈øtant Kamt≈øchatka, the road in future time to new
conque≈øts: after, perhaps, bloody conte≈øts between the progeny of Britons and Ru≈ø≈øians, about countries to which neither have any right; after the deaths of thou≈øands of clamants, and the extirpation of the poor natives by the ≈øword, and new-imported di≈øea≈øes, a quiet ≈øettlement may take place, civilization en≈øue, and the arts of peace be cultivated: learning, the luxury of the ≈øoul, diffu≈øe it≈øelf through the nation, and ≈øome naturali≈øt ari≈øe, who, with ≈øpirit and abilities, may explore each boundary of the ocean which ≈øeparates the A≈øiatic and American continents; may render certain what I can only ≈øu≈øpect; and, by his ob≈øervations on the feathered tribe, their flights and migrations, give utility to mankind, in naval and oeconomical operations, by auguries which the antients knew well to apply to the benefit of their fellow-creatures. He may, perhaps, ≈ømile on the labors of the Arctic Zoologi≈øt (if by that time they are not quite ob≈øolete); and, as the animate creation never changes her cour≈øe, he may find much right; and, if he is endowed with a good heart, will candidly attribute the errors to mi≈øinformation, or the common infirmity of human nature.
